('58', 0, 1, 2, 47) 1. STATEMENT ON UNTOUCHABILITY 1 VII
('58', 0, 2, 3, 84) POONA, November 16, 1932 Though the questions that I shall endeavour to answer in this statement have been more or less covered by the previous statements, as they continue to recur, I thought it would be well to collect as many as possible and to deal with them in one single statement.
('58', 0, 2, 4, 372) “Are you not forcing people to do things against their will?” is one such quest ion.
('58', 0, 2, 5, 457) At least, such is not my intention.
('58', 0, 2, 6, 493) The contemplated fast 2 is intended to stengthen the weak, to energize the sluggards and to give faith to the sceptics.
('58', 0, 2, 7, 613) It should be clear to anyone who will give a little thought to it that those who are hostile to the reform will not only be unaffected by the fast, but will probably and perhaps rightly, from their own standpoint, welcome it, if only it ends fatally.
('58', 0, 2, 8, 864) An angry correspondent does not hesitate to say it in so many words, but says another correspondent, “it is all very well for you to say, you do not intend to do such and such a thing.
('58', 0, 2, 9, 1049) There are many orthodox people who will follow the multitude for fear of personal injury from your over zealous followers.” An argument like this can be advanced under almost any con ceivable circumstance.
('58', 0, 2, 10, 1255) I have led many movements in my lifetime where there has been no fast necessary, but the charge I am now answering has been brought against me often enough, in order to turn me away from my purpose.
('58', 0, 2, 11, 1454) Whatever the intended consequences of the contemplated fast may be, apart from its being a question of honour, it must be taken up, if the occasion arises, for the additional reason that it is certain to stir to worthy effort tens of thousands of people who have faith in me.
('58', 0, 2, 12, 1730) Such must be the case in every movement of a religious character.
('58', 0, 2, 13, 1796) The second question is:
('58', 0, 3, 14, 1820) 1 Issued by Gandhiji, from the Yeravda Central Prison, Poona.
('58', 0, 3, 15, 1882) The earlier six statements were issued on the 4th, 5th, 7th, 9th, 14th and 15th November, 1932. 2 In sympathy with Kelappan’s fast for the opening of the Guruvayur Temple to Harijans; vide “Statement on Untouchability IX”, 26 11 1932. The fast was to commence on January 2, 1933, but was postponed.
('58', 1, 0, 1, 2181) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAATMA GANDHI 2
('58', 1, 1, 2, 2220) Are you not setting one section of the Hindus against another?
('58', 1, 1, 3, 2283) Most emphatically not.
('58', 1, 1, 4, 2306) Some opposition is inevitable in every reform.
('58', 1, 1, 5, 2353) But up to a point.
('58', 1, 1, 6, 2372) Opposition and agitation in a society are a sign of healthy growth.
('58', 1, 1, 7, 2440) I have no fear whatsoever of a permanent cleavage between the sanatanists and the reformers.
('58', 1, 1, 8, 2533) Far be it from me either to underrate the sanatanist opposition or to disregard their senti ment.
('58', 1, 1, 9, 2631) I have no doubt whatsoever that some of them feel strongly that sanatan dharma is in danger.
('58', 1, 1, 10, 2724) Nevertheless it is astonishing how narrow at least in theory is the difference between the sanatanist and the reformer.
('58', 1, 1, 11, 2844) Almost every letter that I have received from the sanatanists makes these startling admissions: 1. We admit that there is much to be done for the amelioration of the condition of the Harijans; 2. we admit that many caste Hindus are ill treating the Harijans; 3. we admit that their children should receive education and that they should have better quarters to live in; 4. we admit that they should have proper arrangement for bathing and drawing water for them selves; 5. we admit that they should have full political rights; 6. we admit that they should have ample facilities for worship and 7. we admit that they should have all the civic rights that the others have.
('58', 1, 1, 12, 3515) But, say these sanatanists, “we must not be compelled to touch them or associate with them, especially whilst they are in their present condition.” Then I say to them, since you admit the necessity for putting them on the same level with you, why are you agitated that other caste Hindus will go a step further and believe on strength of the same Shastras that you believe in, that is, their duty is not to regard the Harijans as untouchables, but to have them share with themselves all those rights and privileges which you concede to them, but which you would have them to enjoy and exercise in isolation from you?
('58', 1, 1, 13, 4132) Surely you who want to guard your own liberty of action and rightly resent the very idea of coercion, will not desire that the reformers should be coerced into carrying out schemes of amelioration which you hold to be necessary in exactly the same manner as you would like.
('58', 1, 1, 14, 4406) I venture to suggest a better way.
('58', 1, 1, 15, 4441) Since you are at one with the reformers in conceding the desirability of ameliorating the condition of the Harijans and since you have not hitherto done anything tangible in that direction, subscribe liberally to the funds that the
('58', 2, 0, 1, 4673) VOL. 58 : 16 NOVEMBER, 1932 14 JANUARY, 1933 3
('58', 2, 1, 2, 4720) reformers are collecting, and use them as your agents for carrying out the common scheme and respect their interpretation of Hindu religion, as you would have them to respect yours.
('58', 2, 1, 3, 4902) Hitherto, in pra ctice, you have not resented the reformer’s action in associating with the Harijans.
('58', 2, 1, 4, 5004) You have suffered him to go his own way.
('58', 2, 1, 5, 5045) You have not boycotted him.
('58', 2, 1, 6, 5073) There is, then, no meaning in your opposition now simply because the movement has become more active and more universal than before.
('58', 2, 1, 7, 5206) One difficulty is still standing in the way.
('58', 2, 1, 8, 5251) Who is to have the use of public temples and other public institutions that are in existence, and from which Harijans are at present debarred, in some cases legally and in other far more numerous cases, illegally?
('58', 2, 1, 9, 5465) There is a very simple way out of the difficulty.
('58', 2, 1, 10, 5515) If only each party will shed anger and mutual disrespect, a referendum can easily be taken for each village or a group of villages and each city or each division of a city, and whichever party has the majority in favour of its view should make use of the public institutions, including the temples.
('58', 2, 1, 11, 5814) And if the sanatanists carry the majority with them, they should defray their share with the reformers of the cost of providing equal services for the reformers and the untouchables.
('58', 2, 1, 12, 5997) I bracket the reformers with the Harijans, for if they are worth their salt and will work up to their convictions, as time progresses, the duty must dawn upon them of denying to themselves the use of a single service which the Harijans cannot enjoy with the caste Hindus on absolutely equal terms.
('58', 2, 1, 13, 6295) Following out this train of reasoning the sanatanists will see that in justice they should bear the whole cost of bringing into being parallel services, because as I have understood the correspondence and as I have explained above, the sanatanists agree that the Harijans are entitled to the same services that they have hitherto enjoyed, and of which the Harijans have hitherto been deprived.
('58', 2, 1, 14, 6689) Let not the sanatanists run away with themselves by picturing a condition of things as existing but which in reality does not exist.
('58', 2, 1, 15, 6822) Let them clearly understand that the removal of untouchability in accordance with the Yeravda Pact 1, and with the declaration of the
('58', 2, 2, 16, 6956) 1 Between the leaders acting on behalf of the depressed classes and of the rest of the Hindu community, regarding the representation of the depressed classes in legislatures and certain other matters affecting their welfare.
('58', 2, 2, 17, 7181) For the text of the agreement, vide Appendix”Agreement between depressed classes leaders and caste Hindu Leaders”.
('58', 3, 0, 1, 7296) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAATMA GANDHI 4
('58', 3, 1, 2, 7335) recently formed All India Anti Untouchability League includes no more than I have narrated.
('58', 3, 1, 3, 7427) It does not include inter dining and inter marriage.
('58', 3, 1, 4, 7480) That many Hindus including myself would go muchfurther ought not to disturb the sanatanists.
('58', 3, 1, 5, 7573) They will not want to stifle private judgment or private action, and if they have deep faith in what they believe, they should not take fright, in anticipation of what is to come.
('58', 3, 1, 6, 7753) If a particular reform has an inherent vitality and has come in response to the needs of the time, no power on earth can stem its irresistible march.
('58', 3, 1, 7, 7903) The third question is:
('58', 3, 2, 8, 7926) Are you not retarding political emancipation by forcing on public attention your views on social and religious questions, and springing upon the public a hurricane agitation for their acceptance?
('58', 3, 2, 9, 8122) I cannot answer this question at length without trespassing upon the limits which, as a prisoner, I have accepted for conducting the anti untouchability campaign.
('58', 3, 2, 10, 8285) But this much I can say that those who know me at all should understand that I draw no hard and fast line of demarcation between political, social, religious and other questions.
('58', 3, 2, 11, 8464) I have always held that they are inter dependent and that the solution of one brings nearer the solution of the rest.
('58', 3, 2, 12, 8582) This does not exhaust the questions which I have collected from the correspondence which is already proving more than I can handle with the very limited assistance which only naturally I can have.
('58', 3, 2, 13, 8779) I must deal with the rest to the best of my ability in the statement 1 to follow.
('58', 3, 2, 14, 8861) I would here like to urge the correspondents to be merciful.
('58', 3, 2, 15, 8922) Hitherto, I have punctiliously acknowledged almost all the letters that have reached me.
('58', 3, 2, 16, 9011) But the correspondents will henceforth please be satisfied with whatever answers I can give through the series of statements I am issuing, and they will help themselves and me, if they will be brief and write only when they have something original to say or when they have questions to which they must have answers from me, before they can form their judgment on any issue arising in connection with the movement.
('58', 3, 2, 17, 9425) The Bombay Chronicle, 17 11 1932
('58', 3, 3, 18, 9458) 1 Vide”Statement on Untouchability—VIII”, 17 11 1932.

('58', 4, 1, 2, 9559) 2. FOREWORD TO “HAMARA KALANK”
('58', 4, 2, 3, 9590) November 16, 1932 This venture of Sasta Sahitya Mandal is laudable.
('58', 4, 2, 4, 9658) As there is such a rigorous movement afoot for the eradication of untouchability, everyone must, as a matter of course, know what is being done in this direction and how.
('58', 4, 2, 5, 9829) We want, through enlightenment, to do away with this sin.
('58', 4, 2, 6, 9887) It is, therefore, essential for the Hindu public to re alize the implications of untouchability and our duty in this matter.

('58', 5, 3, 4, 11138) 5. LETTER TO K. NATARAJAN 1
('58', 5, 4, 5, 11166) November 16, 1932 I have both your letters.
('58', 5, 4, 6, 11210) I am delighted that the doctor has got a suitable job in Delhi.
('58', 5, 4, 7, 11274) Your second letter is an appeal to reason, and rightly so.
('58', 5, 4, 8, 11333) But there are two difficulties about appeals to reason in a case like mine.
('58', 5, 4, 9, 11409) In the first place, though the reasoning may be perfectly sound, it may not be based on the same premises, and there fore may fail to carry conviction.
('58', 5, 4, 10, 11561) Secondly, as you yourself have justly remarked, a case like mine transcends reason.
('58', 5, 4, 11, 11645) Nevertheless I have always desired in such cases to compare notes with kindred spirits.
('58', 5, 4, 12, 11733) For I do believe that with fallible human beings there is no such thing as absolute surety, even about promptings of the inner voice.
('58', 5, 4, 13, 11867) God requires the purest instruments to speak through, but poor mortals can only make an approach to perfection.
('58', 5, 4, 14, 11979) And whilst they are confined in their bodies, they can never attain perfection.
('58', 5, 4, 15, 12059) What I therefore want is with the utmost freedom to discuss with you whatever has been actuating me in the hope that either you will see my viewpoint and find perfect justification for my action, or some argu ment or a word coming from you may discover to me a flaw that might have escaped me.
('58', 5, 4, 16, 12353) I confess however I have no doubt in my mind about the ethics of the proposed fast.
('58', 5, 4, 17, 12437) I am therefore suffering from no mental disturbance and therefore I do not want you to hasten back to Bombay.
('58', 5, 4, 18, 12547) Do carry out all your private and public program mes in the North and when in due course you come back to Bombay I would like you when you can spare a few hours to run up to Poona to have a brief interchange of views.
('58', 5, 5, 19, 12765) Mahadevbhaini Diary, Vol. II, pp.
('58', 5, 6, 20, 12799) 1 Editor, Indian Social Reformer

('58', 6, 1, 2, 12879) 6. LETTER TO CHAMAN KAVI
('58', 6, 2, 3, 12904) November 16, 1932 If, on the one hand, hundreds of self seeking men have misused mosques, temples and churches, on the other, millions have made good use of them.
('58', 6, 2, 4, 13067) If you wish to test the truth of this statement, use your wonderful gift of imagination and suppose that a reformer razes to the ground in a single day all the churches, temples and mosques.
('58', 6, 2, 5, 13258) Then picture to yourself the condition of those millions of simple good souls when they discover that the temples and mosques from which they daily derived consolation and support were no more.
('58', 6, 2, 6, 13452) I see the truth of this every day.
('58', 6, 2, 7, 13487) Devotees who visit even the most unholy temples with pure heart certainly feel the presence of God in those temples, so wonderful is the mystery of His Nature, or say His maya.
('58', 6, 2, 8, 13664) But some great bhakta was inspired and sang: “Maya casts a spell on all, but she is helpless before a God lover”.
('58', 6, 2, 9, 13778) If, therefore, you realize through your imagination that so long as temples exist they should be open for Harijans too, your own reason will convince you of the necessity of the fast.
('58', 6, 2, 10, 13962) My fast is not aimed against the sanatanists; it is aimed against the thousands or rather the millions who are bound to me [by the tie of love].
('58', 6, 2, 11, 14107) If the fast shocks them out of their slumber, the temples are bound to be thrown open to Harijans.
('58', 6, 2, 12, 14206) I have infinite patience as regards the spinning wheel.
('58', 6, 2, 13, 14262) Your experience of villages is limited to Kutch.
('58', 6, 2, 14, 14311) But conditions in the thousands of other villages are far different from those in the villages of Kutch.
('58', 6, 2, 15, 14416) And even in Kutch no cloth can be cheaper than what is produced by the cultivator with his own labour from cotton growing in his own fields.
('58', 6, 2, 16, 14557) If there is any such cloth, you may say that it is a shroud rather than cloth which protects the weaver against cold and heat or covers his shame.
('58', 6, 2, 17, 14704) Suppose somebody offers me, instead of water, a poisonous liquid which looks like water, gives it free and even offers to me the glass which contains it as a gift, and another person offers real water but pours it from his jug into my folded palms and asks four pice for the service, whose offer should I accept?
('58', 6, 2, 18, 15017) You are impatient, your mind is very much unsteady and your faith is short lived.
('58', 6, 2, 19, 15099) That is why you get irritated every now and then.
('58', 6, 2, 20, 15149) But this is not your true nature.
('58', 6, 2, 21, 15183) It is a disease in you.
('58', 6, 2, 22, 15207) Get rid of it, Your truenature is capable of patience and iron firmness of mind.
('58', 6, 2, 23, 15288) One need not put faith in anything too readily, but once we have put faith in a thing after the most careful thought, we must cling to it as tenaciously
('58', 7, 0, 1, 15441) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAATMA GANDHI 8
('58', 7, 1, 2, 15480) as does a black ant to a jar of jaggery.
('58', 7, 1, 3, 15521) “Better lose one’s life rather than break one’s plighted word.” I think I have written enough now.
('58', 7, 2, 4, 15620) [From Gujarati]
('58', 7, 3, 5, 15636) Mahadevbhaini Diary, Vol. II, pp.

('58', 8, 1, 2, 16799) 9. STATEMENT ON UNTOUCHABILITY VIII
('58', 8, 2, 3, 16835) POONA November 17, 1932 Here is another question that many correspondents have asked:
('58', 8, 3, 4, 16921) You say you believe in the Shastras.
('58', 8, 3, 5, 16958) We do not understand what you mean by them, for you seem arbitrarily to reject many things which are supported by the Shastras.
('58', 8, 3, 6, 17086) Even the Gita that you swear by requires one to
('58', 8, 4, 7, 17134) follow the Shastras.
('58', 8, 4, 8, 17155) I must repeat what I have said in a previous statement 1 that for me, nothing that is inconsistent with the main theme of the Gita is Shastra, no matter where it is found printed.
('58', 8, 4, 9, 17335) If I do not shock my orthodox friends, I would like to make my meaning clearer still.
('58', 8, 4, 10, 17421) Nothing that is inconsistent with the universally accepted first prin ciples of morality has for me the authority of the Shastras.
('58', 8, 4, 11, 17552) They are designed not to supersede, but to sustain the first principles, and the Gita is all sufficing for me, because it not only conforms to the first principles, but gives you reasons for adherence to them at any cost.
('58', 8, 4, 12, 17774) But for this Golden Rule that I have suggested, laymen like me would flounder in the midst of a forest of conflicting texts and a pile of nicely printed and equally nicely bound Sanskrit volumes, for which rival pundits claim divine authority.
('58', 8, 4, 13, 18018) Thus, there are many Smritis, some of which are unknown outside the little areas in which, by a few hundred men they are held in veneration.
('58', 8, 4, 14, 18159) No one can give their origin or the dates of their com position.
('58', 8, 4, 15, 18224) I saw one such volume in the South.
('58', 8, 4, 16, 18260) When I inquired of the learned scholar friends about this volume, they told me that they had no knowledge of it.
('58', 8, 4, 17, 18373) There are numerous Agamas 2 which when examined, contradict one another and which have no binding effect outside the little areas where they find acceptance.
('58', 8, 4, 18, 18531) If all these books were to be held as binding on the Hindus, there is hardly an immoral practice for which it would be difficult to find Shastric sanction, and even in the hoary Manusmriti from which if the verses of doubtful authenticity are not expurgated, one would discover several texts contradicting the loftiest morals and teachingsto
('58', 8, 5, 19, 18873) 1 Vide “Statement on Untouchability—I”, 4 11 1932.
('58', 8, 6, 20, 18924) 2 Scriptures
('58', 9, 0, 1, 18937) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAATMA GANDHI 10
('58', 9, 1, 2, 18977) be found spread throughout that great book.
('58', 9, 1, 3, 19021) Therefore the meaning I have given to the word ‘Shastras’ in the Bhagavad Gita, wherein it occurs only in one context, is not any book or set of laws outside the Gita itself, but it means right conduct embodied in a living authority.
('58', 9, 1, 4, 19255) I know that this is not likely to satisfy the critic, and as a layman I can give no lead to anybody, but I can satisfy the curiosity of my critics by telling them what I mean exactly by the Shastras.
('58', 9, 1, 5, 19455) Another question put with equal persistence is this:
('58', 9, 2, 6, 19508) What do you mean by divine guidance or the inner voice, and how would you and for that matter the world, fare, if every one claimed such guidance for himself and each acted in a manner wholly different from his neighbours?
('58', 9, 2, 7, 19731) This is a fair question, and we would come to a pretty pass if divinity had made no provision by way of self protection.
('58', 9, 2, 8, 19852) Whilst, therefore, all may lay the claim, some alone will be able to justify it.
('58', 9, 2, 9, 19933) A person falsely claiming to act under divine inspiration or the promptings of the inner voice without having any such, will fare worse than the one falsely claiming to act under the authority of an earthly sovereign.
('58', 9, 2, 10, 20151) Whereas the latter on being exposed will escape with injury to his body the former may perish body and soul together.
('58', 9, 2, 11, 20269) Charitable critics impute no fraud to me, but suggest that I am highly likely to be acting under some hallucination.
('58', 9, 2, 12, 20386) The result for me, even then, will not be far different from what it would be, if I was laying a false claim.
('58', 9, 2, 13, 20496) A humble seeker that I claim to be has need to be most cautious and to preserve the balance of mind.
('58', 9, 2, 14, 20597) He has to reduce himself to zero before God will guide him.
('58', 9, 2, 15, 20657) Let me not labour this point.
('58', 9, 2, 16, 20687) The claim I have made is neither extraordinary, nor exclusive.
('58', 9, 2, 17, 20750) God will rule the lives of all those who will surrender themselves with out reservation to Him.
('58', 9, 2, 18, 20846) In the language of the Gita, God acts through those who have acquired complete detachment, i.e., self effacement here.
('58', 9, 2, 19, 20965) There is no question of hallucination.
('58', 9, 2, 20, 21004) I have stated a simple sci entific truth, thus to be tested by all who have the will and the patience to acquire the necessary qualifications which are again incredibly simple to understand and easy enough to acquire where there is deter mination.
('58', 9, 2, 21, 21252) Lastly, no one need worry about my claim.
('58', 9, 2, 22, 21294) What I am asking the people to do is capable of being verified by reason.
('58', 9, 2, 23, 21368) Even when
('58', 10, 0, 1, 21378) VOL. 58 : 16 NOVEMBER, 1932 14 JANUARY, 1933 11
('58', 10, 1, 2, 21426) I disappear from the scene, untouchability will have to be removed.
('58', 10, 1, 3, 21494) Whether the fast is divinely inspired or not, need not be a matter of concern even to my closest associates.
('58', 10, 1, 4, 21603) They may, out of affection for me, work with double zeal in the cause.
('58', 10, 1, 5, 21674) That would [not] be a calamity, even if it was found that the fast was the foolish act of a self willed friend.
('58', 10, 1, 6, 21786) Those who have neither affection for, nor faith in, me will remain unmoved by it.
('58', 10, 1, 7, 21868) Constant harping, therefore, on the contemplated fast or my claim in regard thereto, is calculated to befog the public mind and the attention from the great work before the nation.
('58', 10, 1, 8, 22049) I would therefore conclude this statement by drawing the readers’ attention to a few pictures that I have picked up from the voluminous correspondence in my possession.
('58', 10, 1, 9, 22218) Here is one from Vile Parle, suburb of Bombay, inhabited by well to do Hindus among others.
('58', 10, 1, 10, 22310) The suburb has in round figures, 1,700 villas or houses; the Municipality has an income of Rs. 70,000 of which Rs. 31,000 are spent for conservancy.
('58', 10, 1, 11, 22459) The scavengers are accommodated in quarters where there are no roads, no arrangement for water supply and no sanitary convenience.
('58', 10, 1, 12, 22590) The land itself is low lying, the huts are hovels constructed from dilapidated tins which were once used for conservancy work.
('58', 10, 1, 13, 22717) There is no lighting, and nearby is the dumping ground for all the suburban rubbish which gives an eternal stench.
('58', 10, 1, 14, 22832) Next to it is a structure for housing con servancy; attached to this is a water pipe for washing dirty tins, and if the overseer is well disposed he would allow the scavengers to help themselves to water from the pipe; on the other side, is a row of carts that receive the buckets collected from the privies of households.
('58', 10, 1, 15, 23155) It is in these surroundings that the scavengers have to pass their life.
('58', 10, 1, 16, 23228) These quarters are surrounded by fields which are often under water, bree ding mosquitoes, harbouring scorpions, snakes, field rats.
('58', 10, 1, 17, 23361) Thirty one families live in this condition, they are composed of 35 men, 25 women, 34 boys and 15 girls.
('58', 10, 1, 18, 23466) Of this population of 109, only 9 boys can at all read and write with difficulty.
('58', 10, 1, 19, 23548) The rest are utterly illiterate.
('58', 10, 1, 20, 23581) This is a suburb where if the inhabitants, if they had any thought for these fellow beings of theirs, could well afford to provide for them decent accommodation in decent quarters with lighting and water and other conveniences which are part of city life.
('58', 10, 1, 21, 23837) There is work here for both the sanatanists and the reformers.
('58', 10, 1, 22, 23900) It would be no answer to my complaint that the Vile Parle
('58', 11, 0, 1, 23958) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAATMA GANDHI 12
('58', 11, 1, 2, 23998) Municipality has an income of only Rs. 70,000 out of which it spends the princely sum of Rs. 31,000 on conservancy.
('58', 11, 1, 3, 24114) I know that the inhabitants of Vile Parle are well to do enough to tax themselves specially on behalf of these useful servants of society.
('58', 11, 1, 4, 24253) But I would regard that as a slow process.
('58', 11, 1, 5, 24296) It is the primary duty of the Hindu habitants to make decent collections overnight and provide suitable quarters and other conveniences for the scavengers.
('58', 11, 1, 6, 24452) If they did so, even then it would be a tardy performance of a simple duty done to fellowmen.
('58', 11, 1, 7, 24546) When they have done this, there would be a point in their moving the Municipality to take up the burden of additional annual expenditure that would undoubtedly have to be incurred in order to enable the scavengers to live in comparative comfort.
('58', 11, 1, 8, 24792) An almost identical picture has been drawn by Sjt.
('58', 11, 1, 9, 24843) A. V. Thakkar, the tireless Secretary of the All India [Anti ] Untouchability League, of scavengers’ quarters he has inspected during his travels undertaken on behalf of the League.
('58', 11, 1, 10, 25025) He gives a harrowing tale about the condition of such quarters in Danapur and other places about Patna in Bihar.
('58', 11, 1, 11, 25138) Now I wish that instead of engaging in fruitless contro versy about what is not contained in the Shastras about untouchability, everyone of us would apply ourselves to ameliorating the conditions of the so called untouchables.
('58', 11, 1, 12, 25365) There is work enough and to spare for all my learned correspondents who almost without exception have assured me that they yield to no one in their desire to better their material and moral conditions.
('58', 11, 1, 13, 25567) The Bombay Chronicle, 18 11 1932

('58', 13, 2, 3, 28297) YERAVDA CENTRAL PRISON, 1
('58', 13, 3, 4, 28323) November 17, 1932
('58', 13, 4, 5, 28341) DEAR COL.
('58', 13, 4, 6, 28351) DOYLE, I thank you for your letter of the 15th instant in answer to my letter 2 regarding Shrimati Manibehn Patel.
('58', 13, 4, 7, 28466) As the request made in that letter had reference to a very urgent matter, I had expected an imme diate reply to be of value.
('58', 13, 4, 8, 28591) Fortunately her brother’s illness has not yet reached the danger point but it is serious enough to cause anxiety to those who are deeply interested in the patient 3. A request on behalf of a near relative as Manibehn Patel that she should be informed of the progress of her brother’s illness from day to day, I do not regard as one for a concession.
('58', 13, 4, 9, 28941) I venture to submit that it is a human right belonging to every person although he or she may be a prisoner.
('58', 13, 4, 10, 29050) I would therefore like the Government to consider my request from that human standpoint.
('58', 13, 4, 11, 29139) I have no desire whatsoever to ask for a concession which being such may not be expected to be granted to every other prisoner in similar circumstances.
('58', 13, 4, 12, 29292) And lest Government may not know, as you do, why I have made the request rather than her father, I may state that it is simply because Manibehn has been an inmate of the Ashram and has been placed by her father under my guidance since 1924. To complete the relevant information that should be put at the disposal of Government I may add that I wrote my letter to you with the consent and approval of Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel.
('58', 13, 4, 13, 29718) Will you kindly place this letter before the Government if their orders have not been already received ere this reaches you?
('58', 13, 5, 14, 29843) Yours sincerely,
('58', 13, 6, 15, 29860) M. K. GANDHI

('58', 15, 1, 2, 31645) 13. LETTER TO BHAU PANSE 1
('58', 15, 2, 3, 31672) November 17, 1932
('58', 15, 3, 4, 31690) BHAU, I liked your question about cow protection.
('58', 15, 3, 5, 31740) Giving up milk altogether is no doubt our ideal; but I do not think that we can act upon it now.
('58', 15, 3, 6, 31837) Hence, at present, our ideal should be to maintain in the Ashram as many cows as possible, and to provide as much milk as we can.
('58', 15, 3, 7, 31967) We do not have the necessary stability in the Ashram for that, but when conditions become stable, I am eager to do a good deal of work in that field.
('58', 15, 3, 8, 32117) God willing, I shall be able to do it.
('58', 15, 3, 9, 32156) I certainly think it morally wrong to get milk from weak cows.
('58', 15, 3, 10, 32219) At present we cannot escape that.
('58', 15, 3, 11, 32253) In India, we get milk from really healthy cows at very few places.
('58', 15, 3, 12, 32320) The fact is that Hinduism is in a state of utter confusion.
('58', 15, 3, 13, 32380) Though cow protection is one of the pillars on which Hinduism stands, nowhere in the world is the condition of cows more wretched than in India.
('58', 15, 3, 14, 32525) But you need not think too much about this and worry.
('58', 15, 3, 15, 32579) If you do your present duty, you will have done everything that is possible for you.
('58', 15, 3, 16, 32664) That your constipation is not yet cured indicates that your intestines have become very weak.
('58', 15, 3, 17, 32758) The disease has struck deep roots.
('58', 15, 3, 18, 32793) Whenever you do not pass stool and get headache, eat only vegetables if fruits are not available.
('58', 15, 3, 19, 32891) You will not get fever or headache then, will get some nourishment at least and will probably be able to pass stool.
('58', 15, 3, 20, 33008) I am sure that you can get many varieties of leafy vegetables in the Ashram just now.
('58', 15, 3, 21, 33094) If, however, you find that the place does not suit you, you may even go and stay in Rajkot for a while after consulting Chhaganlal.
('58', 15, 3, 22, 33226) The experience will be useful to you and the water of Rajkot may even suit you.

('58', 19, 14, 23, 39016) 23. LETTER TO M. G. BHANDARI
('58', 19, 15, 24, 39045) November 19, 1932
('58', 19, 16, 25, 39063) DEAR MAJOR BHANDARI, You have kindly showed me a memorandum from Government in connection with my interview 2 with the correspondent of The Hindu which refers to Lord Sankey’s letter.
('58', 19, 16, 26, 39247) In the light of that memorandum I have read and re read the Government of India’s decision on my letters requesting facilities in regard to visitors and correspondence on removal of untouchability.
('58', 19, 16, 27, 39445) I can see absolutely no inconsistency between the undertaking given by me and the reference to Lord Sankey’s letter in the interview.
('58', 19, 16, 28, 39579) It would be found on a perusal of the
('58', 19, 17, 29, 39617) 1 Padmaja Naidu’s birthday fell on November 18. 2 On November 12, 1932; Vide”Interview to the Hindu”, 12 11 1932.
('58', 20, 0, 1, 39731) VOL. 58 : 16 NOVEMBER, 1932 14 JANUARY, 1933 21
('58', 20, 1, 2, 39779) interview that rather than in any shape or form depart from my under taking I have expressed my inability, because of the undertaking, to deal with the letter except through the Government.
('58', 20, 1, 3, 39969) I am however grateful to Government for having drawn my attention to what they consider is inconsistency between my under taking and the reference to Lord Sankey’s letter in the interview in question.
('58', 20, 1, 4, 40170) I would add that I am carrying out the undertaking in most difficult circumstances.
('58', 20, 1, 5, 40254) Questions crop up in the course of interviews which have a vital bearing upon untouchability work, but which strictly speaking would be outside untouchability.
('58', 20, 1, 6, 40414) I rigorously refrain from answering them even at the risk of being misunderstood and the cause [of] suffering.
('58', 20, 1, 7, 40525) As it is, generally either you or the Jailor has been present at the interviews.
('58', 20, 1, 8, 40606) You or he will perhaps bear me out when I state that I have scrupulously refused to give my opinion on any matter outside untouchability and have even refused to receive visitors, whether Indian or European, when I have known that they could not have anything important to say on untouchability or when they have desired a discussion on the political aspect of untoucha bility.
('58', 20, 1, 9, 40984) I feel that in doing the last thing I have gone beyond the letter of the Government of India’s decision and my undertaking, but I know that the spirit of them would exclude discussion even on the political aspect of untouchability.
('58', 20, 1, 10, 41216) I have here in mind the corres pon dence I am carrying on with Mr. Jenkins.
('58', 20, 1, 11, 41292) Nevertheless if this reply does not satisfy the Government I suggest their sending an official to discuss with me exactly what the Government would have me to do in matters such as the one which is the subject matter of this correspondence.
('58', 20, 1, 12, 41533) And if consistently with my work I can carry out their wishes I would do so with great pleasure.
('58', 20, 1, 13, 41630) My one desire in the midst of the extraordinary facilities given to me in extraordinary circumstances is, if it is at all possible, to earn at the end of the chapter a certificate from Government that the undertaking given by me had been carried out in an honourable manner.
('58', 20, 2, 14, 41905) Yours sincerely,
('58', 20, 3, 15, 41922) M. K. GANDHI
('58', 20, 4, 16, 41935) Bombay Secret Abstracts, Home Department, Special Branch, File No.

('58', 21, 7, 13, 42480) 25. LETTER TO ANANDSHANKAR B. DHRUVA
('58', 21, 8, 14, 42517) November 19, 1932 You have always been diffident about yourself.
('58', 21, 8, 15, 42582) You were no less diffident when you got an offer to go to Banaras.
('58', 21, 8, 16, 42649) But see, how many years have you spent there?
('58', 21, 8, 17, 42695) And who knows for how many more years still you may remain there?
('58', 21, 8, 18, 42761) Your diffidence is not likely to have any effect on me.
('58', 21, 8, 19, 42817) Rajaji has advanced a very sound argument against Malaviyaji’s going to the South.
('58', 21, 8, 20, 42900) So long as he has not opened the Kashi Vishvanath Temple (for Harijans), the pundits of the South will not listen to him.
('58', 21, 8, 21, 43022) They will ask him to open that temple before going to the South.
('58', 21, 8, 22, 43087) We should not put him in that awkward position.
('58', 21, 8, 23, 43135) Moreover, Rajaji has also argued that, in view of Malaviyaji’s indifferent health, we should not ask him to undertake such a long journey.
('58', 21, 8, 24, 43274) If, therefore, Malaviyaji agrees, you should immediately start as his representative.
('58', 21, 8, 25, 43360) Don’t mind if the people do not listen to you.
('58', 21, 8, 26, 43407) But I don’t think that is likely to happen.
('58', 21, 8, 27, 43451) So much about your tour of the South.
('58', 21, 8, 28, 43489) Now, about the correct interpretation of the Shastras.
('58', 21, 8, 29, 43544) I send with this some of the literature on the subject given to me.
('58', 21, 8, 30, 43612) Go through it carefully and draft a well reasoned reply as soon as you can and
('58', 21, 9, 31, 43691) 1 Vide also “Telegram to Manibehn Patel”, 19 11 1932.
('58', 22, 0, 1, 43745) VOL. 58 : 16 NOVEMBER, 1932 14 JANUARY, 1933 23
('58', 22, 1, 2, 43793) obtain on it signatures of all the pundits whom you can persuade to join with you.
('58', 22, 1, 3, 43876) The reply should be in Sanskrit, Hindi and English.
('58', 22, 1, 4, 43928) It should be addressed to four types of readers: to the honest sanatanists, to impartial students who wish to know the truth, to persons who are working for the removal of untouchability and to whom your statement can be a great help in meeting the arguments of the sanatanists and, last, to non Hindus who should know that the true sanatana dharma does not consider anybody as untouchable from birth and that, if in certain circumstances, a person is considered untouchable, he or she soon becomes touchable again.
('58', 22, 1, 5, 44444) You should also point out that the oppression to which the untouchables are subjected today has no sanction in the Shastras at all.
('58', 22, 1, 6, 44576) I quote here a sentence from a man whom you, I and many other thousands respect:
('58', 22, 2, 7, 44657) In this part of the country these classes have come to be excluded from temples from the very time the people started worshipping in temples.
('58', 22, 2, 8, 44799) Scholars will find it difficult to ascertain the time when the untouchableswere permitted to enter temples.
('58', 22, 2, 9, 44907) I am afraid, though I don’t take pride in the fact that our religion as it is practised today enjoins exclusion of the untouchables.
('58', 22, 2, 10, 45040) The people who cling to the practice as a religious principle have the law, the Shastras and tradition on their side.
('58', 22, 2, 11, 45158) They are the sanatanists.
('58', 22, 2, 12, 45184) You have to reply to this argument.
('58', 22, 2, 13, 45220) Law, i.e., the law of the Government, may be on their side, custom, i.e., the custom of the degenerate present, may also be on their side.
('58', 22, 2, 14, 45359) But the Shastras at any rate are not.
('58', 22, 2, 15, 45397) If you can honestly show that the law of the Hindu period was not on the side of the sanatanists and also that true custom, i.e., the practice of the enlightened, was never on their side during the great prosperous days of Hinduism, you should do that convincingly.
('58', 22, 2, 16, 45663) Your statement should not be like a pronouncement of the Delphic oracle.
('58', 22, 2, 17, 45736) Send me as early as you can a statement enunciating such a Dhruva 1 principle.
('58', 22, 3, 18, 45815) [From Gujarati]
('58', 22, 4, 19, 45831) Mahadevbhaini Diary, Vol. II, pp.

('58', 23, 10, 11, 46335) starting work throughout Maharashtra, in connection with the uplift of the

('58', 23, 14, 16, 46640) pointed out that difficulties they had to face in removing untouchability and throwing
('58', 23, 15, 17, 46727) temples open to the untouchables in the province of Malabar were much greater than
('58', 23, 16, 18, 46810) those in other provinces.

('58', 23, 20, 23, 47078) experiences he had in Malabar, should undertake propaganda work in that province to

('58', 24, 1, 2, 47430) 28. LETTER TO THORNBERG 1
('58', 24, 2, 3, 47456) Norember 20, 1932 I thank you for your letter.
('58', 24, 2, 4, 47503) I was sorry not to be able to see you.
('58', 24, 2, 5, 47542) The way America can help in this internal movement of reform is first by understanding and studying the movement and pronouncing intelligent opinion upon it.
('58', 24, 2, 6, 47700) Even orthodoxy is today sensitive to reasoned opinion, even though it may come from outside; secondly, by placing at the disposal of the reformers the free aid of experts with reference to the economic question.
('58', 24, 2, 7, 47912) For instance, there is the tremen dous problem of carrion eaters.
('58', 24, 2, 8, 47978) They will not give up carrion eating so long as they continue to take charge of dead cattle, which they skin and whose flesh they eat.
('58', 24, 2, 9, 48113) I have myself tried to find clean and expeditious method of skinning carcasses and making the best use of all the contents of these carcasses.
('58', 24, 2, 10, 48256) Not wanting to, and not being able to pay for expert assistance, I have been obliged to grope in the dark.
('58', 24, 2, 11, 48363) America could easily send us free expert assistance in matters such as I have mentioned, without any ulterior proselytizing motives, if only religious minded men of America could be persuaded to believe that Hinduism, Islam and other great religions are just as true as Christianity and that they do not therefore need destruction but reformation where necessary.
('58', 24, 2, 12, 48727) The conviction can only come if sober minded Americans will study the present very big movement.
('58', 24, 3, 13, 48824) Mahadevbhaini Diary, Vol. II, pp.

('58', 33, 5, 10, 61906) 47. LETTER TO NARANDAS GANDHI
('58', 33, 6, 11, 61936) November 21, 1932
('58', 33, 7, 12, 61954) NARANDAS, The pressure of work on me is increasing day by day.
('58', 33, 7, 13, 62017) The condition of the two elbows also requires rest.
('58', 33, 7, 14, 62069) You should, therefore, tell everybody that at present they should not expect long letters from me.
('58', 33, 7, 15, 62168) Probably I may have to content myself with only a letter to you and one to Kusum 2 who is ill.
('58', 33, 7, 16, 62263) We should regard this as the smallest sacrifice that we can make for our Harijan friends.
('58', 33, 7, 17, 62353) We shall have to make much bigger sacrifices in future.
('58', 33, 7, 18, 62409) Even if the whole Ashram gave up its other activities and plunged in this movement of self purification, I would not regard that sacrifice as too big.
('58', 33, 7, 19, 62560) But there can be no renunciation without complete freedom from desire.
('58', 33, 7, 20, 62631) And there can be no freedom from desire without self purification.
('58', 33, 7, 21, 62698) Any body, therefore, who wishes to plunge into this yajna of self purif ication should purify himself.
('58', 33, 7, 22, 62801) The line “Hari’s way is for the brave” is perfectly applicable in the present situation.
('58', 33, 7, 23, 62890) But some of the inmates seem to tremble even at the suggestion for simplicity in food which I have made.
('58', 33, 7, 24, 62995) Those who tremble and cannot overcome their misgivings are at any rate truthful, and deserve compliments for that.
('58', 33, 7, 25, 63110) How long can self restraint practised through false shame endure?
('58', 33, 7, 26, 63176) Those who remember the story of the pilgrim 3
('58', 33, 8, 27, 63222) should reflect over how the other characters who, blindly following his example, got tired in two or three days and returned.
('58', 33, 9, 28, 63348) 1 Vide also Appendix “Discussion with The Times of India” Representative”.
('58', 33, 10, 29, 63423) 2 Kusum Gandhi, daughter of Vrajlal Gandhi 3 In John Bunyan’s Pilgrim’s Progress
('58', 34, 0, 1, 63504) VOL. 58 : 16 NOVEMBER, 1932 14 JANUARY, 1933 35
('58', 34, 1, 2, 63552) I do not get much time at present.
('58', 34, 1, 3, 63587) When I get some, I wish to suggest a good many more changes.
('58', 34, 1, 4, 63648) If we eat more than we need or eat things which we do not need for nourishment, we are guilty of theft according to our principle, besides harming our health.
('58', 34, 1, 5, 63807) The experiment which I suggest in this letter is not quackery, it is based on true science.
('58', 34, 1, 6, 63899) Really speaking, we should eat what the poor and the prisoners do not get only when those things become absolutely necessary in our case.
('58', 34, 1, 7, 64037) Hence I feel that we must from time to time advance towards greater and greater simplicity.
('58', 34, 1, 8, 64129) We should learn thesecret of eating only a few things at one meal.
('58', 34, 1, 9, 64196) Doctors have con ducted experiments and proved that this is necessary for health.
('58', 34, 1, 10, 64278) We may eat several things in the course of the day but we should not mix them all at the same meal.
('58', 34, 1, 11, 64378) We cannot eat at the same meal rotli, dal, vegetables, milk, rice, etc.
('58', 34, 1, 12, 64450) But we can eat at one meal rotli and milk, a vegetable and milk, rice and dal, rice and milk and rotli and dal.
('58', 34, 1, 13, 64562) We should never take dal and milk together.
('58', 34, 1, 14, 64606) Similarly, we should not eat wheat and bajri at the same meal.
('58', 34, 1, 15, 64669) And also it is better not to eat rice and vegetables together.
('58', 34, 1, 16, 64732) I make this suggestion because I have read about it and put it into practice.
('58', 34, 1, 17, 64810) If we follow this practice the burden on the stomach will be lightened and the body also will feel light.
('58', 34, 1, 18, 64916) Those who do not adopt such experiments with full knowledge [of their likely benefits] will certainly be upset by them.
('58', 34, 1, 19, 65036) If the mind does not co operate, such an experiment may possibly fail.
('58', 34, 1, 20, 65107) We shall suc ceed in it if we strengthen our mind by thinking that through such a practice we shall increase our capacity for renunciation, show proper regard for the poor, save money and benefit our health.
('58', 34, 1, 21, 65315) I am realizing in actual experience that milk, bread, vegetables and fruit make a completely balanced diet.
('58', 34, 1, 22, 65423) My weight has gone up to 103_ pounds.
('58', 34, 1, 23, 65461) I eat fresh fruits with nothing else.
('58', 34, 1, 24, 65499) With milk, I eat dates or a vegetable.
('58', 34, 1, 25, 65538) I mix half the quantity of milk with dates and drink the remaining half.
('58', 34, 1, 26, 65611) In this manner, I drink from two and a half to two and three quarter pounds of milk.
('58', 34, 1, 27, 65696) In the morning, I eat mosambis or oranges without fail.
('58', 34, 1, 28, 65752) At seven, I have milk and dates; at twelve, two oranges or mosambis, 1 and at four a vegetable, milk and one loaf of bread.
('58', 34, 1, 29, 65876) This is my daily food.
('58', 34, 1, 30, 65899) I have been thinking of omitting milk or bread.
('58', 34, 1, 31, 65947) I take twice a day sour lemon juice with water and soda bicarb.
('58', 34, 1, 32, 66011) Perhaps this may not be necessary.
('58', 34, 1, 33, 66046) I have yet to find that out.
('58', 34, 1, 34, 66075) Mirabehn is at present living on almost the same diet as I am doing,
('58', 34, 2, 35, 66144) 1 What follows is also available in M.M.U.\I.
('58', 35, 0, 1, 66190) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAATMA GANDHI 36
('58', 35, 1, 2, 66230) and she informs me that it has benefited her.
('58', 35, 1, 3, 66276) It is too early yet to attach importance to her experience.
('58', 35, 1, 4, 66336) Since her heart is behind her experiment, naturally she feels that it is benefiting her.
('58', 35, 1, 5, 66425) If there is no benefit in reality, we shall know by and by.
('58', 35, 1, 6, 66485) It is also necessary not to eat jowar porridge in excessive quantity.

('58', 35, 1, 9, 66798) Nobody should lose courage all too soon.
('58', 35, 1, 10, 66839) Thebest way of running the joint kitchen without much trouble is that anybody who does not like a particular item should not eat it, but without asking for something else in its place.
('58', 35, 1, 11, 67024) Every meal provides sufficient nourishment.

('58', 37, 1, 2, 69510) 50. INTERVIEW TO THE PRESS
('58', 37, 2, 3, 69537) November 21, 1932
('58', 37, 3, 4, 69555) In an interview Gandhiji thoroughly exposed the baselessness of certain assertions made by an Anglo Indian paper, which had come out with the story that Mahatmaji was ‘going spiritual’ as Aurobindo Ghosh had done, and that his interest in active politics was waning.
('58', 37, 4, 5, 69822) Gandhiji says that social reform is very important for Hinduism just now.
('58', 37, 4, 6, 69896) This, however, did not and could not divert him from his political objective.
('58', 37, 5, 7, 69974) To a straight question whether he intended devoting all his time to anti untouchability work, Mahatmaji said: I cannot say that such is my present intention, nor is it ever likely to be.
('58', 37, 5, 8, 70161) It will be perfectly true to say that my life is dedicated to this absolutely necessary reform in Hinduism, but my life is also dedicated to many other things.
('58', 37, 5, 9, 70321) I don’t regard my life as divisible into so many water tight compartments.
('58', 37, 5, 10, 70396) It is one organic whole, and it will be found that all my activities spring from the same source, namely, my passion for vindication of truth and non violence in every walk of life, be it ever so great or so small.
('58', 37, 6, 11, 70611) This in a nutshell supplies all the ‘terms’ on which the Mahatma is prepared to accept release.
('58', 37, 6, 12, 70707) Prospects of his release solely depend on the interpretation which officialdom will put on the above statement.
('58', 37, 7, 13, 70819) The Hindustan Times, 23 11 1932, and The Hindu, 23 11 1932
('58', 37, 8, 14, 70878) 51. FRAGMENT OF LETTER TO LORD SANKEY
('58', 37, 9, 15, 70916) [On or before November 22, 1932] 2
('58', 37, 10, 16, 70951) Replying to Lord Sankey’s invitation, it is understood Mahatma Gandhi has assured Lord Sankey that he was by instinct a co operator and actually dying for co operation.
('58', 37, 10, 17, 71120) But the Ottawa 3 and the Ordinance Bills showed no such desire for securing co operation.
('58', 37, 10, 18, 71210) Finally, the Mahatma is reported to have assured Lord Sankey that he would find “Gandhi in his pocket” if a genuine gesture of co operation is forthcoming from the Government side.
('58', 37, 10, 19, 71391) The Hindustan Times, 23 11 1932

('58', 38, 1, 2, 71909) 52. LETTER TO E. E. DOYLE
('58', 38, 2, 3, 71935) November 22, 1932
('58', 38, 3, 4, 71953) DEAR COL.
('58', 38, 3, 5, 71963) DOYLE, In continuation of my letter 1 regarding Sheth Jamnalal Bajaj, I have further information from his wife and children which makes me extremely anxious.
('58', 38, 3, 6, 72121) They have seen Dr. Modi of Sir J. J. Hospital, the specialist, who advised Jamnalalji before his incarceration.
('58', 38, 3, 7, 72233) Dr. Modi is not satisfied with his weight and general condition.
('58', 38, 3, 8, 72298) Seeing that he has not recently seen the patient, naturally his remarks are based upon the reports received by him from laymen.
('58', 38, 3, 9, 72426) Nevertheless when I add Dr. Modi’s remarks to the patient’s own state of mind as revealed in his telegram I become nervous.
('58', 38, 3, 10, 72550) Perhaps it would not be considered impertinent in this conn ection if I mention the fact that Jamnalalji looks up to me as to a parent.
('58', 38, 3, 11, 72686) His children are under my care and discipline.
('58', 38, 3, 12, 72733) He has himself lived in the Ashram off and on for several months at a time.
('58', 38, 3, 13, 72809) Naturally therefore even as a prisoner I try to give the members of his family what comfort and guidance I can, within the limitations put upon me, and it will be a great relief to me and his family if Jamnalalji could be transferred to this prison and is allowed facilities for such food and special medical advice as his health may require.
('58', 38, 3, 14, 73152) I would lay stress upon the almost universal medical opinion that Jamnalalji suffers from a disease which may any day assume an acute and even fatal form and that such symptoms arise without sufficient previous warn ing.
('58', 38, 3, 15, 73373) I therefore request an early decision by the Government.
('58', 38, 4, 16, 73430) Yours sincerely,

('58', 42, 4, 9, 79504) 59. LETTER TO K. KELAPPAN
('58', 42, 5, 10, 79530) November 23, 1932
('58', 42, 6, 11, 79548) MY DEAR KELAPPAN, I have your letter.
('58', 42, 6, 12, 79586) I wish you would write daily and give me a full report of progress from day to day.
('58', 42, 6, 13, 79670) Of course you will cheerfully resume your fast if it becomes necessary.
('58', 42, 6, 14, 79742) But we must strain every nerve to prevent its resumption.
('58', 42, 6, 15, 79800) Do not for one moment imagine that I promised to fast with you because of anything you had said in your telegrams.
('58', 42, 6, 16, 79915) I know that you would be better pleased if I did not join you.
('58', 42, 6, 17, 79978) But with me it was a point of honour that I should join you if the fast which was suspended upon my advice had to be resumed.
('58', 42, 6, 18, 80104) After all, you should have no difficulty in believing me when I tell you that at least during the days of the fast, all my acts were prompted by the inner voice.
('58', 42, 6, 19, 80266) All the movements of a life of perfect surrender to God are so directed, and it is my perpetual endeavour to make my life one of perfect surrender.
('58', 42, 6, 20, 80414) Therefore I would like you not to expend your energy in dissuading me from the fast if it becomes necessary, but devote every ounce of your energy to organizing public opinion so that the temple is opened to the Harijans before the due date.
('58', 42, 6, 21, 80656) I have read your letter to the Zamorin.
('58', 42, 6, 22, 80696) I think that it is quite all right.
('58', 42, 6, 23, 80732) It would have been better if you had omitted all reference to the Vaidiks and Tantriks.
('58', 42, 6, 24, 80820) Your position with regard to them was already known.
('58', 42, 6, 25, 80873) I had long conversations with Sadashiv Rao.
('58', 42, 6, 26, 80917) He told me all about you.
('58', 42, 6, 27, 80943) I have given him my views fully but in order to make assurance doubly sure I reduce them to writing.
('58', 43, 0, 1, 81044) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAATMA GANDHI 44
('58', 43, 1, 2, 81084) Our claim is that the proposed fast can never savour of coercion because it is based on the assumption that the vast majority of the tem ple going savarnas are in favour of temple entry.
('58', 43, 1, 3, 81271) If this cannot be proved up to the hilt, there is no case for fasting by us.
('58', 43, 1, 4, 81348) Fasting with the knowledge that savarnas are opposed to temple entry by Harijans would undoubtedly amount to coercion.
('58', 43, 1, 5, 81467) If we make that painful discovery, it would not mean that we cease to agitate for temple entry by avarnas, but the movement will then have to take a different turn.
('58', 43, 1, 6, 81632) I can even conceive the possibility of a fast in such an event, but that could only be in an unmistakably different setting.
('58', 43, 1, 7, 81757) In order to demonstrate to all concerned the fact that we have the majority of temple goers on our side, there should be a methodical taking of a referendum of temple goers, say within a ten mile radius.
('58', 43, 1, 8, 81961) And in order to have the thing absolutely above the board, signatures should be taken at public meetings in the presence of witnesses known to the signatories with their full names, addresses and occupations, together with age and sex.
('58', 43, 1, 9, 82197) It is being suggested that whilst many people have been in favour of Harijans entering temples, they may be afraid owing to pressure from their landlords or otherwise to say so openly.
('58', 43, 1, 10, 82382) I should say that even in that case we must be declared to have lost.
('58', 43, 1, 11, 82452) Whatever the cause of abstention may be, if we do not get the majority of votes we must be declared to have lost the battle so far as the proposed fast is concerned.
('58', 43, 1, 12, 82618) Needless to say that there should be no coercion of any kind on our part during the taking of the referendum.
('58', 43, 1, 13, 82728) On the contrary every endeavour should be made to carry on the referendum with the co operation and goodwill of the opponents.
('58', 43, 1, 14, 82855) The points of difference between the so called orthodox party and the reformers should be reduced to a minimum.
('58', 43, 1, 15, 82967) The orthodox party can have nothing to say against the reformers so long as they do not resort to any coercion.
('58', 43, 1, 16, 83079) If they are assured that there will be no attempt whatsoever made either on the part of the reformers or Harijans to force entry, there would be no opposition by the orthodox, and even if there is, it is bound to fall flat.
('58', 43, 1, 17, 83303) Real non violence can never beget violence.
('58', 43, 1, 18, 83347) Too much emphasis cannot be laid upon the point that the removal of untouchability, apart from the political side of it, which is settled, is a wholly religious matter.
('58', 43, 1, 19, 83516) Question was put to me whether sympathizers of temple entry may start fasting a few days before the second of January, in order, I suppose, to force the issue.
('58', 43, 1, 20, 83676) This must not be done on any account

('58', 45, 2, 3, 85778) November 23, 1932
('58', 45, 3, 4, 85796) NARANDAS, Read my letters to Kusum and Bhau 1 and then pass them on to them.
('58', 45, 3, 5, 85873) Kusum’s illness requires care.
('58', 45, 3, 6, 85904) There is no cause at all for fear.
('58', 45, 3, 7, 85939) She holds in her own hands the key to recovery.
('58', 45, 3, 8, 85987) If she lives all the time in open air and eats only what, and as much as, she can digest, she will certainly get all right.
('58', 45, 3, 9, 86111) The only cure for loose motions is a fast.
('58', 45, 3, 10, 86154) During the fast she should drink as much water as she can.
('58', 45, 3, 11, 86213) A little soda bicarb should be mixed in every glass of water she drinks.
('58', 45, 3, 12, 86286) It helps very much in stopping loose motions.
('58', 45, 3, 13, 86332) The proportion of one grain of soda for every ounce of water will be all right.
('58', 45, 3, 14, 86412) If she can digest fruit juices, a fast is not necessary.
('58', 45, 3, 15, 86469) I have discussed about eggs before.
('58', 45, 3, 16, 86505) Compared with fish liver oil, pure eggs are innocent.
('58', 45, 3, 17, 86559) Pure eggs are those from which no chickens come out, however long they are kept, and which are laid by the hen without a cock having been brought to her.
('58', 45, 3, 18, 86713) Such eggs are not boiled but opened as they are and the liquid consumed.
('58', 45, 3, 19, 86786) They help in stopping loose motions and are more nourishing than milk.
('58', 45, 3, 20, 86857) If Kusum is willing, she may drink the liquid of such eggs.
('58', 45, 3, 21, 86917) They are available even in Ahmedabad.
('58', 45, 3, 22, 86955) But I realize that no value should be attached to my advice.
('58', 45, 3, 23, 87016) Instead of doing what I advise from this distance, the proper course would be to follow the doctor’s advice and you should do that.
('58', 45, 3, 24, 87148) Show my suggestions to the doctor and then do as he advises.
('58', 45, 3, 25, 87209) About Bhau, I do not wish to make any suggestion other than what I have done in my letter to him.
('58', 45, 3, 26, 87307) If Kanti has not got all right, I would certainly say that his case requires careful watching.
('58', 45, 3, 27, 87402) That is, we should treat his disease to be a case of black fever.
('58', 45, 3, 28, 87468) That means that he should take complete rest, stop all food except fruit juices and, if he really feels hungry, milk in small quantities at a time.
('58', 45, 3, 29, 87616) If he does not pass stool, he should take an enema.

('58', 45, 3, 34, 87911) He is very eager to weave khadi of even texture from the yarn spun by Mahadev.

('58', 47, 1, 2, 89900) 62. LETTER TO HIRALAL A. SHAH
('58', 47, 2, 3, 89930) November 23, 1932 I was fully aware that the analogy of a dyer did not apply in all respects, but it was good enough for my purpose.
('58', 47, 2, 4, 90063) You think that the problem of untouchability has been solved in prisons.
('58', 47, 2, 5, 90136) But that is so only on paper.
('58', 47, 2, 6, 90166) Nothing of the kind that you suppose is being done.
('58', 47, 2, 7, 90218) I am speaking from personal observation.
('58', 47, 2, 8, 90259) Whether in jails or outside, the fact is that in most parts of India and for most of the year, the Bhangi’s dress is no more than loincloth.
('58', 47, 2, 9, 90400) I myself did a Bhangi’s duty continually for nearly one and a half years.
('58', 47, 2, 10, 90474) I used to do it dressed like an ordinary labourer.
('58', 47, 2, 11, 90525) In the Ashram it is done with the dhoti tucked in.
('58', 47, 2, 12, 90576) A person doing Bhangi’s work does not become as much soiled as a dyer.
('58', 47, 2, 13, 90647) If he does his work scientifically, he need not do anything more than clean himself with earth.
('58', 47, 2, 14, 90743) You probably know that according to Smritis and Islam, such cleaning is as good as a full bath.
('58', 47, 2, 15, 90839) But there are occupations in which this is not sufficient, nor is even washing with water.
('58', 47, 2, 16, 90930) Soap and antiseptic medicines are required for cleaning oneself properly.
('58', 47, 2, 17, 91004) Such occupations are those of the Chamar, the doctor, the dyer and the worker in a coal mine.
('58', 47, 2, 18, 91098) There are many others besides these.
('58', 47, 2, 19, 91135) Thus the cleanliness of Bhangis has very little part in the removal of untouchability.
('58', 47, 2, 20, 91222) Think over all this very carefully.
('58', 47, 2, 21, 91258) You should not lose your sense of perspective.
('58', 47, 2, 22, 91305) If you wish to discuss the matter further, come and see me.
('58', 47, 3, 23, 91365) I did not see anything objectionable in the note in the Chroni cle.
('58', 47, 3, 24, 91433) It is true that at present Bhangis work for all classes of people.
('58', 47, 3, 25, 91500) If, however, Hindus had given them a place in their fold, their condition would never have become as bad as it is.
('58', 47, 3, 26, 91615) The status of Bhangis in Europe or in any other part of the world is not inferior in any respect to that of other workers.
('58', 47, 3, 27, 91738) There are no special localities for their residence nor is there a special dress for them.
('58', 47, 3, 28, 91829) Nowhere outside India is there a special section of the community like our Bhangis.

('58', 49, 4, 9, 94137) November 24, 1932

('58', 49, 5, 11, 94228) So you are without Kisan.
('58', 49, 5, 12, 94254) You are having varied experiences.

('58', 49, 5, 16, 94418) You will return it to me and tell me whether you think it is well written.

('58', 49, 5, 22, 94744) Make any change you like so as to get thoroughly well.

('58', 49, 5, 24, 94835) yesterday.

('58', 49, 5, 26, 94884) I may not increase the quantity of dried milk now.
('58', 49, 5, 27, 94935) And the growing strain of work is not likely to add to the weight.
('58', 49, 5, 28, 95002) But 103 is a good weight for me.

('58', 50, 1, 2, 95475) 66. LETTER TO HOME SECRETARY, GOVERNMENT OF BOMBAY
('58', 50, 2, 3, 95526) November 24, 1932 SECRETARY TO GOVERNMENT OF BOMBAY HOME DEPARTMENT
('58', 50, 3, 4, 95594) DEAR SIR, I have waited almost to the breaking point before writing this letter.
('58', 50, 3, 5, 95675) Untouchability work is proving beyond my ability to cope with and this in spite of assistance I am getting from Sardar Vallabhbhai and Sjt.
('58', 50, 3, 6, 95815) Mahadev Desai.
('58', 50, 3, 7, 95830) The correspondence is daily growing in volume.
('58', 50, 3, 8, 95877) The number of visitors is increasing daily and more and more time has to be given to these visits as the movement progresses.
('58', 50, 3, 9, 96003) I am already in arrears with my correspondence and the statements I must make for the public.
('58', 50, 3, 10, 96097) My difficulty is enhanced by the fact that my elbows are giving more trouble than before and I am not able to use my hands for writing as much as I should, nor have I regained my pre fast vitality so as to enable me to put in more work than I am doing now.
('58', 50, 3, 11, 96354) As it is, we all begin work at 4 o’clock in the morning and it continues with necessary intervals up to 9 p.m.
('58', 50, 3, 12, 96465) The only way therefore out of the difficulty is for the Government to send one of my prisoner associates to stay with me.
('58', 50, 3, 13, 96587) The following are the names that just now occur to me: 1. Sjt.
('58', 50, 3, 14, 96650) Mohanlal Bhatt —Camp Jail, Yeravda 2. ,, Shanker Kalelkar—Central Jail, Yeravda 3. ,, Ramdas Gandhi do— 4. ,, Swami Anand —Camp Jail, Nasik Road 5. ,, Chhaganlal Joshi—(Jail not known) 6. ,, Jugatram Dave —Byculla, House of Correct ion These prisoners have been intimately connected with me and have worked under me, and they know English, Gujarati and Hindi, which is what I need.
('58', 50, 3, 15, 97032) If I had my choice, I would choose Swami Anand as being the most competent for the work.
('58', 50, 3, 16, 97121) He has been Secretary of the Anti Untouchability Committee established by the Congress in 1929 and since then has been devoting most of his time to untouchability work.
('58', 50, 3, 17, 97290) I need hardly say that I have confined my request to the least assistance I need immediately.
('58', 50, 3, 18, 97384) If this is a matter which can only be
('58', 51, 0, 1, 97422) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAATMA GANDHI 52
('58', 51, 1, 2, 97462) decided by the Government of India, may I ask that my request may be telegraphed to them?
('58', 51, 2, 3, 97552) Yours sincerely,

('58', 51, 8, 12, 98189) 68. LETTER TO M. M. ANANTA RAU 2
('58', 51, 9, 13, 98222) November 24, 1932
('58', 51, 10, 14, 98240) DEAR FRIEND, I see quite clearly that we look at the Gita from different stand points.
('58', 51, 10, 15, 98327) The main theme of the Gita to me is oneness of life.
('58', 51, 10, 16, 98380) Realiz ation thereof comes through work without attachment.
('58', 51, 10, 17, 98440) Untouchability as it is practised today seems to me to be utterly contrary to this divine fact of oneness.
('58', 51, 10, 18, 98547) Yours sincerely,
('58', 51, 11, 19, 98564) From a copy: C.W. 9560. Courtesy: Government of Mysore
('58', 51, 12, 20, 98619) 1 Vide “Letter to M.G. Bhandari”, 14 11 1932.
('58', 51, 13, 21, 98665) 2 Manager, Sanatana Dharma Karyalaya, Madras, who in his letter dated November 18, 1932 (C.W. 9559) had said that Gandhiji’s contention that the main theme of the Gita was “oneness and therefore equality of all life” was perhaps based on verse 18, Chapter V, but according to the ‘context and the subject’ that verse referred only to “yoga by renunciation of action”, and did not apply to the question of ‘touchability’ and ‘untouchability’ which were based purely upon action and the effects of action.
('58', 51, 13, 22, 99169) He had asked Gandhiji to enlighten him as to the authority for his advocacy for the removal of untouchability.

('58', 52, 4, 5, 99397) I had your precious letters.
('58', 52, 4, 6, 99426) 1 Your criticism soothes.
('58', 52, 4, 7, 99452) Your silence makes me nervous.

('58', 52, 4, 11, 99637) I do wish I never spoke of God or the Inner Voice or Conscience.

('58', 52, 4, 13, 99832) Truth will receive a deep cut if, for fear of being misunderstood or even being called a fraud, I did not say boldly what I felt to be true.
('58', 52, 4, 14, 99973) I carefully read the typed notes you sent me.
('58', 52, 4, 15, 100019) The reasoning failed to make any appeal to me.
('58', 52, 4, 16, 100066) The implications of the Agamas are stretched too far by the writer.

('58', 54, 2, 3, 102151) November 24, 1932
('58', 54, 3, 4, 102169) MY DEAR HOYLAND, Mahadev to whom this letter is being dictated tells me that you do not like to be called ‘Hoyland’ by near or real friends—I suppose there are degrees in friendship—but I refused to change the mode, telling him there was no ‘Jack’ about your signature!
('58', 54, 3, 5, 102439) But after all what is in a name?
('58', 54, 3, 6, 102472) It is the heart behind that matters and the heart is with you whether the pen traces Jack or John or Hoyland.
('58', 54, 3, 7, 102582) Your letter this time is a book compressed in a single notepaper sheet.
('58', 54, 3, 8, 102654) It tells me more about Russia than what I have read in my desultory reading and heard from travellers.
('58', 54, 3, 9, 102757) I must confess that this partiality for your letter is largely due to my faith in the accuracy of your observation and your truthfulness.
('58', 54, 3, 10, 102895) I want to warn you and other friends against being agitated over the proposed second fast.
('58', 54, 3, 11, 102986) Probably the ordeal won’t have to be gone through.
('58', 54, 3, 12, 103037) But it is the same thing whether it has to be gone through or not.
('58', 54, 3, 13, 103104) I am safe in God’s hands and the prayers of many friends in many lands are one of the many infallible proofs that I am under His absolute rule.
('58', 54, 3, 14, 103248) Love to you all.

('58', 55, 7, 22, 105155) We believe in temple worship, and such believers respectfully urge the trustees of all Hindu temples to throw open their doors to the Harijans on the same terms as to the caste Hindus.
('58', 55, 7, 23, 105340) We do not include in our request the garbhagriha which is only open to the professional ritualists, and as at present the attention of all India is directed to the Guruvayur Temple, we respectfully urge the Zamorin and all concerned to lead the way by opening that temple to the Harijans before the 1st of January next.

('58', 62, 4, 6, 115690) 89. REPLIES TO RATLAM CORRESPONDENTS 2
('58', 62, 5, 7, 115729) November 25, 1932 1. Great things have been misused from times immemorial, and will continue to be misused.
('58', 62, 5, 8, 115837) That is no reason for rejecting them.
('58', 62, 5, 9, 115875) There is nothing in this world in whose name as much evil is done as in the name of religion.
('58', 62, 5, 10, 115969) If, however, we were to banish religion for that reason, the world would perish.
('58', 62, 5, 11, 116050) 2. Shri Kelappan’s error was a very small one.
('58', 62, 5, 12, 116097) It could be recti fied and has been rectified.
('58', 62, 5, 13, 116144) If a fast in itself was an improper means, I could certainly not have supported him.
('58', 62, 5, 14, 116229) Since he has fully atoned for his error, as his co worker and as inventor of the weapon of fasting, it was clearly my moral duty to give my support to him.
('58', 62, 5, 15, 116385) 3. The Zamorin’s duty is to support neither me nor the orthodox Hindus who are fasting.
('58', 62, 5, 16, 116473) His clear duty is to uphold justice.
('58', 62, 5, 17, 116510) Two persons may fast against each other, but both may be in the wrong.
('58', 62, 5, 18, 116581) When that is so, the way of truth and non violence tells us that we should let both of them die, and do only what is just.
('58', 62, 5, 19, 116704) It isnot we who can save or kill people.
('58', 62, 5, 20, 116745) God does that.
('58', 62, 5, 21, 116760) People have survived long fasts, and, on the other hand, we see men and women, who have not been fasting, dying every moment through innumerable causes.
('58', 62, 5, 22, 116913) 4. I am quite aware that the personal element is bound to have an effect.
('58', 62, 5, 23, 116987) But should I, therefore, forsake dharma?
('58', 62, 5, 24, 117028) And if anybody gives up the practice of untouchability even under the spell of my personality, surely he would not be violating dharma.
('58', 62, 5, 25, 117164) 5. I pray to God, and also hope, that even if millions of people fasted against me to make me betray truth, I would make my heart as
('58', 62, 6, 26, 117297) 1 The addressee was a Bengali Assistant Accountant General who in his letter to Gandhiji had observed: “Your body is a trust and you have no right to go on fast again and again.” 2 The questions were contained in their joint letter.
('58', 63, 0, 1, 117530) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAATMA GANDHI 64
('58', 63, 1, 2, 117570) hard as a stone and not yield to them.
('58', 63, 1, 3, 117609) In considering all these factors, however, we should not lose sight of one thing, namely, that not many people will come forward to lay down their lives by fasting in order to keep injustice alive.
('58', 63, 1, 4, 117807) The truth is that very few people are likely to come forward to die even for justice.
('58', 63, 1, 5, 117893) 6. A crore of people may act in the name of their inner voice, but they may be impostors or fools.
('58', 63, 1, 6, 117992) How, then, should a man who is really urged by his inner voice act?
('58', 63, 1, 7, 118060) Should he suppress his inner voice and deny God for fear that others may follow his example and falsely claim to be inspired by their inner voice?
('58', 63, 1, 8, 118207) 7. If I believe that the orthodox Hindus have no popular support, why should I hide my view?
('58', 63, 1, 9, 118300) If, however, they do have such support, I cannot suppress that fact and it is easy for them to prove their claim.
('58', 63, 1, 10, 118414) 8. In the first place, my political, religious and social ideas are different branches of the same tree.
('58', 63, 1, 11, 118519) Hence they are not inconsistent with one another.
('58', 63, 1, 12, 118569) But those who see no connection among them should not forsake what they think to be dharma in order to make use of my political strength.
('58', 63, 1, 13, 118707) If anybody, however, through foolishness or cowardice, is ready to barter away the diamond of dharma for the pebble of political advantage, should I for that reason forsake my dharma?
('58', 63, 1, 14, 118891) It is doing violence to language to use the word ‘coercion’ in this connection.
('58', 63, 1, 15, 118971) There will always be such powers like personal influence and, if we regard them as forms of coercion, there would be no room for determined human effort to achieve anything.
('58', 63, 1, 16, 119145) 9. The question is improper.
('58', 63, 1, 17, 119174) 10. Mixed dinner parties with Harijans are not a necessary part of the movement for the eradication of untouchability.
('58', 63, 1, 18, 119293) 11. There is certainly some difference between Bharatbhushan 1
('58', 63, 2, 19, 119356) Panditji’s views and mine, but I don’t know if there is any diffe renceregarding this fast.
('58', 63, 2, 20, 119448) If there is any such difference, however, it is for the people to think what they should do.
('58', 63, 2, 21, 119541) They should follow the view which appeals to their reason and their heart.
('58', 63, 2, 22, 119616) 12. The fast is not intended to convert the orthodox Hindus.
('58', 63, 2, 23, 119677) My aim is to arouse those who have risen above custom and realized the sin of untouchability so that they may begin working and to make those who have no conviction in the matter start thinking.

('58', 65, 11, 17, 123016) A young man has sent me a farce by you entitled Brahmacharyashram and has criti cized it with a sad heart.
('58', 65, 11, 18, 123123) Sardar went through it first.
('58', 65, 11, 19, 123153) Mahadev glanced through it and read out to me some sentences.
('58', 65, 11, 20, 123215) If prizes wereto be awarded for appreciating innocent humour, I suppose I would win a small one even at the age of sixty four.
('58', 65, 11, 21, 123342) Co workers like you have also noticed my ability to understand humour.
('58', 65, 11, 22, 123413) In your farce, however, I see no pleasant humour but the most offensive jesting, almost bordering on obscenity such as uncultured men might slip into, during their idle gossiping.
('58', 65, 11, 23, 123593) One is entitled to expect you to produce, from jail, something really beautiful.
('58', 65, 11, 24, 123674) I will not enter into detailed discussion; but having stated my criticism, I make this plea, write to the publisher and withdraw the farce.
('58', 65, 11, 25, 123814) That young man informs me that some persons actually wish to stage the play, and the poor man is,

('58', 67, 7, 9, 125805) 95. INTERVIEW TO KHIMJI AND J. K. MEHTA 2
('58', 67, 8, 10, 125847) November 25, 1932
('58', 67, 9, 11, 125865) Mahatma Gandhi urged that there should be propaganda of a vigorous character for the removal of untouchability and specially for temple entry at present.
('58', 67, 9, 12, 126019) His attention was drawn to the fact that a referendum was going to be taken by women workers and others in Bombay for allowing untouchables to go to the temple of Guruvayur and he said that such a referendum was most welcome as it would show to the people all over India and the trustees of Guruvayur Temple, what were the feelings of the caste Hindus.
('58', 67, 9, 13, 126372) He added that Provincial Boards should identify themselves with the referendum work.
('58', 67, 10, 14, 126457) He stressed, of course, the importance of the referendum near Guruvayur itself
('58', 67, 11, 15, 126536) and he wanted it to be clearly understood that even if people all over the country were
('58', 67, 12, 16, 126624) in favour of the entry of the untouchables into the temple of Guruvayur and the actual
('58', 67, 13, 17, 126711) temple goers to the Guruvayur Temple opposed it, he would abide by the decision of
('58', 67, 14, 18, 126794) the Guruvayur people themselves, who should be considered the last authority on the question.
('58', 67, 14, 19, 126888) He suggested that Shastris of note might also be asked to give their
('58', 67, 15, 20, 126957) opinion regarding the authority of the Shastras on this question.
('58', 67, 16, 21, 127023) He again emphasized the importance of a census being taken of the depressed classes in the city, specially regarding the education of their children of different ages.
('58', 67, 17, 22, 127191) He also urged that adults of both the sexes among the untouchables had, through different sources, expressed a desire for education and night schools should be opened out for them.
('58', 67, 17, 23, 127372) He favoured scholarships being given to students of the depressed classes in high schools or colleges so as to give an encouragement to
('58', 67, 18, 24, 127508) 1 Gandhiji’s host during his visit to Takula, Nainital, in May 1931. 2 They met Gandhiji on behalf of the All India Anti Untouchability League.
('58', 68, 0, 1, 127652) VOL. 58 : 16 NOVEMBER, 1932 14 JANUARY, 1933 69
('58', 68, 1, 2, 127700) higher education among the depressed classes, who, after their education was over, might very well give one or two years’ service to the cause of social uplift of their brethren.
