('58', 68, 3, 4, 127912) 96. STATEMENT ON UNTOUCHABILITY IX
('58', 68, 4, 5, 127947) [November 26, 1932] 1
('58', 68, 5, 6, 127969) As January 1st is nearing, the correspondence on Guruvayur is increasing.
('58', 68, 5, 7, 128043) Instead of answering one by one the questions that arise from the correspondence, it would perhaps be simpler to answer them by way of a mere statement of my position.
('58', 68, 5, 8, 128211) The fast will begin on January 2 next if, before that date, the Guruvayur Temple is not opened to Harijans on the same terms as it is open to the caste Hindu sin general; but the fast will be postponed, if it becomes clear that the temple going Hindus in the neighbourhood are opposed to the temple entry of Harijans or if it is clear that although everybody is willing to open the temple to Harijans, there is a legal difficulty that cannot be overcome before Jannuary 2, next.
('58', 68, 5, 9, 128690) The majority of letters received by me assure me that the temple goers are in favour of admission of Harijan worshippers to the temple.
('58', 68, 5, 10, 128826) One or two correspondents vehemently contest the position and claim that a proper referendum will result in an overwhelming majority against such an entry.
('58', 68, 5, 11, 128982) These correspondents have given me no proof in support of their opinion, whereas others say that they have actually taken referendum after their own fashion and found it to be in favour of temple entry by Harijans.
('58', 68, 5, 12, 129197) If the orthodox people will agree, a fresh referendum can at once be taken in the presence of referees appointed by both the parties.
('58', 68, 5, 13, 129331) I need not repeat here the scheme suggested last Saturday in answer to a question from The Times of Indiacorrespondent.
('58', 68, 5, 14, 129451) Anyway,the reform party should lose no time in fortifying their contention with incontestable proof.
('58', 68, 5, 15, 129552) They, however, say that, although the opinion of the temple goers may be overwhelmingly in their favour, the key of the temple is held by the Zamorin.
('58', 68, 5, 16, 129703) That is no doubt technically true, but he is not the owner.
('58', 68, 5, 17, 129763) He is a trustee representing the temple going public.
('58', 68, 5, 18, 129817) Therefore, he cannot resist the clearly expressed wish of the majority
('58', 68, 6, 19, 129888) 1 Vide the following item.
('58', 69, 0, 1, 129915) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAATMA GANDHI 70
('58', 69, 1, 2, 129955) of them.
('58', 69, 1, 3, 129964) It is his duty to overcome the legal difficulties if there are any, and if he fails to do so, it simply means that the force of the public opinion has not become strong enough to compel the performance of his obvious duty.
('58', 69, 1, 4, 130187) The fast will then further solidify public opinion so as to make itself felt.
('58', 69, 1, 5, 130265) The key to the temple, therefore, is in fact in the hands of the public.
('58', 69, 1, 6, 130338) But as the legal maxim has it, law or equity helps the watchful, never the slothful.
('58', 69, 1, 7, 130423) Let Kerala reformers, therefore, not blame the Zamorin.
('58', 69, 1, 8, 130479) It is discourteous and wrong to impute motives to him.
('58', 69, 1, 9, 130534) If he refuses to open the temple to Harijans, let us think that he is not con vinced of the public demand.
('58', 69, 1, 10, 130641) His refusal must be a signal not for abu sing him, but discovering the weakness in our position.
('58', 69, 1, 11, 130738) It is surely more dignified and proper for the public to feel that it is a clearly ex pressed wish and cannot be flouted by its representative which the Zamorin is.
('58', 69, 1, 12, 130903) Guruvayur has already become an all India concern.
('58', 69, 1, 13, 130954) Let the caste Hindus all over India bestir themselves and declare their opinion that they desire Guruvayur Temple to be opened to Harijans.
('58', 69, 1, 14, 131094) The moral force of such an opinion honestly and freely expressed will be irresisti ble.
('58', 69, 1, 15, 131182) I have already warned the reformers against using unbecoming language in respect of orthodox sanatanists or no changers, as they have called themselves, in a petition addressed to H.E. the Viceroy.
('58', 69, 1, 16, 131380) They are entitled to their opinion.
('58', 69, 1, 17, 131416) I look upon this untouchability question as primarily religious, and I would like both the no changers and the reformers to work in a religious spirit without imputing motives to one another.
('58', 69, 1, 18, 131608) No reform, much less religious reform, can be or should be carried by compulsion.
('58', 69, 1, 19, 131690) I have repeatedly stated in un equivocal terms the limitations and functions of the proposed fast.
('58', 69, 1, 20, 131789) But a correspondent writing in Gujarati for himself and others says in effect: It is all very well for you to say that you do not want to coerce anybody, but your position cannot but compel some people to act against their will.
('58', 69, 1, 21, 132018) Some of us have no respect for your religious views or your social reforms, but we want you to live for your political power, and, therefore, if you persist in fasting, we will have to pocket our convictions and help you in your fight for temple entry.
('58', 69, 1, 22, 132271) If this is not coercion, we do not
('58', 70, 0, 1, 132306) VOL. 58 : 16 NOVEMBER, 1932 14 JANUARY, 1933 71
('58', 70, 1, 2, 132354) know the meaning of the word.
('58', 70, 1, 3, 132384) My answer is, I must not be expected to surrender my cherished convictions because I hold a prominent position in the Indian world, or because I have some political influence; I cannot barter away my faith or suppress its movement for the sake of retaining my social position or political influence.
('58', 70, 1, 4, 132684) Everything is subservient to and is derivable from that faith.
('58', 70, 1, 5, 132747) Ask me to deny or suppress it, and it would be worse than asking me to commit suicide.
('58', 70, 1, 6, 132834) I would also venture to suggest that those who subordinate their convictions to their regard for my position or political influence can only have shallow convic ions if any at all.
('58', 70, 1, 7, 133015) Convictions are made of sterner stuff.
('58', 70, 1, 8, 133054) People have been known to stake their all for the sake of their convictions which may then be called religion.
('58', 70, 1, 9, 133165) The correspondent asks: What is the poor Zamorin to do?
('58', 70, 1, 10, 133221) On the one hand you and Mr. Kelappan will fast.
('58', 70, 1, 11, 133269) On the other, 1,000 no changers are said to have decided to do likewise.
('58', 70, 1, 12, 133342) Whom is the Zamorin to please?
('58', 70, 1, 13, 133373) I answer without the slightest hesitation that he is to please neither party.
('58', 70, 1, 14, 133451) He is there to please God, which is Truth.
('58', 70, 1, 15, 133494) He is there to do his duty, and if it demands the sacrifice of thousands of no chan gers, Mr. Kelappan and myself, he should have the courage to do so and he will deserve the honour of his own generation and posterity.
('58', 70, 1, 16, 133713) God will take care of the fasting fraternity.
('58', 70, 1, 17, 133759) Those who fast will do so for defending the truth as they see it, and God of Truth will do what He likes with them.
('58', 70, 1, 18, 133875) If their fast is in answer to an inner urge, it will be its own reward, and it will be well with them whether the purpose to which it is directed is apparently fulfilled or not.
('58', 70, 1, 19, 134053) The same correspondent persists: But it is all very well for you to talk of the call of God, the conscience, the inner voice and all that.
('58', 70, 1, 20, 134192) Others also can and do put forth the same claim.
('58', 70, 1, 21, 134241) What are we, who have no inner voice and who have no God to parade before the public, to do and which are we to believe?
('58', 70, 1, 22, 134362) I can only say: You have to believe no one but yourselves.
('58', 70, 1, 23, 134421) You must try to listen to the inner voice, but if you won’t have the expression ‘inner voice’, you may use the expression ‘dictates of reason’ which you should obey, and if you will not parade God, I have no doubt you will parade something else which in the end will prove to be God for, fortunately, there is no one and nothing else but
('58', 71, 0, 1, 134759) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAATMA GANDHI 72
('58', 71, 1, 2, 134799) God in this universe.
('58', 71, 1, 3, 134821) I would also submit that it is not everyone claiming to act on the urge of the inner voice who has that urge.
('58', 71, 1, 4, 134931) After all like every other faculty this faculty for listening to the still, small voice within requires previous effort and training perhaps much grea ter than what is required for the acquisition of any other faculty, and even if out of thousands of claimants only a few succeed in estab lishing their claim, it is well worth running the risk of having and tole rating doubtful claimants.
('58', 71, 1, 5, 135321) So much for the Gujarati correspondent.
('58', 71, 1, 6, 135361) I must now conclude this statement with a question from a correspondent who writes in English.
('58', 71, 1, 7, 135456) His is a long letter containing elaborate argument but I think the following epitome correctly represents him: Hitherto I have known you to be free from any trace of communalism but you now suddenly appear in a communal garb.
('58', 71, 1, 8, 135682) I could have understood and justified your fast for swaraj or for all India unity, but I cannot understand this fast on behalf of Hinduism.
('58', 71, 1, 9, 135822) I have never taken you as a Hindu at all, certainly not as a narrow Hindu.
('58', 71, 1, 10, 135897) What is there in opening the temples to Harijans, who do not want to go there?
('58', 71, 1, 11, 135976) I am glad of this question.
('58', 71, 1, 12, 136004) I have no desire whatsoever to appear to anyone as other than what I am.
('58', 71, 1, 13, 136077) I am not ashamed of Hinduism or of the Hindu.
('58', 71, 1, 14, 136123) I totally deny being narrow.
('58', 71, 1, 15, 136152) I fancy I could not be held for one single moment by a narrow creed, and it is because the super imposition of untouchability would make Hinduism a narrow creed that I have rebelled against it, and I would count my life to be a cheap price to pay for the removal of that blot.
('58', 71, 1, 16, 136429) I have nothing of the communalist in me, because my Hinduism is all inclusive.
('58', 71, 1, 17, 136508) It is not anti Mussalman, anti Christian or anti any other religion.
('58', 71, 1, 18, 136577) But it is pro Mussalman, pro Christian and pro every other living faith in the world.
('58', 71, 1, 19, 136663) To me, Hinduism is but one branch from the same parent trunk, whose roots and whose quality we judge only by the collective strength and quality of the different branches put together, and if I take care of the Hindu branch on whichI am sitting and which sustains me surely I am taking care also of the sister branches.
('58', 71, 1, 20, 136983) If the Hindu branch is poisoned, the poison is likely to spread to others.
('58', 71, 1, 21, 137058) If that branch withers, the parent will be the weaker for its withering.
('58', 71, 1, 22, 137131) If my correspondent and those who think with him have followed me hitherto, they will discover that if God gives me the
('58', 72, 0, 1, 137251) VOL. 58 : 16 NOVEMBER, 1932 14 JANUARY, 1933 73
('58', 72, 1, 2, 137299) privilege of dying for this Hinduism of my conception, I shall have sufficiently died for the unity of all and even for swaraj.
('58', 72, 1, 3, 137427) Finally let me repeat what I have said before now, that the question whether Harijans want to, or would enter into temples, if they were open to them, is irrelevant.
('58', 72, 1, 4, 137593) The removal of untouchability is not a matter of bestowing patronage on Harijans.
('58', 72, 1, 5, 137675) It is one of penance and purification by the caste Hindus and one of the penances they have to do is to open the Hindu temples and invite the Harijans to them.
('58', 72, 1, 6, 137835) The Bombay Chronicle, 29 11 1932

('58', 75, 5, 10, 143059) 103. LETTER TO ANAND SWARUP
('58', 75, 6, 11, 143087) November 26, 1932
('58', 75, 7, 12, 143105) BHAI ANAND SWARUP, I have your letter.
('58', 75, 7, 13, 143144) All the questions are good, but I do not have sufficient time to answer them all.
('58', 75, 7, 14, 143226) I am not sure when I shall be able to reply through the newspapers, and so I think I may write at least this much.
('58', 75, 7, 15, 143341) Ramanama and Omkar are one and the same.
('58', 75, 7, 16, 143382) Tulsidas too has shown this most clearly.
('58', 75, 7, 17, 143424) He has extolled the name precisely because one lacks concentration while reciting prayers.
('58', 75, 7, 18, 143515) All the Shastras assure us and the experience of devotees shows that anyone can ultimately gain concentration of mind if one goes on praying with a feeling of reverence.
('58', 75, 7, 19, 143685) Closing eyes while chanting the prayer is enough but it is certainly good if the thoughts are centred on the point between the eyebrows.
('58', 75, 7, 20, 143822) The assertion that God himself is truth has a drawback that it implies some further qualities possessed by God.
('58', 75, 7, 21, 143934) That God has many names, a thousand, is quite true.
('58', 75, 7, 22, 143986) But remembering God as the posse ssor of many names is fraught with the possibility of a diminution in the significance of the entity to which we wish to offer total surrender.
('58', 75, 7, 23, 144163) But all other attributes fade away when we proclaim that Truth alone is God; only the idea of truth remains in mind and this is more prevalent in monism.
('58', 75, 7, 24, 144317) Atheism has no place here as even an atheist accepts existence which is a development of sat.
('58', 75, 7, 25, 144411) Here truth does not imply merely truthfulness of speech; its meaning here is unity of thought, word and deed and yet more.
('58', 75, 7, 26, 144534) Whatever is in reality here, what existed
('58', 76, 0, 1, 144576) VOL. 58 : 16 NOVEMBER, 1932 14 JANUARY, 1933 77
('58', 76, 1, 2, 144624) in the past and will remain in the future is the substance, truth, Parameshwar 1 and nothing but that.
('58', 76, 1, 3, 144727) Now for the scavenging and hygiene of commodes.
('58', 76, 1, 4, 144775) A commode should be placed in a room which constantly receives sunlight.
('58', 76, 1, 5, 144848) It should be constructed in such a way as to be removed daily and cleaned.
('58', 76, 1, 6, 144923) Two buckets should be placed on a wooden frame, one for urine and one for stools.
('58', 76, 1, 7, 145005) After evacuation of the bowels the excrement should be covered with sand or mud.
('58', 76, 1, 8, 145086) A bucket full of earth should be kept in the room.
('58', 76, 1, 9, 145137) If the house is near a field or a garden the excreta should be regularly buried there for being converted into manure.
('58', 76, 1, 10, 145256) Except during the rainy season, the roof should be re movable during the rest of the year so that the room receives sunshine throughout the day.
('58', 76, 1, 11, 145401) With this arrangement and daily washing out of the buckets and the room, the lavatory will be and should be as clean as a bed room.
('58', 76, 1, 12, 145533) This arrangement is very convenient in the villages and it should not prove difficult in towns like Meerut.
('58', 76, 2, 13, 145641) MOHANDAS GANDHI [PS.] It is not essential to place the buckets in a wooden frame.
('58', 76, 2, 14, 145723) They can be placed on a frame made of stone or bricks.

('58', 76, 4, 16, 145830) 104. INTERVIEW TO “THE TIMES OF INDIA”
('58', 76, 5, 17, 145869) November 26, 1932
('58', 76, 6, 18, 145887) Certain people who visited Mr. Gandhi this week left Yeravda Jail under the
('58', 76, 7, 19, 145963) impression that Mr. Gandhi had assured them that once the Guruvayur temple entry
('58', 76, 8, 20, 146044) matter had been settled, he would extend his fast in order to compel the temple
('58', 76, 9, 21, 146124) trustees throughout India to open all temples to the untouchables.
('58', 76, 9, 22, 146191) They have told
('58', 76, 10, 23, 146206) their friends about this and the news has spread quickly.
('58', 76, 10, 24, 146264) This morning I sought Mr.
('58', 76, 11, 25, 146290) Gandhi’s confirmation or denial of this as I felt that a mistake had occurred
('58', 76, 12, 26, 146368) somewhere.
('58', 76, 12, 27, 146379) He immediately denied its accuracy.
('58', 76, 12, 28, 146415) Mr. Gandhi said: Such a course on my part would disturb public opinion and would be a breach of faith.
('58', 76, 12, 29, 146518) Once the fast is over and the temple is open, many other temples are highly likely to be opened to the untou chables because by the time Guruvayur is opened, so much propa 
('58', 77, 0, 1, 146691) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAATMA GANDHI 78
('58', 77, 1, 2, 146731) ganda work will have been done and public opinion will have been so much affected that it is not likely that there will be much hesitation on the part of other trustees to open the temples under their charge.
('58', 77, 1, 3, 146940) Should it prove otherwise, I should not think of restarting the fast without the greatest deliberation and without an absolutely just cause.
('58', 77, 1, 4, 147081) So far as I can say now no such fast for a particular item in the anti untouchability programme is contemplated.
('58', 77, 2, 5, 147194) In reply to my query as to whether he had any detailed information as to the actual situation in the neighbourhood of the Guruvayur Temple, Mr. Gandhi said that so far as information is available the caste Hindus in the neighbourhood, who were in the habit of visiting the temple, were overwhelmingly in favour of Harijans beingadmitted on precisely the same terms as they themselves were admitted.
('58', 77, 2, 6, 147593) But I also have letters from people in the neighbourhood casting aspersions on the accuracy of my information.
('58', 77, 2, 7, 147704) I have, therefore, suggested that a quick public referendum of the caste Hindu people within a radius of say ten miles from the temple be taken in the pre sence of referees, one to be appointed to act on behalf of the reformers and one on behalf of the sanatanists.
('58', 77, 2, 8, 147970) If it is thought nece ssary there may also be an umpire.
('58', 77, 2, 9, 148027) These gentlemen should supervise the taking of votes so as to avoid any chance of undue pressure being exercised, impersonation or any other malpractice.
('58', 77, 2, 10, 148181) If, however, as a result of this quick referendum it is found that the information at my disposal was wrong I will unhesitatingly advise Mr. Kelappan to postpone his fast until public opinion is sufficiently educated to warrant the opening of the temple to the Harijans.
('58', 77, 3, 11, 148452) Meanwhile he has asked 1 Urmila Devi, sister of the late Mr. C. R. Das to go south and assist in the campaign there.
('58', 77, 3, 12, 148569) The Times of India, 28 11 1932

('58', 88, 4, 13, 165006) 124. LETTER TO E. E. DOYLE
('58', 88, 5, 14, 165033) November 28, 1932
('58', 88, 6, 15, 165051) DEAR COL.
('58', 88, 6, 16, 165061) DOYLE, I have today astounding news that a co worker of mine, Sjt.
('58', 88, 6, 17, 165128) Appasaheb Patwardhan, a civil disobedience prisoner in Ratnagiri Jail, is semi fasting because he and some other prisoners who were permitted to do Bhangi work have been suddenly deprived of it under your orders.
('58', 88, 6, 18, 165341) My fear is that this order was a result of my having said in the course of our conversations that your policy was inconsistent in that you were allowing non Bhangi prisoners to do Bhangi work in the Ratnagiri Prison and you would not allow it in this.
('58', 88, 6, 19, 165593) It is difficult for me to understand why those prisoners who volunteer to do such work should be prevented from doing it.
('58', 88, 6, 20, 165715) Surely you do not want forcibly to keep up untouchability in prisons when it is crumbling to pieces outside.
('58', 88, 6, 21, 165824) Appasaheb is an M.A. of the Bombay University, is a great social reformer and a man of character whom any State would be proud to have as a citizen.
('58', 88, 6, 22, 165973) Service of untouchables is an article of faith with him.
('58', 88, 6, 23, 166030) He underwent a fast in 1930 for the above reason in that very jail.

('58', 94, 1, 2, 175210) 134. LETTER TO E. E. DOYLE
('58', 94, 2, 3, 175237) November 30, 1932
('58', 94, 3, 4, 175255) DEAR COL.
('58', 94, 3, 5, 175265) DOYLE, I thank you for your prompt reply to my letter 1 regarding Appasaheb Patwardhan, but I am sorry for the attitude you have taken up.
('58', 94, 3, 6, 175404) Since the matter has gone up to the Government, I would like to draw their attention to the following facts: 1. Appasaheb Patwardhan is wedded to the idea that he should work side by side with Bhangis and it is most repugnant to him to have to observe in prisons untouchability which he does not do outside.
('58', 94, 3, 7, 175712) 2. He had to fast in 1930 for this very reason.
('58', 94, 3, 8, 175760) 3. I must adhere to my statement that Appasaheb Patwardhan had been actually doing Bhangi work in the Ratnagiri Jail, until he was stopped.
('58', 94, 3, 9, 175900) 4. There was no question of his issuing any threat and, in my humble opinion, statement of his moral claim and consequence of rejection of that claim should not be considered as a threat.
('58', 94, 3, 10, 176088) 5. In considering a moral or religious question, the question of shortage of labour does not arise.
('58', 94, 3, 11, 176188) 6. In my opinion it is unjust to say of an absolutely docile priso ner like Appasaheb Patwardhan who has been always prepared to do any task asked of him that he is fighting for“a particular variety of work”.
('58', 94, 3, 12, 176397) He wants to do Bhangi work in addition to whatever task may be given to him.
('58', 94, 3, 13, 176474) 7. There are many prisoners in Yeravda, including us three, who are anxious to do their own conservancy work, and it is because you have not looked upon it with favour that I have myself remained silent and with difficulty prevented my co workers from making it an issue of conscience.
('58', 94, 3, 14, 176760) 8. As you are yourself aware of the conversation about this matter and about hand spinning by civil disobedience prisoners has remained in abeyance because of the more important matters arising, and absorbing my time and attention.
('58', 94, 3, 15, 176992) But these two are matters of deepest importance to many of us.
('58', 94, 3, 16, 177055) 9. With due deference I cannot help repeating that to prevent
('58', 94, 4, 17, 177117) 1 Vide “Letter to E.E. Doyle”, 28 11 1932.
('58', 95, 0, 1, 177160) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAATMA GANDHI 96
('58', 95, 1, 2, 177200) Appasaheb Patwardhan from voluntarily working side by side with his Bhangi co prisoners because he does not belong to the Bhangi caste is a perpetuation in prisons of the bar of untouchability when that bar is being swiftly removed outside prison walls.
('58', 95, 1, 3, 177454) I would therefore implore you personally to revise the uncom promising attitude you have taken up and to let humble Appasaheb Patwardhan and his associates do conservancy work.
('58', 95, 1, 4, 177631) Believe me that there is no defiance in their request.
('58', 95, 1, 5, 177686) Some of us who are convinced civil resisters leave our resistance outside prison walls and having entered them are anxious to carry out and promote prison discipline to the utmost extent that our conscience would allow and we do so in order to show that our resistance is always civil and never incivil or criminal.
('58', 95, 1, 6, 178002) But if I cannot make you or Government appreciate this obvious and just position, I have with the utmost regret to inform you that from Saturday the 3rd proximo, so far as I am concerned, I must join Appasaheb in his protest and respectfully claim to do my own conservancy work, and if he does not get the relief, I must put myself not on reduced rations but on a complete fast.
('58', 95, 1, 7, 178381) I would ask you not to treat this as a threat, but as a human being to appreciate the feelings of a fellow being.
('58', 95, 1, 8, 178495) I have already hardened my heart, but I have not hard ened it so as to see an honourable colleague wasting away in defence of a cherished principle without my at least sharing his agony and sac rifice.
('58', 95, 1, 9, 178697) Believe me it is no pleasure to me to have to write such letters.
('58', 95, 2, 10, 178763) Yours sincerely,
('58', 95, 3, 11, 178780) Home Department, Political, File No.

('58', 95, 4, 13, 178883) 135. LETTER TO F. MARY BARR
('58', 95, 5, 14, 178911) November 30, 1932
('58', 95, 6, 15, 178929) MY DEAR MARY, You have asked for only a postcard, but that won’t be adequate for me.
('58', 95, 6, 16, 179014) Because I do not find a particular thing helpful for me, I may not be indifferent about others and not take the trouble of knowing whether it is helpful for them.
('58', 95, 6, 17, 179177) I know that that particular form of idolatry is helpful for millions, not because they are lessdeveloped than I am, but because they are differently constituted.
('58', 95, 6, 18, 179339) What must not be forgotten about me is that not only do I not consider idol worship
('58', 96, 0, 1, 179423) VOL. 58 : 16 NOVEMBER, 1932 14 JANUARY, 1933 97
('58', 96, 1, 2, 179471) to be a sin, but I know that in some form or other it is a condition of our being.
('58', 96, 1, 3, 179554) The difference between one form of worship and another is a difference in degree and not in kind.
('58', 96, 1, 4, 179652) Mosque going or chruch going is a form of idol worship.
('58', 96, 1, 5, 179708) Veneration of the Bible, the Koran, the Gita and the like is idol worship and even if you don’t use a book or a building but draw a picture of divinity in your imagi nation and attribute certain qualities, it is again idol worship and I refuse to call the worship of the one who has a stone image a grosser form of worship.
('58', 96, 1, 6, 180032) Learned judges have been known to have such images in their own homes.
('58', 96, 1, 7, 180103) A philosopher like Pandit Malaviya will not eat his meal without offering worship to the household deity.
('58', 96, 1, 8, 180209) It would be both arrogant and ignorant to look down upon such worship as superstition.
('58', 96, 1, 9, 180296) Again in the imagination of the worshipper, God is in a consecrated stone and not in the other stones lying about him.
('58', 96, 1, 10, 180415) Even so, the sanctuary in a Church is more sacred than any other place in it.
('58', 96, 1, 11, 180493) You can multiply for yourself instances of this character.
('58', 96, 1, 12, 180552) All this is a plea not for laxity in thought or worship, but it is a plea for a definite recognition of the fact that all forms of honest worship are equally good and equally efficient for the respective worshippers.
('58', 96, 1, 13, 180769) Time is gone for the exclusive possession of right by an individual or a group.
('58', 96, 1, 14, 180849) God is no respector of forms or words, for He is able to penetrate our actions and our speech and read and understand our thoughts, even when we do not understand them ourselves and it is first our thoughts that matter to him.
('58', 96, 1, 15, 181076) I am glad you are with Maria and your picture of her family which includes our four footed kinsfolk is instructive and it is just like her.
('58', 96, 1, 16, 181216) I do not mind her not writing to me.
('58', 96, 1, 17, 181253) Whilst I welcome her letters when she has anything to say to me, I do not want her to steal a single minute merely for writing to me because somebody else is writing.
('58', 96, 1, 18, 181420) I am glad you have fourteen months’ grace.
('58', 96, 1, 19, 181463) I like your progra mme.
('58', 96, 1, 20, 181487) So far as I recall you have not been to Santiniketan.
('58', 96, 1, 21, 181541) You ought to go there at least.
('58', 96, 1, 22, 181573) I do not want to harness you for untouchability work before you have gone through your touring.
('58', 96, 1, 23, 181669) Untouchability work is a long programme and you can be fitted in whenever you are quite ready and you have a definite call from within.
('58', 96, 1, 24, 181805) I would like you also quietly to study this movement in all its ramifications and assimi late the spirit lying behind it, and if you give yourself to it I want you to do it with your whole heart without any mental reservation.
('58', 96, 1, 25, 182032) I want you therefore not to hesitate to place all your doubts before me and offer yourself for the service when both your head and heart are
('58', 97, 0, 1, 182173) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAATMA GANDHI 98
('58', 97, 1, 2, 182213) completely satisfied.
('58', 97, 1, 3, 182235) Of course in connection with the untouchability work you can see me any time you like.
('58', 97, 1, 4, 182322) Please share this with Maria.
('58', 97, 1, 5, 182352) My love to both of you in which Mahadev joins.
('58', 97, 3, 6, 182399) BAPU [PS.] I have not revised this.

('58', 100, 4, 6, 186144) Call both of them and ask them everything, and then literally follow the advice of the doctor whom you have consulted.
('58', 100, 4, 7, 186263) Both you and I can then stop worrying.
('58', 100, 4, 8, 186302) We are not masters of life or death, nor are doctors, but we can try.
('58', 100, 4, 9, 186372) We may try as our reason guides us and then be unconcerned.
('58', 100, 4, 10, 186432) It is nothing but God’s kindness that .
('58', 100, 4, 11, 186472) 1 left.
('58', 100, 4, 12, 186480) You had actually sanctioned him leave, and it was pure chance that youdetained him afterwards for some days.
('58', 100, 4, 13, 186589) It was as though God had willed that he should be tested.
('58', 100, 4, 14, 186647) Such things have often happened in the history of the Ashram.
('58', 100, 4, 15, 186709) Evil got exposed of itself.
('58', 100, 4, 16, 186737) I indeed wish to write at great length about food, but I don’t think I shall be able to do that.
('58', 100, 4, 17, 186834) I shall have to be brief.
('58', 100, 4, 18, 186860) It is not right to serve rotlas of bajri every day.
('58', 100, 4, 19, 186912) If rotlas of bajri and jowar and rotlis of wheat are served by turn, the inmates would get the benefit of all the three cereals.
('58', 100, 4, 20, 187041) Every time the grain taken out for consumption should be weighed and the rotlas also should be of uniform weight.
('58', 100, 4, 21, 187155) What the weight of each rotla should be, you will be able to decide only through experience.
('58', 100, 4, 22, 187248) If you follow this practice, everyone will be able to know how much he should eat.
('58', 100, 4, 23, 187331) Here the smallest rotla weighs six ounces.
('58', 100, 4, 24, 187374) If people wish to derive the full benefit from the morning gruel, they should eat nothing else with it.
('58', 100, 4, 25, 187478) The quantity of flour in the gruel should be measured.
('58', 100, 4, 26, 187533) If the quantity of water also is measured, it will be easy to know how much flour each helping contained.
('58', 100, 4, 27, 187639) If a person is not satisfied with one helping, he may by all means have another, but nobody should exceed the limit that he has fixed for himself.
('58', 100, 4, 28, 187786) He may eat less sometimes if he has not enough appetite.
('58', 100, 4, 29, 187843) But he should not exceed the fixed limit even if he feels more hungry than usual.
('58', 100, 4, 30, 187925) This will do him no harm.
('58', 100, 4, 31, 187951) If the grain is properly cleaned before being ground, the flour
('58', 100, 5, 32, 188015) 1 The name has been omitted.
('58', 101, 0, 1, 188044) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAATMA GANDHI 102
('58', 101, 1, 2, 188085) of every cereal should be used without sifting.
('58', 101, 1, 3, 188133) I approve of Dr. Talwalkar’s suggestion for increasing the quantity of milk and ghee, but not at all of his suggestion for including chutney.
('58', 101, 1, 4, 188275) Even those who eat chutney suffer from constipation.
('58', 101, 1, 5, 188328) If you wish, you may make this experiment.
('58', 101, 1, 6, 188371) You may prepare chutney for those who suffer from rather severe constipation.
('58', 101, 1, 7, 188449) Let them try it.
('58', 101, 1, 8, 188466) If the effect on them is undoubtedly beneficial, you may try it, if you wish, for others.
('58', 101, 1, 9, 188556) In preparing the chutney, you should use black pepper instead of chillies.
('58', 101, 1, 10, 188631) Read the letter which I shall write to Dr. Talwalkar about this.
('58', 101, 1, 11, 188696) My own experience of chutney is not encouraging.
('58', 101, 1, 12, 188745) Before I went to England, I may say that I used to eat pepper and chillies in fairly good quantities.
('58', 101, 1, 13, 188847) At that time good food was my chief interest in life.
('58', 101, 1, 14, 188901) In England, we get extract of chillies.
('58', 101, 1, 15, 188941) I must have eaten it for about a month.
('58', 101, 1, 16, 188981) I had to suffer for that.
('58', 101, 1, 17, 189007) Afterwards, that is, in about a month or so, the pattern of my life changed and I left off eating spices, never to eat them again.
('58', 101, 1, 18, 189138) Since then I have experimented on hundreds of persons, but I do not remember any case in which spices were used as a medicine with beneficial effect.
('58', 101, 1, 19, 189288) Personally I am convinced that constpation is a sign of indigestion.
('58', 101, 1, 20, 189357) Food which is digested does not cause constipation.
('58', 101, 1, 21, 189409) All food leaves some residue and, if it is properly digested, the bowels throw them out.
('58', 101, 1, 22, 189498) However, I don’t press you to follow my advice.
('58', 101, 1, 23, 189546) It is well known that spices are inimical to physical celibacy.
('58', 101, 1, 24, 189610) For that reason, too, we should think a hundred times before including spices in our food.
('58', 101, 1, 25, 189701) We may certainly serve any spices purely as medicine for a limited period.
('58', 101, 1, 26, 189776) It is possible that, so long as they act as medicine, they may not endanger celibacy.
('58', 101, 1, 27, 189862) For instance, if a person feels extremely cold, pure brandy will make him warm but will not intoxicate him, for the power of the brandy will have been used up in overcoming the cold.
('58', 101, 1, 28, 190045) I think I have dwelt long enough on chutney.
('58', 101, 1, 29, 190090) Dr.Talwalkar’s suggestion about including ground nut should not be acted upon in any circumstances.
('58', 101, 1, 30, 190190) I have experimented with ground nut more than anybody else is likely to have done.
('58', 101, 1, 31, 190273) It has been tried for a long time even in the Ashram.
('58', 101, 1, 32, 190327) On the whole the result was discouraging.
('58', 101, 1, 33, 190369) In the current experiment, you seem to have excluded dal altogether.
('58', 101, 1, 34, 190438) It is all right if the effect has been good.
('58', 101, 1, 35, 190483) For checking the effect, you should get everybody weighed, and should know from each person how he or she feels.
('58', 101, 1, 36, 190596) It is for you to judge

('58', 109, 8, 14, 202133) 153. LETTER TO E. E. DOYLE
('58', 109, 9, 15, 202160) December 3, 1932
('58', 109, 10, 16, 202177) DEAR COL.
('58', 109, 10, 17, 202187) DOYLE, At about 7.15 this morning Major Mehta handed me the following message:
('58', 109, 11, 18, 202266) Mr. Gandhi may be allowed to do his own conservancy work if he
('58', 109, 12, 19, 202329) wants to.
('58', 109, 12, 20, 202339) But he should be informed that Government cannot accept his
('58', 109, 13, 21, 202399) intervention on behalf of convict Appasaheb Patwardhan.
('58', 109, 13, 22, 202455) It seems to me that Government have not appreciated the posi tion.
('58', 109, 13, 23, 202522) The permission to me to do my own conservancy work is of little moment.
('58', 109, 13, 24, 202594) Relief for Appasaheb Patwardhan is the chief and central thing.
('58', 109, 13, 25, 202658) My fast began this morning as per my letter 3 to you and, I am sorry to say, has to continue till relief is granted to Appasaheb Patwardhan and his associates.
('58', 109, 13, 26, 202818) It should be understood that they have
('58', 109, 14, 27, 202857) 1 The addressee had sought Gandhiji’s blessings in a telegram informing him that anti untouchability campaign had been started in Guruvayur at a conference opened by Kasturba.
('58', 109, 14, 28, 203033) 2 From “Diary, 1932”, entry under this date 3 Vide “Letter to E.E. Doyle”, 30 11 1932.
('58', 110, 0, 1, 203120) VOL. 58 : 16 NOVEMBER, 1932 14 JANUARY, 1933 111
('58', 110, 1, 2, 203169) asked not for doing their own conservancy work, but for joining the regular file and this they have done as a matter of sacred principle.
('58', 110, 1, 3, 203307) Government should also know that it is not Bhangis alone who are given this work but others described as low castes are compelled to render this service although they have never done it outside prisons.
('58', 110, 1, 4, 203510) Reformers like Appasaheb Patwardhan who were civil disobedience prisoners in 1930 in Ratnagiri could not suffer the misery of non Bhangi prisoners being forced against their will to do the work and submitted to the authorities that they should be allowed to replace such men.
('58', 110, 1, 5, 203786) This was, in my opinion, a laudable offer which the autho rities should have gladly, if not thankfully, accepted.
('58', 110, 1, 6, 203900) It was a volun tary offer made to help the Government.
('58', 110, 1, 7, 203955) Meanwhile the Delhi Pact 1
('58', 110, 2, 8, 203982) The same offer was renewed this time and these prisoners were permitted to do the work.
('58', 110, 2, 9, 204070) Suddenly orders seem to have been sent to prohibit the work.
('58', 110, 2, 10, 204131) Hence Appasaheb Patwardhan’s putting himself on reduced diet.
('58', 110, 2, 11, 204193) I ventured to seek relief as soon as I came to know of this tragedy.
('58', 110, 2, 12, 204262) In rejecting my humble and helpful intervention, Government seem to have suddenly reversed the policy which they adopted as early as 1922 23 in connection with me and have continued ever since.
('58', 110, 2, 13, 204456) When during my first incarceration in 1922—and that as a convict—I sought to intervene on behalf of two hunger striking priso ners, it was at first resented and then on reconsideration the Govern ment accepted it.
('58', 110, 2, 14, 204670) 2 The then Inspector General of Police who was deputed by His Excellency, Sir George Lloyd, to carry on negotia tions with me and the Superintendent of this Prison thanked me for the happy result of the intervention.
('58', 110, 2, 15, 204887) Two precious lives were saved and a beneficial circular was issued by the Government as a result of my humble effort.
('58', 110, 2, 16, 205005) In 1930 under similar circumstances the new Superintendent, who knew little or nothing of the event just described of 1922 23 disliked my offer, but subsequently it was accepted by you yourself again with happy result and the practice was then estab lished of my being allowed to see fellow prisoners for the definite purpose of my being able to render the humble office of intermediary between them and the administration.
('58', 110, 2, 17, 205429) That practice has been con tinued up to now, not I hope with any unhappy result.
('58', 110, 2, 18, 205510) Each time I have intervened, I hope the officials concerned will testify, I have done
('58', 110, 3, 19, 205596) 1 Gandhi Irwin Agreement of 1931. 2 Vide “Letter to Jail Superintendent, Yeravda”, 9 7 1923.
('58', 111, 0, 1, 205689) 112 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('58', 111, 1, 2, 205731) so in a helpful manner.
('58', 111, 1, 3, 205755) It is, therefore, difficult for me to understand the Government without any apparent cause reversing this policy, and that too just when I have been obliged most reluctantly to embark upon a fast.
('58', 111, 1, 4, 205952) I must regretfully adhere to the fast until relief is given to my friends and the human right of intervention that the Government have hitherto recognized is restored to me.
('58', 111, 1, 5, 206126) There is one thing I should mention.
('58', 111, 1, 6, 206163) I am carrying on concen trated conversations about untouchability from day to day with many friends who come to see me.
('58', 111, 1, 7, 206283) Just at present the strain is greater than usual because of the members of the Anti Untouchability League being in Poona.
('58', 111, 1, 8, 206405) The visitors are bound to notice the weakness that must overtake me even today and they are bound to inquire about the reason.
('58', 111, 1, 9, 206532) I shall be unable to conceal the truth from them and yet I have no desire whatsoever that they should know anything about the unfor tunate contretemps between Government and myself.
('58', 111, 1, 10, 206714) For I am hoping that the Government will recognize the utter reasonableness of my request.
('58', 111, 2, 11, 206805) Yours sincerely,
('58', 111, 3, 12, 206822) Home Department, Political, File No.

('58', 111, 4, 16, 206942) 154. LETTER TO G. N. KANITKAR 1
('58', 111, 5, 17, 206974) December 3, 1932 You say Harijans should be allowed to enter temples, because all have broken the Shastras.
('58', 111, 5, 18, 207082) This is an immoral attitude.
('58', 111, 5, 19, 207111) If in 99 cases we have broken the Shastras that is no reason for breaking them in the 100th case.
('58', 111, 5, 20, 207209) That is no reform but deform.
('58', 111, 5, 21, 207239) My point is that not to allow Harijans to enter temples is wrong and against religion.
('58', 111, 5, 22, 207326) This is a religious movement for elevation of religion.
('58', 111, 6, 23, 207382) Mahadevbhaini Diary, Vol. II, p.
('58', 111, 7, 24, 207415) 1 The letter was in reply to the addressee’s which read: “The Shastris have very often violated the Shastras.
('58', 111, 7, 25, 207525) Why should they then stick to their word in this case?”

('58', 112, 1, 2, 207630) 155. LETTER TO MANIBEHN PATEL 1
('58', 112, 2, 3, 207662) December 3, 1932 Whatever one has learnt about dharma is tested only at a time like this.
('58', 112, 2, 4, 207752) If what we have read and thought does not help us in any way, we should take it that we have learnt nothing.
('58', 112, 2, 5, 207861) If a doctor or a lawyer is well read in his subject and discourses learnedly on it but cannot handle even one case, he is a doctor or a lawyer only in name.
('58', 112, 2, 6, 208018) Similarly, a man may be a great authority on religion but if his know ledge of dharma is confined to what he has read in books or remains only in his mind, he is a dharma pundit only in name.
('58', 112, 3, 7, 208210) [From Gujarati]
('58', 112, 4, 8, 208226) Mahadevbhaini Diary, Vol. II, p.

('58', 113, 8, 14, 209427) 158. INTERVIEW TO FREE FRESS
('58', 113, 9, 15, 209456) [December 3, 1932] 1
('58', 113, 10, 16, 209477) I have never said that I will not concentrate all my energy on that service [emancipation of the Harijans], but I cannot previously bind myself not to do anything else.
('58', 113, 10, 17, 209646) Circumstances may compel me to do things, which it would be sinful on my part not to do.
('58', 113, 11, 18, 209735) Replying to a question as to why he should not carry on the Anti Untoucha bility propaganda from outside as he is doing it from the prison now, he said: I am doing nothing but concentrating the whole of my energy on the Harijans now.
('58', 113, 12, 19, 209969) Q. As you attach a great importance to fast, would you advise others to carry on
('58', 113, 13, 20, 210050) the campaign by the same methods?
('58', 113, 14, 21, 210084) A. Fasting is a very special method and nobody can fast unless there is a definite special call for him to do so.
('58', 113, 14, 22, 210198) Therefore there should be no fast in imitation, and I would be so presumtuous as to say that if anybody wants to fast in connection with untouchability out of sym pathy he or she should refer to me and obtain my consent before so doing.
('58', 113, 14, 23, 210435) But I can say that on that single issue of Guruvayur, none but Kelappan and I should fast.
('58', 113, 14, 24, 210526) But everybody can and should carry on
('58', 113, 15, 25, 210564) 1 From “Diary, 1932”, entry under this date
('58', 114, 0, 1, 210608) VOL. 58 : 16 NOVEMBER, 1932 14 JANUARY, 1933 115
('58', 114, 1, 2, 210657) the campaign in hundreds of other ways which are open to all because the methods of service are so many and varied.
('58', 114, 2, 3, 210773) Q. Having dedicated yourself to the Harijans, does not your life belong to them now?
('58', 114, 3, 4, 210858) A. To say that my life belongs to Harijans is only half truth.
('58', 114, 3, 5, 210921) The whole truth is that my life belongs to God and therefore it belongs to the Harijans and, for that matter, the whole of creation, and it is God who can keep me, or can take me away.
('58', 114, 4, 6, 211106) Questioned if, when fighting the untouchability battle, he should fritter away his energy on other issues by fasting, Mahatmaji said: This was also along the same lines.
('58', 114, 4, 7, 211276) There was therefore no ques tion of frittering away any energy.
('58', 114, 5, 8, 211340) It will be a year now, since the campaign was launched.
('58', 114, 5, 9, 211396) 1 What should be our next step?
('58', 114, 5, 10, 211428) Would you give any message for the New Year?
('58', 114, 6, 11, 211473) A. That question is outside the scope of permission granted to me.
('58', 114, 7, 12, 211540) The Hindustan Times, 7 12 1932
('58', 114, 8, 13, 211571) 159. STATEMENT ON FAST TO ANTI UNTOUCHABILITY COMMITTEE 3
('58', 114, 9, 14, 211629) December 4, 1932 Although the Inspector General gave me permission to say whatever I liked about the origin of the fast and what passed between Government and myself I do not want to take full advantage of the liberty he has given me.
('58', 114, 9, 15, 211864) I shall only give you the substance of what happened so that you can be at ease and my position may not be mis understood.
('58', 114, 9, 16, 211987) The fast which commenced yesterday, was, you will be glad to know, broken just before I came here.
('58', 114, 9, 17, 212086) Mine is a peculiar posi tion.
('58', 114, 9, 18, 212116) Though I have hardened my heart there are things about which I have an exceedingly sensitive nature.
('58', 114, 9, 19, 212217) To me there is no difference of degree in matters of moment and as I am capable of giving my life for a great cause I am equally capable of laying down my life for the life of a comrade.
('58', 114, 10, 20, 212404) 1 The reference is to the resumption of the civil disobedience movement; 2 Vide also Appendix “Discussion with Free Press Representative”.
('58', 114, 11, 21, 212543) 3 Members of the Committee met him at 1 p.m.
('58', 114, 11, 22, 212588) He was lying in bed and spoke in a low voice.
('58', 115, 0, 1, 212634) 116 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('58', 115, 1, 2, 212676) Now in the present case, the question before me was one of choice either to allow a dear comrade to die and myself live uncon cerned or in an attempt to save his life put mine in jeopardy.
('58', 115, 1, 3, 212865) Appa saheb Patwardhan, who is a prisoner in Ratnagiri Jail is an incorrup tible man and a dear comrade whom I know to be cent per cent honest.
('58', 115, 1, 4, 213008) I came to know through regular channels that Appasaheb had to put himself on the lowest diet consistent with bare existence for the service of untouchables which he wanted to do and which he was not permitted to do.
('58', 115, 1, 5, 213224) I wrote to Government 1 in mildest language possible that if relief was not given to Appasaheb, I would have to go through the same agony and sacrifice as he was undergoing.
('58', 115, 1, 6, 213398) He was and is going through slow death.
('58', 115, 1, 7, 213438) I said I should have to fast.
('58', 115, 1, 8, 213468) If I de serted him I would be capable of deserting the Harijans, and a man who deserts his comrades is not worth much.
('58', 115, 1, 9, 213587) I had necessarily to give short notice because there was no choice for me.
('58', 115, 1, 10, 213662) Although I know that Appasaheb is a man of iron nerves, I could imagine what agonies a man on reduced rations would be going through and so I could not help giving short notice.
('58', 115, 1, 11, 213840) I am glad to say that circumstances have arisen enabling me to break my fast though it does not mean that the chapter is closed.
('58', 115, 1, 12, 213969) The Inspector General of Prisons who was here is conferring with Government and pending Government’s decision, which he hopes to get from Government on or before Wednesday morning, the fast stands suspended.
('58', 115, 1, 13, 214177) But I have hopes I will not have to resume it.
('58', 115, 1, 14, 214224) So far as my physical well being is concerned I may say that I could not be better looked after than here and no one should run away with the idea that Government are not at all concerned about my life or they would like me to die in jail.
('58', 115, 1, 15, 214464) They honestly want to see me discharged, if I am to be discharged at all, in full possession of health, that is to say, consistently with my age.
('58', 115, 1, 16, 214610) In the present case I had asked for very little but perhaps Government thought it was too much; but I think they will now understand the delicate position and grant the relief which is sought for.
('58', 115, 1, 17, 214807) 2 There are other matters also regarding the fast, but I do not like to go into them.
('58', 115, 1, 18, 214893) It will certainly be very good if the Government publishes the corres pondence I had with it.
('58', 115, 1, 19, 214987) But I leave it to the Government.
('58', 115, 1, 20, 215021) I hope what I told you is enough to give an assurance that I have not acted stupidly or hurriedly or unwisely.
('58', 115, 1, 21, 215132) Knowing me as you do,
('58', 115, 2, 22, 215154) 1 Vide “Letter to E. E. Doyle”, 30 11 1932.
('58', 115, 3, 23, 215198) 2 What follows has been translated from Mahadevbhaini Diary,.
('58', 116, 0, 1, 215260) VOL. 58 : 16 NOVEMBER, 1932 14 JANUARY, 1933 117
('58', 116, 1, 2, 215309) you would wish me to act in the same manner should a similar occa sion arise again.
('58', 116, 1, 3, 215393) So far as I am concerned I should lose all my self esteem and consider myself a despicable creature if I did not do all I was capable of doing in the contingency.
('58', 116, 1, 4, 215556) For a man like me, who may not commit violence and who has taken a vow to observe non violence in thought, word and deed, has self sacrifice as a last resort.
('58', 116, 1, 5, 215715) I depend on wisdom given by God to a small man like me and the weapon that I possess is readiness to fling away my life when there is a desperate cause.
('58', 116, 1, 6, 215868) In this way my life is based on many such fasts.
('58', 116, 1, 7, 215917) This is the highest form of prayer.
('58', 116, 1, 8, 215953) The world has known it recently but I knew it for many years.
('58', 116, 1, 9, 216015) It is not a thoughtless action.
('58', 116, 1, 10, 216047) In it there is no coercion on others.
('58', 116, 1, 11, 216085) It does bring pressure on individuals and the Government but is no more than the natural and moral outcome of self sacrifice.
('58', 116, 1, 12, 216211) It shakes and awakes the slumbering soul and impels a loving heart to action.
('58', 116, 1, 13, 216289) The person, who has to introduce basic reforms in man, social conditions and atmosphere, has to create fermentation in the public.
('58', 116, 1, 14, 216420) It cannot be brought about without causing a shake up in the society.
('58', 116, 1, 15, 216490) There are only two ways of doing this—violence and non violence.
('58', 116, 1, 16, 216555) Violence affects the body and degrades both the person who commits it and the person who is the object of it.
('58', 116, 1, 17, 216665) But in fasting the person suffers himself and the pressure brought about is of quite different kind.
('58', 116, 1, 18, 216766) It does not affect the body of the person at whom it is directed but strengthens his morale or nature.
('58', 116, 1, 19, 216869) I hope what I have told you is enough.
('58', 116, 1, 20, 216908) Who knows I may have to go through a series of fasts and die by inches.
('58', 116, 1, 21, 216980) But if that does happen I want you to feel proud of my action and not feel that it was the action of an imbecile.
('58', 116, 1, 22, 217094) My life is largely governed by reason and, when it fails, it is governed by a superior force, that is, faith.
('58', 116, 2, 23, 217204) The Times of India, 5 12 1932, and Mahadevbhaini Diary, Vol. II, pp.

('58', 117, 1, 2, 217502) 161. LETTER TO E. E. DOYLE
('58', 117, 2, 3, 217529) December 4, 1932
('58', 117, 3, 4, 217546) DEAR COL.
('58', 117, 3, 5, 217556) DOYLE, I am writing this after having taken my silence.
('58', 117, 3, 6, 217612) It is better to put down in writing what I have understood to be the position.
('58', 117, 3, 7, 217691) The fast remains suspended till Wednesday morning so as to give the Government time to come to a final decision.
('58', 117, 3, 8, 217804) The fast is not to be resumed if the Government give permission to Appasaheb Patwardhan and his associates to do conservancy work in common with the regular file, it being considered sufficient even if permission is restricted to such service in the yard they occupy.
('58', 117, 3, 9, 218072) The larger question of such permission being given to volun teers to be settled as soon as possible.
('58', 117, 3, 10, 218173) By the breaking of the fast today I do not give up the human right of intervention on behalf of fellow prisoners.
('58', 117, 3, 11, 218287) The Government have called my assistance intervention.
('58', 117, 3, 12, 218342) I do not regard it as such.
('58', 117, 3, 13, 218370) All my previous interventions 1 have been helpful as I believe Majors Jones, Martin, Bhandari and perhaps you could testify.
('58', 117, 3, 14, 218495) I enclose herewith a letter to be sent to Appasaheb Patwardhan.
('58', 117, 3, 15, 218559) I am most anxious to know how he is faring.
('58', 117, 3, 16, 218603) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI

('58', 124, 2, 3, 228034) December 5, 1932
('58', 124, 3, 4, 228051) NARANDAS, I got your two letters, of the 3rd and the 4th, together.
('58', 124, 3, 5, 228119) I under stand from what you say in your letter that Kusum will follow Dr. Talwalkar’s advice, but Radha will not.
('58', 124, 3, 6, 228233) She will derive any benefit from the treatment that she is likely to get only if she carries it out with determination.
('58', 124, 3, 7, 228353) Qureshi’s decision to go to Lucknow is correct.
('58', 124, 3, 8, 228401) You did right in not sending Hasmukhrai’s letter.
('58', 124, 3, 9, 228451) See if you can still reason with Parvati and restrain her.
('58', 124, 3, 10, 228510) I would not have the courage to undertake the experiment which you are making with regard to Ratilal.
('58', 124, 3, 11, 228612) This does not mean that you should not continue it.
('58', 124, 3, 12, 228664) But it can certainly mean that you have more love in you than I, and it should not be surprising if that is so.
('58', 124, 3, 13, 228776) The real test of a teacher lies in his success in training his pupil to do better than himself.
('58', 124, 3, 14, 228872) In other words, he should give to the pupil all he has.
('58', 124, 3, 15, 228928) If, however, he had had to struggle hard to acquire what he has, his knowledge and skill would be limited.
('58', 124, 3, 16, 229035) On the other hand, if the pupil whom he is training has great natural aptitude, he can considerably increase what he receives from the teacher.
('58', 124, 3, 17, 229179) I have not, therefore, paid you an idle compliment in saying what I have written above.
('58', 124, 3, 18, 229267) It is nothing but an expression of my sincere wish, and that has always been my nature.
('58', 124, 3, 19, 229355) Whenever I try to impart to somebody what I possess, my only wish is that the other person should improve upon what I give him.
('58', 124, 3, 20, 229483) In small matters this has actually happened.
('58', 124, 3, 21, 229528) Prema seems to be deceiving herself.
('58', 124, 3, 22, 229565) She overworks and falls ill.

('58', 127, 10, 23, 233502) 184. INTERVIEW TO THE PRESS
('58', 127, 11, 24, 233530) December 5, 1932 My future is in the hands of God.
('58', 127, 12, 25, 233581) Gandhiji was resting on a cot when I was conducted to the ward.
('58', 127, 12, 26, 233645) A lady visitor, who had entered the jail premises ten minutes before, was sitting near Gandhiji, carry ing on a one sided conversation, as Gandhiji’s day of silence had not yet ended.
('58', 127, 12, 27, 233829) Mr. Mahadev Desai, the Mahatma’s Secretary, was busy attending to the correspondence.
('58', 127, 12, 28, 233915) Punctually at 2 p.m., the Mahatma broke his silence.
('58', 127, 13, 29, 233968) The Mahatma, referring to the referendum that is being taken in Guruvayur, stated that he was glad, it was being done in a thorough manner.
('58', 127, 13, 30, 234108) Instructions were
('58', 127, 14, 31, 234126) 1 The addressee had expressed a sense of guilt for being warmly clad herself, while serving the scantily clothed Harijan children of Vadaj.
('58', 127, 14, 32, 234266) 2 Vide “Letter to Raihana Tyabji”, 2 12 1932.
('58', 127, 15, 33, 234312) 3 These two sentences are in Gujarati.
('58', 128, 0, 1, 234351) VOL. 58 : 16 NOVEMBER, 1932 14 JANUARY, 1933 129
('58', 128, 1, 2, 234400) printed on the back of the voting paper, and to each house holder the issue was to be clearly explained.
('58', 128, 2, 3, 234505) Referring to the legal difficulties 2, Gandhiji said that it was not his province to study those difficulties.
('58', 128, 2, 4, 234616) He was prepared to be guided by the legal friends.
('58', 128, 2, 5, 234667) The Mahatma stressed that every difficulty ought to be overcome.
('58', 128, 2, 6, 234732) He was satisfied with Dr. Subbaroyan’s Bill 3 published in The Hindu.
('58', 128, 2, 7, 234802) Asked whether he would postpone his
('58', 128, 3, 8, 234838) fast now, in view of the efforts being made in that direction, Gandhiji said that if the referendum was in his favour, and legal difficulties had to be overcome before 2nd January, so far as he could see the fast must be suspended.
('58', 128, 3, 9, 235070) But if Dr. Subbaroyan was not granted leave to introduce the Bill, the fast would commence on 2nd January.
('58', 128, 4, 10, 235177) Commenting on the suggestion made in the Press that the surest way of preventing him from commencing the fast in connection with Guruvayur was to vote against temple entry, the Mahatma said: I cannot get out of the fast by such a dodge.
('58', 128, 4, 11, 235414) I shall then have to impose upon myself a far more severe ordeal than a fast unto death.
('58', 128, 5, 12, 235503) One of those sitting round him, and listening to the answers he was giving me, remarked that there could be nothing more severe than a fast unto death.
('58', 128, 5, 13, 235655) Gandhiji retorted: No.
('58', 128, 5, 14, 235678) Hitherto I have made my fast conditional.
('58', 128, 5, 15, 235720) A more severe resolve would be a thirty days’ fast.
('58', 128, 5, 16, 235772) If I go on a thirty days’ fast, I am bound to carry it out, irrespective of whether the temple is thrown open to Harijans or not.
('58', 128, 6, 17, 235902) Questioned regarding the suggestion of some pundits in South India for a com promise between sanatanists and reformers, that if Harijans underwent a purification ceremony they could be admitted into temples, Gandhiji said: I am not in favour of such a proposal.
('58', 128, 6, 18, 236164) It is the caste Hindus who have to undergo purification for having done a violent wrong to the untouchables.

('58', 132, 5, 7, 243039) 188. LETTER TO RAMDAS GANDHI
('58', 132, 6, 8, 243068) December 6, 1932 Are you able to follow the “Ram Gita” 2?
('58', 132, 6, 9, 243126) Its central idea is bhakti and its fruit.
('58', 132, 6, 10, 243168) Pure bhakti is bound to lead to non attachment and true knowledge.
('58', 132, 6, 11, 243235) If bhakti does not produce such results, it is not true bhakti but mere sentimentality.
('58', 132, 6, 12, 243323) True knowledge means the dis crimination between the essential and the non essential.
('58', 132, 6, 13, 243409) The book learning that does not give this power of discrimination is not know ledge but bookishness.
('58', 132, 6, 14, 243510) You can see that once this is realized and the “Ram Gita” grasped accordingly, all worry and impatience dis appear.
('58', 132, 6, 15, 243626) I am writing this letter soon after the morning prayers.
('58', 132, 6, 16, 243683) I inten ded to write about the fast, but began with comments on the “Ram Gita”.
('58', 132, 6, 17, 243763) The fast is now a thing of the past.
('58', 132, 6, 18, 243800) As it lasted only a day and a half, I feel no effect of it at all.
('58', 132, 6, 19, 243867) The weakness came rather quickly but it also left as quickly as it had come.
('58', 132, 6, 20, 243944) I did a lot of work on the day of the fast and also on Sunday.
('58', 132, 6, 21, 244007) I can now take sufficient quantity of milk.
('58', 132, 6, 22, 244051) You should not, therefore, worry about my fasts any time.
('58', 132, 6, 23, 244109) You should know one thing, i.e., that it is not I who undertake a fast.
('58', 132, 6, 24, 244181) It may be said that God does it, as my fasts are inspired by Him.
('58', 132, 6, 25, 244247) You should not, therefore, feel unhappy when I fast, but, if anything, rejoice that I follow dharma by doing so.
('58', 132, 6, 26, 244360) It should also be remembered that no one is to fast in mere imitation of my action.
('58', 132, 6, 27, 244444) And particularly those who have close relations with me should fast only after consulting me.
('58', 132, 6, 28, 244538) Of course it is possible to imagine circumstances in which there might be no time at all to consult me or when the inspi ration from within might be unmistakable.
('58', 132, 6, 29, 244701) However, the tradition

('58', 134, 5, 10, 247287) M. K. GANDHI
('58', 134, 6, 11, 247300) ENCLOSURE
('58', 134, 7, 12, 247310) By untouchability is meant the pollution of a person by the touch or approach or sight of another person, but as the practice of classifying people as untouchables in the different provinces does not always conform to the definition and having considered the variety of practice, the Servants of the Untouchables Society has decided for the time being to confine its activities to or work for the removal of the follow ing among other disabilities so as to secure for these classes the same status as the other Hindus enjoy: Prohibition to use public temples, wells, roads, schools, parks, dispensaries, hos pitals, crematoria and the like.
('58', 134, 7, 13, 247951) It is however understood that removal of untouchability shall not include interdining as it is generally understood or intercaste marriages.

('58', 136, 7, 18, 251021) 195. LETTER TO A GUJARATI STUDENT
('58', 136, 8, 19, 251055) December 6, 1932 To ensure that my fast does not by any chance pass as black mail, the opinion of the people living in the neighbourhood of the temple is being collected.
('58', 136, 8, 20, 251226) If the majority is in favour of the reform, the reform is a duty and should be effected.
('58', 136, 8, 21, 251315) This in no way involves injustice to the minority.
('58', 136, 8, 22, 251366) If the minority desires, a fixed time can be
('58', 137, 0, 1, 251411) 138 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('58', 137, 1, 2, 251453) set apart for them.
('58', 137, 1, 3, 251473) Otherwise, it is open to them to build a temple of their own.
('58', 137, 1, 4, 251535) If three of the four brothers living as a joint family change their religion, it will be justice if they become the owners of the joint family property and give the fourth brother his share.
('58', 137, 1, 5, 251726) In the present case the utmost that the minority can demand is money to build a separate temple for themselves.
('58', 137, 1, 6, 251838) However, they cannot do even that if an exclusive time is set apart for them when they can worship in the temple.
('58', 137, 1, 7, 251952) If we apply this line of reasoning to your case, the conclusion is this: The Grandfather should have the freedom to follow dharma as he understands it, and you to follow it as you understand it.
('58', 137, 1, 8, 252147) If, for this reason, he asks you to leave the home, you have no choice but to endure the boycott.
('58', 137, 1, 9, 252245) If your wife refuses to live with you unless you undergo ceremonial purification, you should endure boycott by her too.
('58', 137, 1, 10, 252365) You should not live with her against her will.
('58', 137, 1, 11, 252412) A husband has no right whatever to force his wife to do or believe anything.
('58', 137, 1, 12, 252489) But it is probable that the wife will say this: ‘What else can I do even if you do not undergo purification?
('58', 137, 1, 13, 252598) I will live with you.’ If your wife says this, it means that she cares for you more than she does for the custom of untouchability.
('58', 137, 1, 14, 252730) In other words, as between the custom of untoucha bility and living with you, she regards it as her duty to live with you.
('58', 137, 1, 15, 252853) We have to make innumerable such choices every day in our life, but we make them spontaneously and, therefore, are not conscious of doing so.
('58', 137, 1, 16, 252995) This contains a reply to all your questions.
('58', 137, 1, 17, 253040) Ask me to ex plain again if you do not follow anything in this.
('58', 137, 1, 18, 253104) If you wish to put other questions, you may do that too.
('58', 137, 2, 19, 253161) [From Gujarati]
('58', 137, 3, 20, 253177) Mahadevbhaini Diary, Vol. II, p.

('58', 139, 7, 8, 255963) [Before December 7, 1932] 4
('58', 139, 8, 9, 255991) Questioned whether he would be satisfied with the admission of Harijans up to the flag post 5, Mahatmaji made it perfectly clear that there was no halfway house in the house of God.
('58', 139, 8, 10, 256173) There is no such thing as temple entry step by step.
('58', 139, 8, 11, 256226) It should be unconditional and unqualified.
('58', 139, 8, 12, 256270) The Harijans should be given the same equality of status as the other caste Hindus in the matter of public worship.
('58', 139, 9, 13, 256386) Asked whether he would accept some elementary test like purification and giving up eating beef, etc., Mahatmaji said that though he was always advocating the purification and the social uplift of the Harijans in all respects, he has made it a point of honour not to accept any conditions whatsoever as conditions precedent for admission of Harijans into temples.
('58', 139, 9, 14, 256749) Some of the caste Hindus who enjoy the right of free entry need as much purification, if not more.
('58', 139, 10, 15, 256848) The status of Harijans today is in direct proportion to the shameful treatment the caste Hindus have been giving them for generations past.
('58', 139, 10, 16, 256988) In fact the conditions calling for purification are the result of such treatment.
('58', 139, 10, 17, 257070) The position of the caste Hindus in this respect is exactly similar to that of a debtor in a commercial

('58', 141, 1, 2, 259082) 202. LETTER TO DR.
('58', 141, 1, 3, 259101) B. C. ROY
('58', 141, 2, 4, 259111) December 7, 1932
('58', 141, 3, 5, 259128) DEAR DR.
('58', 141, 3, 6, 259137) BIDHAN, I have had a long chat with Sjt.
('58', 141, 3, 7, 259178) Ghanshyamdas Birla, as also Satisbabu regarding the Anti Untouchability Board for Bengal.
('58', 141, 3, 8, 259268) I have also several letters from Bengal complaining about the formation of the Board.
('58', 141, 3, 9, 259354) Before it was formed Ghanshyamdas had told me that he was going to ask you to form the Board, and without giving any thought to the suggestion I at once endorsed it.
('58', 141, 3, 10, 259520) But I see that the idea has not found favour in Bengal, especially so far as Satisbabu and Dr. Suresh are concerned.
('58', 141, 3, 11, 259637) They think that the Board is bound to have a party colour about it.
('58', 141, 3, 12, 259705) I do not know how far this fear is justified, but I do know this that the work of anti untouchability should not become a party affair in any way whatsoever.
('58', 141, 3, 13, 259863) We want all who desire the reform to associate themselves freely and whole heartedly with any organization that may be formed.
('58', 141, 3, 14, 259990) I would therefore suggest that you should call all the workers representing different groups and parties and place yourself at their disposal and let them then choose whomsoever they like as President, offering to give your whole hearted co operation to the President and Board of their choice.
('58', 141, 3, 15, 260285) I know that this requires self abnegation.
('58', 141, 3, 16, 260328) If I know you well, I know that this is not beyond you.
('58', 141, 3, 17, 260384) Of course if you feel that there is nothing in the com plaints made and that you will be able to smooth down all the diffi culties and that you will be able to bring all the parties together, I have of course nothing to say.
('58', 141, 3, 18, 260609) In making the suggestions that I have made I have assumed the impossibility of securing the association of all parties with the Board as it is constituted at present.
('58', 141, 3, 19, 260776) I have now placed the whole thing before you.
('58', 141, 3, 20, 260822) You will do whatever is best in the interest of the cause.
('58', 141, 4, 21, 260881) Khaitan gave me your message about Basanti Devi.
('58', 141, 4, 22, 260930) I told him that I wanted her to make her own choice, but wanted her to work effectively and ceaselessly in the cause of anti untouchability.
('58', 141, 4, 23, 261071) I am not enamoured of her accepting any office in any organization.
('58', 141, 4, 24, 261139) When I was there at the time of the Deshbandhu collections, both she and I had come to the conclusion that hers was not to run any organization,
('58', 141, 5, 25, 261284) 1 For Dr. B. C. Roy’s reply, vide Appendix “Letter from Dr. B.C. Roy”; vide also “Letter to Dr. B. C. Roy”, 15 12 1932.
('58', 142, 0, 1, 261404) VOL. 58 : 16 NOVEMBER, 1932 14 JANUARY, 1933 143

('58', 143, 1, 2, 263329) 204. LETTER TO CHHAGANLAL GANDHI
('58', 143, 2, 3, 263362) YERAVDA MANDIR, December 7, 1932
('58', 143, 3, 4, 263395) CHHAGANLAL, Padma and his mother came and saw me yesterday.
('58', 143, 3, 5, 263455) Devdas was with them, too.
('58', 143, 3, 6, 263482) They had brought two long letters from Prabhudas.
('58', 143, 3, 7, 263532) For the present, I have given them to Devdas to read so that I might know the impression they make on him.
('58', 143, 3, 8, 263639) Those letters and my conver sation with Padma have given me at any rate the definite impression that the two have become deeply infatuated with each other.
('58', 143, 3, 9, 263795) They regard their relation to each other as that of a brother and sister or a father and daughter, but that is nothing but self deception.
('58', 143, 3, 10, 263934) However, I believe that they have not completely fallen.
('58', 143, 3, 11, 263991) The two do not even know that they are sexually attracted to each other, but in fact they are.
('58', 143, 3, 12, 264086) Padma is a silly girl and still a child, is very talkative and also affectionate.
('58', 143, 3, 13, 264168) So probably she does not even know what it is to be sexually attracted.
('58', 143, 3, 14, 264240) But her ways and manners and the expressions on her face are those of a wife to a husband.
('58', 143, 3, 15, 264331) It is rather different with Prabhudas.
('58', 143, 3, 16, 264370) He is full of sexual fancies but is fighting hard to over come them.
('58', 143, 3, 17, 264439) While he had not yet succeeded in that, he came across a girl like Padma.
('58', 143, 3, 18, 264513) He is quite aware that he must entertain no sexual feelings towards her.
('58', 143, 3, 19, 264586) But what can he do?
('58', 143, 3, 20, 264606) That is why he keeps company with her.
('58', 143, 3, 21, 264645) The two have met privately and moved about together.
('58', 143, 3, 22, 264698) What is poor Sarojinidevi to do?
('58', 143, 3, 23, 264731) She is very much upset and deeply hurt.
('58', 143, 3, 24, 264771) Padma would not listen to her, would not wake up, and as for Prabhudas, she does not have the courage to speak to him.
('58', 143, 3, 25, 264890) However, the atmosphere could not but become vitiated.
('58', 143, 3, 26, 264945) The neigh bours saw the impurity of their relation which the two could not see.
('58', 143, 3, 27, 265025) Sitala Sahay came to know of it and was very unhappy.
('58', 143, 3, 28, 265079) He has rushed to me with all of them to find a solution.
('58', 143, 3, 29, 265136) Though Prabhudas has not physically fallen, he believes himself so far guilty that he has come to a decision that the two of them should not be together any time and is asking my permission to undertake a fast of fifteen or twenty days’ duration so that he might learn to be vigilant.
('58', 143, 3, 30, 265421) If he is not permitted to undertake a fast, he wants to be permitted to marry.
('58', 143, 3, 31, 265500) All this is not quite clear in his letters, but I have been able to read it between the lines.
('58', 143, 3, 32, 265595) I do not intend to permit him to undertake a fast, but wish to press him to get married.
('58', 143, 3, 33, 265684) He believes that he would be able to find a suitable girl.
('58', 143, 3, 34, 265743) I think he will have no difficulty in finding such a girl if
('58', 144, 0, 1, 265804) VOL. 58 : 16 NOVEMBER, 1932 14 JANUARY, 1933 145
('58', 144, 1, 2, 265853) he tries to look outside the circle of our caste.
('58', 144, 1, 3, 265903) I have no difficulty in making up my mind to this extent, but what is to be done about Khali?
('58', 144, 1, 4, 265997) Both Prabhudas and Padma need to stay at hill station.
('58', 144, 1, 5, 266052) It would be proper for both to stay in Almora and at separate places but it would not be worthy of what we believe to be our poverty or what others think to be our poverty.
('58', 144, 1, 6, 266225) Our poverty may seem outdated, but then we must put some limit somewhere.
('58', 144, 1, 7, 266299) However, God will show us the way.
('58', 144, 1, 8, 266334) I have written all this just for your information and not to ask for your help in this matter or to cause you worry.
('58', 144, 1, 9, 266451) Prabhudas is no more a child.
('58', 144, 1, 10, 266481) He wants me to show him the way.
('58', 144, 1, 11, 266514) Since he likes my advice, I will go on guiding him and in that way things will be right in the end.
('58', 144, 1, 12, 266614) Ultimately it will happen neither as I wish nor as Prabhudas wishes.
('58', 144, 1, 13, 266683) After all there is a limit to what human effort can achieve.
('58', 144, 1, 14, 266744) Prabhudas’s aspirations have always been noble.
('58', 144, 1, 15, 266792) He is not deceitful and so, God will save him.
('58', 144, 1, 16, 266839) He has struggled very hard to remain a life long celibate, but the Fate seems to have been against him.
('58', 144, 1, 17, 266943) How is Prabhudas to blame for that?
('58', 144, 1, 18, 266979) He has come out safe from many difficult circumstances earlier also and will do so this time, too.
('58', 144, 1, 19, 267078) I will not think it a misfortune if he marries.
('58', 144, 1, 20, 267126) He will rather be happy, and so neither you nor Kashi need grieve at all and make yourselves miserable.
('58', 144, 1, 21, 267230) I am not going to blame Prabhudas even in my thought, neither personally nor in my letters.
('58', 144, 1, 22, 267322) If anybody has been at fault in this, it was me, for I have induced all of you to join me in a stupendous experiment as dangerous as putting one’s hand into a serpent’s burrow.
('58', 144, 1, 23, 267499) I do not at all repent having done so.
('58', 144, 1, 24, 267538) The experi ment will certainly continue and its result is bound to be good.
('58', 144, 1, 25, 267614) It will require sacrifices though, and we shall make them.
('58', 144, 1, 26, 267673) You yourself were thinking of going to Khali.
('58', 144, 1, 27, 267719) If you do wish to go and if you can hand over your Vijapur work to somebody, I see no harm in your going.
('58', 144, 1, 28, 267825) Your presence at Khali will certainly be a source of consolation to Prabhudas, but your first duty is to take care of the work of Vijapur.
('58', 144, 1, 29, 267964) How will Kashi manage?
('58', 144, 1, 30, 267987) She also is almost a cripple.
('58', 144, 1, 31, 268017) She just cannot tolerate the weather at Almora at this time of the year.
('58', 144, 1, 32, 268090) This needs to be considered, too.
('58', 144, 1, 33, 268124) If, after taking into consideration all this, you still wish to go and can go, you may do so.
('58', 144, 1, 34, 268218) But do not think it at all necessary to go there for Pabhudas’s good.
('58', 144, 1, 35, 268288) I cannot think of any thing more to write after this.
('58', 144, 3, 36, 268342) From the Gujarati original: S.N. 33067

('58', 145, 1, 2, 268423) 205. INTERVIEW TO STUDENTS
('58', 145, 2, 3, 268450) POONA, December 7, 1932 How can you fight them?
('58', 145, 2, 4, 268498) 1 What do you generally do when you want your things done?
('58', 145, 2, 5, 268557) You cry.
('58', 145, 2, 6, 268566) Is it not ?
('58', 145, 3, 7, 268578) STUDENTS: (laughingly) Yes.
('58', 145, 4, 8, 268606) GANDHIJI: Then cry and weep.
('58', 145, 4, 9, 268635) (Laughter)
('58', 145, 5, 10, 268646) One student said that as their fathers were Government servants, they were
('58', 145, 6, 11, 268721) afraid to join the anti untouchability movement.
('58', 145, 7, 12, 268770) GANDHIJI: But this is not political work.
('58', 145, 7, 13, 268812) Government servants could do many things, contribute to the funds, engage in their houses untouchables, bring up the Harijan boys and girls and there was no politics in that.
('58', 145, 8, 14, 268987) How can we serve them in schools?
('58', 145, 9, 15, 269021) GANDHIJI: In schools you cannot do anything.
('58', 145, 9, 16, 269066) You go there to learn.
('58', 145, 9, 17, 269089) Do not bother your little heads there but out of school hours, you can do.
('58', 145, 11, 18, 269164) GANDHIJI: Where the untouchables are living, mix with them, play with them and see that their quarters are kept clean, take broom and sweep and teach them to be clean.
('58', 145, 11, 19, 269332) Show by your own life that you do not observe untouchability, show them that you love them.
('58', 145, 11, 20, 269424) Treat them as your blood brothers.
('58', 145, 11, 21, 269459) You are too young.
('58', 145, 11, 22, 269478) Day by day you will learn better the knack of doing the right.
('58', 145, 12, 23, 269541) The Hindustan Times, 9 12 1932
