('58', 146, 1, 2, 269950) 206. INTERVIEW TO ASSOCIATED PRESS OF INDIA
('58', 146, 2, 3, 269994) POONA, December [7] 1, 1932 The Government have regarded the question as of all India im portance.
('58', 146, 2, 4, 270093) From the point of view of prison administration, they had difficulty in giving a decision in connection with the request of Appa saheb Patwardhan, but they have consented to consider the whole question and announce their decision as early as possible.
('58', 146, 2, 5, 270345) In the cir cumstances, I recognized the Government’s difficulty myself, and was permitted to send a telegram 2 to Appasaheb advising him, pending Government decision, to suspend the partial fast.
('58', 146, 2, 6, 270541) The following tele gram was received from him this morning:
('58', 146, 3, 7, 270601) Your kind wire.
('58', 146, 3, 8, 270617) Agree postpone action.
('58', 146, 3, 9, 270640) Letter follows.
('58', 146, 3, 10, 270656) Health is quite all right.
('58', 146, 3, 11, 270683) The result is, Appasaheb begins to take his full rations from today, and my fast stands, naturally, further suspended.
('58', 146, 3, 12, 270802) From my point of view as an anti untouchability worker, the matter is quite simple.
('58', 146, 3, 13, 270886) The so called high caste Hindus, like Appasaheb Patwardhan and his co workers, who voluntarily offer to do conservancy work, purely from a humanitarian motive and in a spirit of service, should be permitted to do that work.
('58', 146, 3, 14, 271110) The existing practice seems to be to confine this service to the so called low caste prisoners, although they may never have done conservancy work outside, and although they may not belong to the Bhangi caste, and this they are made to do whether they wish it or not.
('58', 146, 3, 15, 271378) People who are in prison for conscience sake cannot afford to arrogate superiority to themselves.
('58', 146, 3, 16, 271476) At the same time, there are obvious administrative difficulties in suddenly disturbing a practice that has prevailed for a number of years throughout the prisons in India.
('58', 146, 3, 17, 271648) I have, therefore, no hesitation in suspending the fast myself, pending an examination of the whole question by the Government of India and the Local Government.
('58', 146, 3, 18, 271810) Appasaheb has specialized in this subject and therefore knows much more about it than I do.
('58', 146, 3, 19, 271902) I am glad he has appreciated the Government’s difficulties and has suspended the partial fast.
('58', 146, 3, 20, 271997) Let us hope that an early and satisfactory decision will be arrived at by the Government so as to enable the reformers now

('58', 149, 3, 7, 276129) I have marked certain portions and I send you for immediate reference a free translation of some of the most important portions.
('58', 149, 3, 8, 276258) From this two things stand out prominently.
('58', 149, 3, 9, 276302) Quite a large number of the so called high caste Hindus were actually doing conservancy work with satisfaction, till the work was stopped under your orders.
('58', 149, 3, 10, 276459) The party was organized and its work supervised by Appasaheb Patwar dhan himself.
('58', 149, 3, 11, 276541) At the time there were not sufficient Bhangis in the Jail, therefore the so called low caste prisoners had to be imported from another jail.
('58', 149, 3, 12, 276682) If this information is correct, it makes Appasaheb’s case stronger than I had imagined.
('58', 149, 3, 13, 276770) But that is not now of much moment.
('58', 149, 3, 14, 276806) What however is clear to me is that this is a case which demands early and sympathetic handling.
('58', 149, 3, 15, 276903) Could you please ascertain from the Government when a deci sion may be expected, especially in view of my contemplated fast on the 2nd January next?

('58', 151, 1, 2, 279472) 212. LETTER TO P. N. RAJBHOJ December 8, 1932
('58', 151, 2, 3, 279518) MY DEAR RAJBHOJ 1, With reference to your letter of the 3rd instant, here are my answers to your questions 2: 1. If, as a result of the referendum, it is found that the majority of the temple going population in the area covered by the referendum is against temple entry by Harijans, the fast will undoubtedly be post poned.
('58', 151, 2, 4, 279843) The postponement is likely to be indefinite, and resumption, if there is to be a resumption, can only be determined by circumstances over which I can have no control and which I cannot forsee.
('58', 151, 3, 5, 280036) 2. I think that it is premature to talk of satyagraha about other temples if and when Guruvayur is opened.
('58', 151, 3, 6, 280143) We should always hope that the opening of Guruvayur will clear the way to the other temples.
('58', 151, 3, 7, 280236) 3. I should hope that the Zamorin will not influence the people one way or the other, but even if he does, I should expect peopleat least on a religious question such as the one before them to think independently.
('58', 151, 3, 8, 280450) In any event, I should consider myself bound by the opinion of the majority.
('58', 151, 3, 9, 280527) The referendum will merely determine the question of the fast, not the question of opening the temple.
('58', 151, 3, 10, 280630) If the result is hostile to temple entry by Harijans, ways and means will have to be found of educating public opinion and preparing it for the opening.
('58', 151, 3, 11, 280783) This is clear to me that there should be no forcible opening of any single temple.
('58', 151, 3, 12, 280866) It would be an unseemly thing to have hostile
('58', 151, 4, 13, 280912) 1 Honorary Organizer and General Secretary of the Depressed Classes of India Service Society, Poona 2 (i) “If after the referendum it is found that the caste Hindus are against temple entry, will you fast?
('58', 151, 4, 14, 281118) You stated that you will postpone your fast.
('58', 151, 4, 15, 281163) How long will you postpone?
('58', 151, 4, 16, 281191) (ii) When Guruvayur Temple is opened, satyagraha will be offered at other temples.
('58', 151, 4, 17, 281274) Will you render your active support?
('58', 151, 4, 18, 281311) (iii) As the Zamorin is a big landlord and influential man, will he not be able to carry a large section of the caste Hindus with him?
('58', 151, 4, 19, 281446) Will it be a proper and genuine expression of the opinion of the caste Hindus that we obtain through the referendum?
('58', 151, 4, 20, 281563) (iv) Are you not aware that many caste Hindus eat beef ?
('58', 151, 4, 21, 281620) In your fifth statement in reply to my question you asked Harijans to give up beef.
('58', 151, 4, 22, 281704) Some people take it as a condition for entry into temples.
('58', 151, 4, 23, 281763) In that case are all caste Hindus who eat beef eligible for temple entry?
('58', 151, 4, 24, 281837) You might be aware that there are several untouchables who neither eat beef nor lead unclean lives.
('58', 151, 4, 25, 281937) Why are such untouchables prevented from entry into temples?” (S.N. 18652) 3 Vide also Appendix “Discussion with Macrae”.
('58', 152, 0, 1, 282059) VOL. 58 : 16 NOVEMBER, 1932 14 JANUARY, 1933 153
('58', 152, 1, 2, 282108) sections looking daggers at one another, using the same temple.
('58', 152, 1, 3, 282172) 4. I am firmly of opinion that there should be no condition made for the entry of Harijans to temples that are not applicable to the other Hindu worshippers.
('58', 152, 1, 4, 282330) There should be therefore one regulation for all.
('58', 152, 1, 5, 282380) I personally do feel that beef being forbidden food in Hindu ism, it should be given up by beef eating Harijans, whether the temples are opened or not.
('58', 152, 1, 6, 282532) They should impose that condition on themselves without any prompting and without any consideration in the shape of temple entry or other.
('58', 152, 1, 7, 282671) There can be no doubt that every reform voluntarily made by Harijans among themselves is bound to hasten the removal of the black mark.
('58', 152, 1, 8, 282807) It would make the task of caste Hindu reformers infinitely easier than it is, and wind will be taken out of the sail of the opponents of the removal of untoucha bility.
('58', 152, 1, 9, 282976) I hope therefore that no Harijan will say, ‘First remove un touchability, and then we shall abstain from beef or do many other things expected of us.’ Such an attitude will be just as bad as the atti tude of those who would impose conditions on their admission to temples and the like.

('58', 154, 9, 19, 286967) 216. STATEMENT ON UNTOUCHABILITY X
('58', 154, 10, 20, 287002) December 9, 1932 One of the friends who attended the meeting of Anti Untouchability League, which because of the prior body founded by Mr. V. R. Shinde bearing practically the same name will henceforth be called, and in my opinion more appropriately, the Servants of Un touchables Society, gave me a list of several questions with argument woven into them.
('58', 154, 10, 21, 287359) For the sake of brevity, I reproduce the most important of these questions in the form of a letter:
('58', 154, 11, 22, 287459) As the Society has been formed at your instance and for the purpose of
('58', 154, 12, 23, 287530) carrying out the programme for the removal of untouchability, workers
('58', 154, 13, 24, 287600) naturally would expect your definite guidance.
('58', 154, 13, 25, 287647) The first question that occurs to
('58', 154, 14, 26, 287681) me then is this: Are the workers to constitute themselves as reformers, doing
('58', 154, 15, 27, 287759) 1 Addressee’s wife
('58', 155, 0, 1, 287778) 156 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('58', 155, 1, 2, 287820) work of uplifting untouchables or uplifting themselves and if it is to be the
('58', 155, 2, 3, 287898) latter, should not the greatest stress be laid upon work amongst caste Hindus
('58', 155, 3, 4, 287976) themselves, and if so how is that work to be done?
('58', 155, 3, 5, 288027) This is a comprehensive question and in answering it, I hope to be able to cover the main points raised by my friend.
('58', 155, 3, 6, 288145) I have repea tedly declared in unequivocal terms that caste Hindus are sinners who have sinned against those who are called untouchables.
('58', 155, 3, 7, 288283) Caste Hindus are responsible for the present condition of the untouchables.
('58', 155, 3, 8, 288359) Imme diately, therefore, they repent for the sin and purify themselves by removing the load of untouchability from off the backs of un touch ables, we shall discover perfect transformation among the latter.
('58', 155, 3, 9, 288566) Not that they will at once shed the habits of a lifetime, but there would be conscious effort on their part to shed those habits and everywhere the multitude of caste Hindus will be helping them to give up those habits.
('58', 155, 3, 10, 288786) It would be like the suppressed members of a family rejoining the suppressors, feeling the warmth of reunion and suppressors receiv ing them as if they were never separated.
('58', 155, 3, 11, 288960) I am painfully conscious of the fact that such a consummation will take some time before it comes, but it will never come unless some of us understand and adopt the right attitude.
('58', 155, 3, 12, 289141) Even among the liberal minded workers, I have often heard the opinion expressed that untouchability should be removed only when the Harijans give up their bad habits, educate themselves and live clean lives utterly forgetting that Harijans cannot do these things whilst they remain untouchables.
('58', 155, 3, 13, 289437) Even if they would, they forget also that individual Harijans who are living decently are not received on terms of equality by caste Hindus and the very best amon gst them are denied the ordinary amenities of life every day and con tact with caste Hindus.
('58', 155, 3, 14, 289693) Their birth constitutes the automatic cause for the penal servitude for life which cannot be commuted by any change in manners or any other consideration.
('58', 155, 3, 15, 289848) Hence there is and can be no incentive to better their mode of life.
('58', 155, 3, 16, 289917) The idea has taken deep root in their minds that they may hope for no redemption at least during their present lifetime.
('58', 155, 3, 17, 290038) The only way therefore is to undo the mischief and make them realize the dignity of their status as men.
('58', 155, 3, 18, 290143) Caste Hindus should first un conditionally take them up as their very own and then and then only can a change in their condition on a vast scale take place.
('58', 155, 3, 19, 290300) Therefore the first and foremost items in the programme of work should be a whirlwind propaganda for educating and canvassing opinion among
('58', 156, 0, 1, 290440) VOL. 58 : 16 NOVEMBER, 1932 14 JANUARY, 1933 157
('58', 156, 1, 2, 290489) caste Hindus.
('58', 156, 1, 3, 290503) This work can be done by personal visits on a most intensive scale and by flooding the country with literature on the subject.
('58', 156, 1, 4, 290630) In my opinion untouchability is as self demonstrated a sin as untruth.
('58', 156, 1, 5, 290701) The proposition does not need the support of Shastras.
('58', 156, 1, 6, 290756) Nevertheless, as there is a body of learned men who invoke the aid of Shastras in order to justify untouchability by reason of mere birth, it would be well for workers to arm themselves with pro reform litera ture.
('58', 156, 1, 7, 290971) There is a growing body of learned men in Shastras who em phatically hold that untouchability as it is believed and practised today, has no support whatsoever in the Shastras.
('58', 156, 1, 8, 291147) This propaganda can only be entrusted to workers who have character to lose, those who will not be easily ruffled by insults, who have patience to listen to counter argument and wit enough to combat it.
('58', 156, 1, 9, 291350) In a movement of religious reform, there is no room whatsoever for coercion in any shape or form.
('58', 156, 1, 10, 291448) Reformers will have to submit to their fate if as a result of this personal canvassing it is discovered that a vast majority of Hindus have no sense of sin about untouchability or even otherwise are averse to its removal and the consequent raising of the Harijans’ status.
('58', 156, 1, 11, 291721) They will have then without being irritated against the majority shown by personal suffering that they are in the right and the majority in the wrong and this they can best do by making common cause with Harijans and voluntarily denying themselves those rights and conveniences which are today denied to Harijans.
('58', 156, 1, 12, 292035) Such an act of self denial by a large body of men and women will by itself fill the Harijans with hope and raise them in their own estimation and encourage them to an effort for self improvement.
('58', 156, 1, 13, 292231) The most effective work that can be done among caste men is to induce them to take one Harijan at least per family either as member or at least as domestic servant.
('58', 156, 1, 14, 292396) There is an ancient practice in well to do households never to take their meal without having at least one guest to share it with them.
('58', 156, 1, 15, 292532) Nowadays this is more observed in the breach than in the performance.
('58', 156, 1, 16, 292602) This act is described as one of the five daily yajnas or sacrifices.
('58', 156, 1, 17, 292671) I cannot conceive of a better mode of offering this yajna than that of having a Harijan to share the meal with us.
('58', 156, 1, 18, 292786) This must not be confused with inter dining.
('58', 156, 1, 19, 292831) For me, inter dining means dining with those who may touch your food and whose food you may touch but dining together under the same roof without the mutual touch does not mean inter dining.
('58', 157, 0, 1, 293022) 158 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('58', 157, 1, 2, 293064) If untouchability of Harijans is removed, there can be no objection to their sharing the family meal precisely on the same terms as other castes.
('58', 157, 1, 3, 293210) There are again innumerable social functions and ceremonies to which Harijans are never invited by caste men.
('58', 157, 1, 4, 293320) Their cattle and other domestic animals may share their joys and sorrows but not Harijans or, if they do, these are occasions when they are pointedly reminded that they are not the same sort of human beings as caste Hindus.
('58', 157, 1, 5, 293544) I have pointed out only a few illustrations of the kind of pro paganda and work that can be and should be done amongst caste men to purge themselves of the sin but, even as special treatment and care are bestowed upon a banished member of the family when he is recalled, so will caste men do the work amongst Harijans themselves when the sense of sin has really dawned upon them.
('58', 157, 1, 6, 293924) They will then go to the Harijans not as teachers or donors but as debtors going to their creditors to discharge their obligations and in that humble spirit they will offer to teach them, their children and otherwise help them in every way possible for them.
('58', 157, 1, 7, 294183) It has been suggested that if this constructive programme is taken up, it would prove too expensive and too long drawn out to be of immediate service, and to do it would be a programme by itself on the part of a handful of reformers.
('58', 157, 1, 8, 294417) It assumes a different shape when it is conceived as an item in the programme of self purification.
('58', 157, 1, 9, 294517) A tree is judged by its fruit and so has the changed spirit of caste men to be judged by its results.
('58', 157, 1, 10, 294619) It is, therefore, not enough for them to be able to say that they have touched half a dozen Harijans during the day or even that they have fed a Harijan but their newly born affection for them should make them impatient to render this neglected portion of humanity every help that it is in their power to render.
('58', 157, 1, 11, 294932) After all, Harijans themselves have to feel the effect of the new awakening in Hinduism and they cannot do so unless caste men come in contact with them in every walk of life and every activity.
('58', 157, 1, 12, 295127) If the awakening is universal, constructive programme will not prove expen sive.
('58', 157, 1, 13, 295208) Local volunteers will work in their own localities without needing any payment and if the awakening is not universal it becomes the double duty of workers to tackle the constructive programme.
('58', 157, 1, 14, 295401) Therefore, whether it is slow or quick, expensive or inexpensive, I have no doubt it must be the integral part of the activities of the society.
('58', 157, 1, 15, 295546) It may not be able to overtake all Harijan children, or all
('58', 158, 0, 1, 295606) VOL. 58 : 16 NOVEMBER, 1932 14 JANUARY, 1933 159
('58', 158, 1, 2, 295655) Harijan sick needing medical aid but whatever is done in that direction will count and should be an earnest of more to come.
('58', 158, 1, 3, 295780) Moreover the monetary contributions will be the index of the extent to which caste Hindus have responded to the call of the age.
('58', 158, 1, 4, 295909) In this programme temple entry occupies the most important place, for, when the innumerable public temples are opened to Harijans they will immediately feel the dawning of a new era for them.
('58', 158, 1, 5, 296101) They will forget that they were once the outcastes of the society.
('58', 158, 1, 6, 296168) Intermingling at temples will of itself induce a change in their outlook and in their lives.
('58', 158, 1, 7, 296261) They will forsake their objectionable habits.
('58', 158, 1, 8, 296307) But say some of my correspondents:
('58', 158, 2, 9, 296342) What are temples worth today?
('58', 158, 2, 10, 296372) They are dens of iniquities.
('58', 158, 2, 11, 296401) All kinds of practices are going on there.
('58', 158, 2, 12, 296444) I have a cutting before me containing a letter from a lady draw ing an ugly picture of what is going on in a famous temple.
('58', 158, 2, 13, 296568) I do not know how far charges made against some of these celebrated shrines are true.
('58', 158, 2, 14, 296654) There is no doubt that temples are not what they must have been when they were built.
('58', 158, 2, 15, 296740) Temple reform in itself is a separate subject.
('58', 158, 2, 16, 296787) Their deterioration cannot be pleaded as valid reason for not opening them to Harijans and I know that vast mass of poor people who visit these temples are untouched by corruption that may be going on in them; and whatever may be true of famous temples is un doubtedly not true of village temples.
('58', 158, 2, 17, 297085) Village temples were and even now are a place of refuge for villagers.
('58', 158, 2, 18, 297156) It is difficult to conceive the life of a Hindu villager being regulated without his temple.
('58', 158, 2, 19, 297249) Whether it is birth or death or marriage in a Hindu family, temple plays a pro minent part.
('58', 158, 2, 20, 297341) Therefore, Harijans must have access to it.
('58', 158, 2, 21, 297385) But says another correspondent:
('58', 158, 3, 22, 297417) If you do not insist on Harijans conforming to certain regulations such as cleanliness, you will lower the already tottering reputation of temples.
('58', 158, 3, 23, 297565) I anticipate no such catastrophe.
('58', 158, 3, 24, 297599) What I have said is that no special condition should be laid down for the entry of Harijans that is not applicable to every other Hindu worshipper.
('58', 158, 3, 25, 297747) I heartily endorse that suggestion of Dr. Bhagwandas that in stead of untouchability senselessly attaching to birth, it should attach to individual’s outward conduct.
('58', 158, 3, 26, 297914) 1 One cannot regulate inward
('58', 158, 4, 27, 297943) 1 Vide also “Letter to Bhagwandas” 14 12 1939.
('58', 159, 0, 1, 297990) 160 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('58', 159, 1, 2, 298032) cleanliness but it is possible to regulate outward conduct and therefore those whose habits are unclean, who are unwashed and unkempt, who are drunk, should be regarded untouchables till they have cleaned them selves even as every human being all the world over in decent society is untouchable whilst he is in a dirty condition from any cause whatso ever.
('58', 159, 1, 3, 298389) But under the cover of specious argument as cleanliness, etc., Harijans should no longer be kept without payment of the debt due to them by caste men.
('58', 159, 1, 4, 298540) The first step therefore is to receive them as they are, subject only to general regulations, not specially imposed for the occasion, but the regulations that have been in vogue before reforms came.
('58', 159, 1, 5, 298739) New regulations may undoubtedly be framed after freedom of Harijans is honestly declared and assured to them.

('58', 162, 2, 3, 303488) December 9, 1932
('58', 162, 3, 4, 303505) MY DEAR CHARLIE, I have your letter of 12th November only today.
('58', 162, 3, 5, 303570) If it was an airmail letter, it should have been received about the 22nd of Novem ber.
('58', 162, 3, 6, 303657) Your letter therefore seems to have gone through the whole circuit of examination before being delivered to me.
('58', 162, 3, 7, 303769) I shall enquire.
('58', 162, 3, 8, 303786) I am surprised that there should be any question arising as to whether I could do untouchability work more effectively as a free man than as a prisoner.
('58', 162, 3, 9, 303939) I should think that it is a self evident proposition that I could do more effective work as a free man.
('58', 162, 3, 10, 304043) At the same time I can fully appreciate the Government standpoint.
('58', 162, 3, 11, 304110) So long as they feel that civil disobedience must be put down at any cost and that their plan might be frustrated or checked if I was left free to carry on civil disobe dience propaganda, they are bound to keep me under detention unless I would give them an assurance, be it even verbal, that I would not carry on civil disobedience propaganda.
('58', 162, 3, 12, 304455) For my part, however much I may wish to confine myself wholly to untouchability work, I cannot without a full knowledge of the circumstances outside give any under taking as to my future action.
('58', 162, 3, 13, 304650) After all civil disobedience under given circumstances is as much an article of faith with me as removal of untouchability.
('58', 162, 3, 14, 304774) I can therefore never say beforehand what will occupy my attention exclusively or for the most part at a given mo ment and since a civil resister bargains for the punishment he receives for his resistance, he must not fret over it.
('58', 162, 3, 15, 305006) Therefore and to that extent I am content with my lot.
('58', 162, 3, 16, 305061) I hope this tells you clearly how I stand.
('58', 162, 3, 17, 305104) I hope you got there no alarming report about my little fast over Appasaheb Patwardhan.
('58', 162, 3, 18, 305192) I need not, give you the details about the event for you must have seen them in the papers.
('58', 162, 3, 19, 305284) All I need say is that except for a little weakness there is no ill effect left of the fast.
('58', 162, 3, 20, 305377) I hope too that you are finding no difficulty in understanding and appre ciating the temple entry question and the contemplated fast.
('58', 162, 3, 21, 305511) I hope that you are keeping your health in spite of the stress.
('58', 162, 3, 22, 305575) Dr. Ansari is wonderful.

('58', 172, 3, 9, 322197) 237. LETTER TO NANABHAI I. MASHRUWALA
('58', 172, 4, 10, 322235) December 11, 1932 First about Appasaheb.
('58', 172, 4, 11, 322276) One should serve untouchables wherever one finds them.
('58', 172, 4, 12, 322331) Moreover, persons serving the cause of anti untou chability ought not to be silent witnesses to people who are not untou chables being treated as such.
('58', 172, 4, 13, 322483) Appa’s tapashcharya in this regard is not a new thing, and his demand was not that he should be permitted to do a particular kind of work in place of another, but that he should not be prevented from doing what he regarded as his dharma.
('58', 172, 4, 14, 322721) I cannot go into further details on this subject.
('58', 172, 4, 15, 322771) However, I did not have even a moment’s doubt about the propriety of Appasaheb’s step or about the step I intended to take.
('58', 172, 4, 16, 322895) Nor have I any doubt about it now after the matter is over.
('58', 172, 4, 17, 322955) Now about the issue of temple entry.
('58', 172, 4, 18, 322992) It would of course be ille gal on the part of the trustees if they go beyond their authority in doing anything.
('58', 172, 4, 19, 323104) The present movement is not intended to force the trustees to take any illegal step.
('58', 172, 4, 20, 323189) However, if the people on whose behalf they are acting as trustees desire a particular step to be taken, it becomes their duty to secure legal sanction for it.
('58', 172, 4, 21, 323349) If the people are against a proposed step, a fast [to force the trustees to take it] would be blackmail, and a poll is being taken to prove that the intended fast is not of such character.
('58', 172, 4, 22, 323538) If the majority of people express themselves against Harijans being permitted to enter temples, then I will not fast on that issue.
('58', 172, 4, 23, 323670) But other more difficult duties will arise for us then, which it is unnecessary to discuss now.
('58', 172, 4, 24, 323766) If a temple belongs to a parti cular sect, we cannot insist on people outside its fold being permitted to visit it, but the Harijans belonging to that sect must have the right to
('58', 173, 0, 1, 323945) 174 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('58', 173, 1, 2, 323987) enter it.
('58', 173, 1, 3, 323997) This question, however, does not arise at all in the case of the Guruvayur Temple.
('58', 173, 1, 4, 324080) The idea of fasting has a purely spiritual aim.
('58', 173, 1, 5, 324128) Without it, it would be impossible to overcome our inertia.
('58', 173, 1, 6, 324188) Whenever a religion had lost its vitality, men of sincere devotion went through extreme tapashcharya to restore life to it.
('58', 173, 1, 7, 324312) Without such tapashcharya, no religious awakening can be brought about.
('58', 173, 1, 8, 324384) If a person disappears into a jungle and undertakes an indefinite fast, nothing can be said against his step.
('58', 173, 1, 9, 324494) It would of course be considered foolish if anyone did that ignorantly.
('58', 173, 1, 10, 324566) But the step would be regarded as irreproachable if taken with a spiritual aim.
('58', 173, 1, 11, 324646) A lighter step than that by me in the present circumstances would be fully justified.
('58', 173, 1, 12, 324732) I say ‘lighter’ because my fast will not be absolute or unconditional.
('58', 173, 1, 13, 324803) The fast will end if a certain condition is accepted.
('58', 173, 1, 14, 324857) In laying down a condition one should exercise discretion and self restraint, and I believe that I have done so in the present instance.
('58', 173, 1, 15, 324994) Being conditional, the fast will shock the people less to that extent.
('58', 173, 1, 16, 325065) My relation with the people has now become a family bond.
('58', 173, 1, 17, 325123) For many years I have trained myself for such a bond, and I have seen from personal experience that, within certain limits, fasting has a place in domestic relationships.
('58', 173, 1, 18, 325294) Even in that sphere, one must of course exercise self restraint.
('58', 173, 1, 19, 325359) It is after experimenting in the small family circle that I have widened the field of practice.
('58', 173, 1, 20, 325455) I have tried to explain the idea so as to convince your reason, but the truth is that I have never undertaken any of my fasts after rational consideration, but that each one of them was under taken in obedience to the inner voice.
('58', 173, 1, 21, 325686) I do not mean to say that there can be no error in this.
('58', 173, 1, 22, 325743) There goes on in the heart a ceaseless battle between the divine and the demoniac.
('58', 173, 1, 23, 325826) We cannot always judge when it is the demon that deludes us or the divine that leads us.
('58', 173, 1, 24, 325915) It is for this reason that religion enjoins that everybody who wishes to awaken the divine in him should walk on the razor’s edge of the yamaniyamas.
('58', 173, 2, 25, 326065) [From Gujarati]
('58', 173, 3, 26, 326081) Mahadevbhaini Diary, Vol. II, pp.
('58', 174, 0, 1, 326115) VOL. 58 : 16 NOVEMBER, 1932 14 JANUARY, 1933 175

('58', 184, 1, 2, 342941) 258. LETTER TO C. V. VAIDYA
('58', 184, 2, 3, 342969) December 13, 1932 I was delighted to receive your letter 1 so full and instructive.
('58', 184, 2, 4, 343053) I wish you could have discussed your position with me before sending your letter to the Premier; but nothing is lost yet, and if you can con veniently spare the time, I would love to see you and discuss the thing with you.
('58', 184, 2, 5, 343276) Meanwhile, I present my doubts: 1. Do you mean to say that under no circumstances can Hindu Law or Hindu practice be changed by Hindu public opinion ?
('58', 184, 2, 6, 343427) 2. Do you say that Smritis are unalterable and that everything said in them has to be carried out to the letter by a devout Hindu?
('58', 184, 2, 7, 343558) 3. Were not Smritis written or revealed in response to the requirements of the age in which they were written?
('58', 184, 2, 8, 343669) 4. Were not the Smritis written at different times?
('58', 184, 2, 9, 343721) 5. If you hold that under no conceivable circumstance can legislation alter prevailing practice, how would you deal with the legal difficulty which is supposed to exist in Madras, viz., that even one man can under the law decided by the present courts, prevent the entry of untouchables to certain temples in spite of the consensus of public opinion in favour of such entry?
('58', 184, 2, 10, 344096) 6. Or, do you hold that the existing temples can never be opened to untouchables?
('58', 184, 2, 11, 344178) 7. Or, is not your opposition to legislation based on the assumption that the mixed legislatures would be interfering with
('58', 184, 3, 12, 344301) 1 Dated December 8, 1932 which read: “ .
('58', 184, 3, 13, 344342) I have addressed a letter (dated November 18, 1932) to Mr. Ramsay MacDonald, President, 3rd R.T.C. .
('58', 184, 3, 14, 344443) The reason which led me to address the letter is that I apprehend that hasty reformers will force by legislation, temple entry and such like reforms down the throats of the orthodox Hindus of India who are voiceless, not being represented in the R.T.C. or the Legislative Councils.
('58', 184, 3, 15, 344725) Subsequently came your declaration published in The Times of India, that if you had the power you would make it an offence under the Penal Code for anyone to refuse to touch the Harijans.
('58', 184, 3, 16, 344913) This was the last straw that broke the back of my silence and I at once addressed a letter on the subject to Mr. Ramsay MacDonald, President, 3rd R.T.C., requesting him to introduce a section in the new Constitution like the one existing in the present Government of India Act, prohibiting future legislatures from passing any laws forcing reforms in religious and socio religious matters.
('58', 184, 3, 17, 345303) I feel strongly on the subject of non interference by the State Legislatures in such matters and I thought it my duty to do what I can for it at this juncture” (S.N. 18669).
('58', 185, 0, 1, 345477) 186 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('58', 185, 1, 2, 345519) Hindu religion, although if Hindu opinion was taken, such legislation would be found to have no public backing?

('58', 186, 1, 2, 347412) 259. LETTER TO K. NAGESWAR RAO
('58', 186, 2, 3, 347443) December 13, 1932
('58', 186, 3, 4, 347461) MY DEAR NAGESWAR RAO, I have your letter.
('58', 186, 3, 5, 347503) My message to you is that I hope Andhra will be to the fore in removing the blot of untouchability of Hinduism.
('58', 186, 3, 6, 347615) As to the interview 1 with Shree Suryanarayana Rao, I do not think there is anything to send to the Press.
('58', 186, 3, 7, 347722) Nearly three fourths of the long time I gave him was passed in reading some correspondence with his guru and then discussing with him his own credentials or qualifications for knowing all about Hinduism.
('58', 186, 3, 8, 347926) He quoted some verses from the Bhagavad Gita to convince me that untouchability was countenanced by it and that it attached to birth, but he left on me the impression that public opinion in the general interest of the commu nity demanded removal of the bar against the entry of avarnas to temples, and that so far as the other disabilities were concerned they should certainly be removed.
('58', 186, 3, 9, 348315) But he was emphatic that there should be no force used in connection with temple entry, but that efforts should be made in a conciliatory manner to persuade custodians of temples to throw them open to untouchables wherever public opinion was ripe.
('58', 186, 3, 10, 348563) Naturally there was no question of our agreeing, but the attempt was made to understand each other’s position and he said that as he understood what it was that I was exactly fighting for, he would try to collect together the sanatanists in the South and procure a settlement.
('58', 186, 3, 11, 348840) Whilst I am dictating this, Ramchandra Rao is here, and he generally confirms my impression.
('58', 186, 3, 12, 348933) If Sjt.
('58', 186, 3, 13, 348941) Suryanarayana Rao has said anything that is inconsistent with this statement, you should show this to him before publishing it, or, if you come to the conclusion that my statement should be published in any case, then, too, it should not be published without its being first shown to him.
('58', 186, 4, 14, 349230) Yours sincerely, SJT.

('58', 189, 5, 16, 354142) 264. STATEMENT ON UNTOUCHABILITY XI
('58', 189, 6, 17, 354178) December 14, 1932
('58', 189, 7, 18, 354196) Supposing on the strength of your statement 1 that in the event of the Referendum going against you, you would have to postpone your fast indefinitely, voters, although they may be in favour of Harijans entering the Guruvayur Temple, give their votes against you for the sake of preventing the fast, what would you do?
('58', 189, 7, 19, 354515) This is a question asked of me.
('58', 189, 7, 20, 354547) I should hope there would be no such trickery resorted to by the voters.
('58', 189, 7, 21, 354620) If, however, it is discovered that they have resorted to any such trickery, I can only say that they would be endangering my life more than if they voted honestly and according to their convictions.
('58', 189, 7, 22, 354819) Having put my life at stake for the removal of untouchability, I hope I shall not be found so cowardly as to save it by taking advan tage of any dodge.
('58', 189, 7, 23, 354971) What I have said about the postponement refers only to honest voting.
('58', 189, 7, 24, 355041) If I am satisfied that the majority of temple goers in the neigh bourhood of Guruvayur are really against temple entry by Harijans, and if I still persisted in fasting, I should be guilty of using coercive measures in order to secure my end.
('58', 189, 7, 25, 355283) I am not conscious of ever having done such a thing in my life, and I am not likely to do so now,
('58', 189, 8, 26, 355381) 1 Vide “Letter to P.N. Rajbhoj”, 8 12 1932.
('58', 190, 0, 1, 355425) VOL. 58 : 16 NOVEMBER, 1932 14 JANUARY, 1933 191
('58', 190, 1, 2, 355474) when I may be nearing my end, to deny the practice of a lifetime.
('58', 190, 1, 3, 355540) I am most anxious to preserve the approaching fast against the slightest taint of coercion, and I have no doubt that at the end of it, it would be found to have been free from reproach.
('58', 190, 1, 4, 355726) I am watching, as a scientist would watch, the effect the contemplated fast is producing, and it fills me with hope and delight.
('58', 190, 1, 5, 355855) It has set the people thinking, and it will certainly not compel any person to act against his cons cience; but it is making sluggish people shed their sluggishness and act promptly, that is to say, that it is moving to action those who bear affection towards me.
('58', 190, 1, 6, 356119) I am not sorry for that movement.
('58', 190, 1, 7, 356153) Those who think that I am attempting to corrupt Hinduism, write to me angry letters and invite me to anticipate the fast and thus hasten my death.
('58', 190, 1, 8, 356300) I do not mind such letters.

('58', 196, 4, 7, 368238) 272. LETTER TO MANIBEHN
('58', 196, 5, 8, 368262) December 14, 1932 It is but natural that palate of a person in good health should be sensitive to, and relish for himself, the tastes of various foods, and even the man of the highest degree of self control will recognize and ought to be able to recognize, such relish.
('58', 196, 5, 9, 368532) Only he should have no attach ment to it.
('58', 196, 5, 10, 368574) When one becomes accustomed to abstinence from a harmful thing—whatever the reason for abstaining from it, such absti nence benefits the soul as well as the body as the hankering for that thing disappears.
('58', 196, 5, 11, 368780) The effect of a complete or a partial fast varies with different men according to their natures and in the same person at different times.
('58', 196, 5, 12, 368919) You will be able from your numerous experiences to think of cases in which the mind or the body or both of them were the cause for such difference.
('58', 196, 5, 13, 369067) Not only do I feel no hardship in observing silence, but every week I eagerly look forward to one o’clock on Sunday.
('58', 196, 5, 14, 369184) The fact is that we feel hardship in doing a thing for which we are not mentally ready.
('58', 196, 5, 15, 369272) Anything for which the mind is ready or is made ready becomes quite easy to do.
('58', 196, 5, 16, 369352) The person who becomes absorbed in silence ceases to hear the idle chatting of people around him.
('58', 196, 5, 17, 369450) I hope you remember the secluded hut erected for Kishore lalbhai.
('58', 196, 5, 18, 369516) There could be nothing but peace and silence in such a place.
('58', 196, 5, 19, 369578) For two or three days Kishorelal found the rattling noise made by running trains unbearable, and I suggested that he should close his ears with cotton plugs.
('58', 196, 5, 20, 369736) However, when I went to him the next morning,
('58', 196, 6, 21, 369782) 1 The letter was in reply to addressee’s which read: “A sinner as I am by what means should I absolve myself of the sins?
('58', 196, 6, 22, 369904) You had confessed your sins before your father; how can I develop the courage to do likewise?
('58', 196, 6, 23, 369998) I have read your Autobiography; how can I gain the strength to admit my sins?”

('58', 197, 1, 2, 370119) he told me that he had heard neither the train whistle nor the noise of the running wheels on that day.
('58', 197, 1, 3, 370223) Of course both these things had been there, but he had stopped paying attention to them.
('58', 197, 1, 4, 370312) In other words, he had become accustomed to silence.
('58', 197, 1, 5, 370365) My suggestion about the cotton plugs had roused him, for such artificial aid would be repugnant to one who has voluntarily retired into solitude and taken a vow of silence.
('58', 197, 1, 6, 370538) Those who come to love silence begin ultimately to listen to the divine music within, and are so absorbed in it that they cease to hear the sounds occurring around them.
('58', 197, 1, 7, 370708) Our cat family has three members.
('58', 197, 1, 8, 370742) They present themselves daily without fail at both the mealtimes, without a bell being rung for them or without being called.
('58', 197, 1, 9, 370868) If we all become as punctual as these dear creatures, we would save millions of hours of time.
('58', 197, 1, 10, 370963) And we have doubtless been taught how time is money.
('58', 197, 1, 11, 371016) This is perfectly true, and so money saved is money earned.
('58', 197, 1, 12, 371076) Who can compute the loss of wealth to this world through people who do not value time?

('58', 197, 7, 21, 371679) 274. LETTER TO NARANDAS GANDHI
('58', 197, 8, 22, 371710) December 14, 1932
('58', 197, 9, 23, 371728) NARANDAS, I got the weekly mail.
('58', 197, 9, 24, 371761) I am writing this after reading Anandi’s letter.
('58', 197, 9, 25, 371810) The rule about eating three times only does not apply to any body who is ill or weak in health.
('58', 197, 9, 26, 371906) Nor does it apply to children.
('58', 198, 0, 1, 371937) VOL. 58 : 16 NOVEMBER, 1932 14 JANUARY, 1933 199
('58', 198, 1, 2, 371986) rule which applies to all is this: Everybody should eat in the same manner as he takes medicine—in measured quantity and at fixed times.
('58', 198, 1, 3, 372123) Somebody may even have to be fed two teaspoonfuls of something every hour.
('58', 198, 1, 4, 372198) If so he should not be given that thing every half an hour.
('58', 198, 1, 5, 372258) Thus the habit of munching something in between meals is a bad one and is violation of the vow of not indulging the palate.
('58', 198, 1, 6, 372382) One should not even eat a green tamarind.
('58', 198, 1, 7, 372424) But a girl like Anandi may need to eat more often than thrice.
('58', 198, 1, 8, 372487) She ought not to do so just to please herself, but she may eat what is necessary for the sake of her health and as often as necessary.
('58', 198, 1, 9, 372622) Children of the age of Babla may eat four times.
('58', 198, 1, 10, 372671) Of course nobody should swallow in three meals the quantity that he would eat in four meals.
('58', 198, 1, 11, 372764) It may help if the quantity consumed in three meals is divided into four meals, but it would be harmful to eat in three meals the quantity that one might eat in four meals.
('58', 198, 1, 12, 372937) When one has got fever, one should not eat solid food, by which I mean wheat, jowar, bajri, rice, pulses and tubers, that is, articles which contain starch and protein.
('58', 198, 1, 13, 373106) If, however, one feels hungry and passes normal stools, one may drink milk in small quantities.
('58', 198, 1, 14, 373202) Fruit juices may be taken in practically any condition, though even these should not be taken if one has no appetite.
('58', 198, 1, 15, 373320) Anybody who cannot digest jowar and bajri must not eat them.
('58', 198, 1, 16, 373381) Anybody whose body—not palate—demands rice, may eat it.
('58', 198, 1, 17, 373437) For those who are ill, the water in which rice has been boiled sometimes proves the ideal food.
('58', 198, 1, 18, 373533) Ordinarily, rice is not essential for health and, sometimes, even does harm.
('58', 198, 1, 19, 373610) Rice eaters are generally seen to be flabby.
('58', 198, 1, 20, 373655) They have round bellies.
('58', 198, 1, 21, 373680) This is a common sight in Bihar and Madras.
('58', 198, 1, 22, 373724) I hope I have now made myself clear.
('58', 198, 1, 23, 373761) What shall I write concerning the Chharas?
('58', 198, 1, 24, 373804) Our tapashcharya is imperfect.
('58', 198, 1, 25, 373835) Our faith in God is not strong enough.
('58', 198, 1, 26, 373874) We do not look upon the Chharas as our own brothers and sisters.
('58', 198, 1, 27, 373939) We are afraid of them.
('58', 198, 1, 28, 373962) I deserve this charge more than anybody else.
('58', 198, 1, 29, 374008) My shortcomings have taken visible form as the camping of Chharas in the neighbour hood of the Ashram.
('58', 198, 1, 30, 374111) Endure them.
('58', 198, 1, 31, 374124) Please remember that I have not advised a letter of abject supplication to be written to the Collector.
('58', 198, 1, 32, 374228) I had suggested the substance of the draft after careful thought.
('58', 198, 1, 33, 374294) I am, therefore, certainly eager to know what action Mavalankar has taken.
('58', 198, 1, 34, 374369) I hope you yourself had followed my mean ing.
('58', 198, 1, 35, 374415) I see in this situation a severe test of our devotion to dharma.
('58', 198, 1, 36, 374480) From here, I see our dharma
('58', 199, 0, 1, 374508) 200 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('58', 199, 1, 2, 374550) quite clearly.
('58', 199, 1, 3, 374565) Any man or woman, old or young, who has courage and faith in God, should go and live among them, plead with them and, even if they beat him or her, show them the right path.
('58', 199, 1, 4, 374739) We should know how they live.
('58', 199, 1, 5, 374769) If, however, we do not have the necessary strength to do all this, we should think and decide whether we are willing to defend ourselves by fighting the Chharas.
('58', 199, 1, 6, 374931) If we are willing to do that, we should decide whether we should seek the Government’s help and, if not, whether we could engage paid watchmen and from which com munity or class we would select them.
('58', 199, 1, 7, 375131) If, on the other hand, we do not wish to engage such watchmen, we should decide whether we would fight as best as we could, or whether we would prefer not to abandon our path and, though we did not possess sufficient strength to follow it well, we would be content with as much as we could do in that direction.
('58', 199, 1, 8, 375443) I think I have said enough.
('58', 199, 1, 9, 375471) I hope nobody will get scared.
('58', 199, 1, 10, 375502) I have written all this so that people there may think over the problem.
('58', 199, 1, 11, 375575) Prema’s operation must be over.
('58', 199, 1, 12, 375607) BAPU [PS.] Please let me know what Mavalankar has done.
('58', 199, 1, 13, 375663) I am thinking what can be done in that direction.

('58', 201, 1, 2, 377893) 278. INTERVIEW TO DEPUTATION OF ARYA SAMAJ, BOMBAY 1
('58', 201, 2, 3, 377946) December 14, 1932
('58', 201, 3, 4, 377964) In response to ‘namaste’ by the deputation, Mahatmaji welcomed them with a
('58', 201, 4, 5, 378039) He spent an hour and a half in discussing the subject of untouchability from
('58', 201, 5, 6, 378116) Shastraic point of view.
('58', 201, 5, 7, 378141) He said that he was aware of the activities of Arya Samaj in
('58', 201, 6, 8, 378202) this direction, and hoped that Arya Samaj would continue it with more vigour.
('58', 201, 7, 9, 378280) directed that Arya Samaj should do propaganda work by lectures and literature and also
('58', 201, 8, 10, 378367) continue more enthusiastically the constructive work among the untouchables.
('58', 201, 9, 11, 378444) Mahatmaji said that he was fully confident about the success of the Guruvayur
('58', 201, 10, 12, 378522) question from the information received from the workers.
('58', 201, 10, 13, 378579) He said hundreds of
('58', 201, 11, 14, 378599) volunteers had reached Malabar and the work was going on satisfactorily.

('58', 201, 11, 16, 378730) The work of referendum was also going
('58', 201, 12, 17, 378768) on well.
('58', 201, 12, 18, 378777) He showed his indifference towards the mischievous propaganda which some
('58', 201, 13, 19, 378850) of the persons had started by misrepresenting his writings, taking a sentence from
('58', 201, 14, 20, 378933) here and another from there without giving reference to the context.
('58', 201, 15, 21, 379002) On request Mahatmaji selected three books from the big bundle brought by the deputationists and being asked to have a copy of Satyarth Prakash, the ‘Magnum
('58', 201, 16, 22, 379158) Opus of Rishi Dayanand’, he said in reply that he always kept that book with him.
('58', 201, 17, 23, 379240) The Bombay Chronicle, 17 12 1932
('58', 201, 18, 24, 379273) 1 The deputation, which consisted of Dwijendranath, Shivdas Chapsey, Vijayashankerji, Parbhubhai Sharma, Vallabhdas R. Mehta, Jammubhaiji and Shanker Rao, “impressed upon Mahatmaji that it was essential to counteract the propaganda started by the so called sanatanists against the work of the removal of untouchability.
('58', 201, 18, 25, 379593) There was no mention or sanction of so called untouchability in the Vedas and other ancient scriptures of the Hindus.
('58', 201, 18, 26, 379711) The criteria to determine the Chandalas, etc., as prescribed in Manu and other Smritis were in no way applicable to the present so called ‘untouchables’, and Arya Samaj following in the footsteps of Maharshi Dayanand Saraswati had been propagating the message of equality among all human beings.
('58', 201, 18, 27, 380007) In accordance with the mission of Maharshi Dayanand, Arya Samaj was doing the work of removal of untouchability for long, and with more vigour after the epic fast.

('58', 202, 1, 2, 380467) 279. STATEMENT ON UNTOUCHABILITY XII
('58', 202, 2, 3, 380504) December 15, 1932 I thought I had made my position quite clear about the limi tations of the temple entry agitation.
('58', 202, 2, 4, 380621) But I see sanatanist friends are still agitated over a fancied danger which they think sanatan dharma is facing from this agitation.
('58', 202, 2, 5, 380754) I, therefore, summarize below what I have said in published statements and letters to correspondents: 1. The method of fasting is at the present moment confined only to Guruvayur.
('58', 202, 2, 6, 380934) There are historic reasons for the fast from a reformer’s standpoint.
('58', 202, 2, 7, 381004) There was no escape from it.
('58', 202, 2, 8, 381033) Those reasons I know will not be accepted as any justification by the opponents of reform or even by all who believe in temple entry.
('58', 202, 2, 9, 381167) My purpose in referring to it is merely to state the limitations of the fast.
('58', 202, 2, 10, 381245) 2. The fast as contemplated will not be undertaken if the refe rendum goes against the reformers.
('58', 202, 2, 11, 381343) It will be postponed if it is found that the existing law is against reformers and that every effort is made for the necessary legislation and Viceregal sanction has been obtained for the introduction of a permissive Bill, that the Bill cannot go through the Legislature before 2nd January, 1933. 3. I would not be a party to any forcible temple entry in de fiance of the wishes of a majority of worshippers at the respective tem ples and the agitation will be confined only to public temples.
('58', 202, 2, 12, 381837) There fore, the opening of private temples will depend entirely upon their owners and the restrictions applicable to caste Hindus will naturally be applicable to Harijans.
('58', 202, 2, 13, 382009) In my opinion, these limitations ought to satisfy any reasonable Hindu, but I know there is a body of opinion which will not tolerate the opening of any existing Hindu temple to Harijans on the same terms as to other Hindus.
('58', 202, 2, 14, 382234) For such uncompromising opponents, there is no method of conciliation that I can devise short of a programme of new temple building.
('58', 202, 2, 15, 382367) That means a sharp additional division in an already divided society, but I am convinced if the reformers will loyally and honestly abide by the limitations I have suggested, the unreasonable opposition will die for want of support.
('58', 202, 2, 16, 382600) Those who have arrogated to themselves the name sanatan dharma, should not be sur prised or shocked if opponents also derive authority for reform from the same scriptures that the sanatanists profess to believe in.
('58', 202, 2, 17, 382815) There is a growing body of Shastris, well versed in Sanskrit lore, who believe
('58', 203, 0, 1, 382894) 204 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('58', 203, 1, 2, 382936) that it is not only permissible in Hinduism to admit ‘untouch ables’ to public temples, but that it is wrong to prohibit them from offering worship in common with other Hindus at these temples.
('58', 203, 1, 3, 383130) These pundits also believe that there is no such thing as untoucha bility, attaching to birth and incapable of being cured by any penance or purification.
('58', 203, 1, 4, 383285) They do believe in untouchability attaching to acts and occupations, but this is no peculiarity to Hinduism.
('58', 203, 1, 5, 383394) It is common to all religions and is based upon sound hygienic principles.
('58', 203, 1, 6, 383469) I believe, too, that the alarm caused over the proposed legislation is also based on ignorance.
('58', 203, 1, 7, 383565) So far as I understand the proposal, it sim ply amounts to this.
('58', 203, 1, 8, 383630) If a two thirds majority of worshippers at a parti cular temple express their desire through a regular channel devised by the legislature, such temples should be thrown open to Harijans on terms of equality with others.
('58', 203, 1, 9, 383850) In my opinion, the proposal itself is so intrinsically sound that no reasonable person can have anything to say in opposition to it.
('58', 203, 1, 10, 383983) Anyway, let the opponents of reform understand exactly what the reformers seek to achieve.
('58', 203, 1, 11, 384074) As it is, I am sorry to have to observe an agitation against reform being conducted in disregard of facts and that it is being sustained by statements that are contrary to truth and by baseless insinuations and imputations.
('58', 203, 1, 12, 384298) Such methods can do no harm to reform if it is sound in itself, but it hurts Hinduism if the reformers or their opponents resort to methods that are less than fair and just.
('58', 203, 2, 13, 384472) The Hindu, 16 12 1932

('58', 204, 1, 2, 384938) 281. LETTER TO MIRABEHN
('58', 204, 2, 3, 384962) December 15, 1932
('58', 204, 3, 4, 384980) MIRA, Your letter has arrived in due time.
('58', 204, 3, 5, 385023) It is now nearly 4.20 and we have finished the morning prayer.
('58', 204, 3, 6, 385086) Chhaganlal Joshi makes the fourth member of the human family and if we add the feline members, we make seven.
('58', 204, 3, 7, 385196) Only the latter won’t attend the prayers.
('58', 204, 3, 8, 385238) Their recogni tion of kinship is confined to the common board.
('58', 204, 3, 9, 385301) Chhaganlal’s arrival has facilitated despatch of work, but has not reduced my hours of labour.
('58', 204, 3, 10, 385396) It was not expected to.
('58', 204, 3, 11, 385420) Things that must be attended to by me, have to be.
('58', 204, 3, 12, 385471) The pressure must continue at least till 2nd January.
('58', 204, 3, 13, 385525) What is it that prevents the heart from following or co operating with reason?
('58', 204, 3, 14, 385604) Can it be want of faith?
('58', 204, 3, 15, 385629) Though I have not come to any final decision, my opinion tends in that direction.
('58', 204, 3, 16, 385711) Though my reason tells me that there is no need to avoid a snake if I have love in me, it must be my want of faith that prevents my association with him.
('58', 204, 3, 17, 385865) Instances of this character can be multiplied.
('58', 204, 3, 18, 385912) I would like you to make researches in this direction and try to trace the cause of conflict between the heart and reason in every case you can recall.
('58', 204, 3, 19, 386064) By so doing it may be possible for you to make the heart co operative with reason.
('58', 204, 3, 20, 386147) If it is good for me and everybody that I should fast, why should the heart refuse to rejoice?
('58', 204, 3, 21, 386242) The heart does rejoice if I am healthy.
('58', 204, 3, 22, 386282) It is better in certain cases that I should fast than that I should be healthy.
('58', 204, 3, 23, 386362) Reason says so, yet the heart rejects the clear testimony of reason.
('58', 204, 3, 24, 386431) Does it do so for want of faith?
('58', 204, 3, 25, 386464) Or is there here self deception and as a matter of fact reason has not perceived the necessity for fasting as it has for the preservation of health?
('58', 204, 3, 26, 386613) Here I have simply stated the problem for you without presuming to decide.
('58', 204, 3, 27, 386688) I cannot have sufficient data for coming to a decision even if I wanted to come to a decision.
('58', 204, 3, 28, 386783) I must leave this subject at this point for the time being at any rate.
('58', 204, 3, 29, 386855) My weight is now 103. I have reduced the quantity of milk, knocked off bread and increased the quantity of oranges from eight to sixteen.
('58', 204, 3, 30, 386993) Dates too have been dropped for the time being.
('58', 204, 3, 31, 387041) Of milk I am taking just one lb.
('58', 204, 3, 32, 387074) Presently I hope to increase the quantity of milk.
('58', 205, 0, 1, 387125) 206 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('58', 205, 1, 2, 387167) I have sent you Dr. Gour’s book for the information it is likely to contain.
('58', 205, 1, 3, 387244) Justice Amir Ali’s is likely to be a superior book as a historical work.
('58', 205, 1, 4, 387317) I may be mistaken.
('58', 205, 1, 5, 387336) It is useless to appeal The Times of India to publish my state ments 1 in full.

('58', 207, 1, 2, 390764) 284. LETTER TO JAMNALAL BAJAJ
('58', 207, 2, 3, 390794) December 15, 1932
('58', 207, 3, 4, 390812) JAMNALAL, I got your letter.
('58', 207, 3, 5, 390841) I understand what you say regarding Kamal nayan.
('58', 207, 3, 6, 390890) No arrangement can be made for him to stay in Poona.
('58', 207, 3, 7, 390943) I had discussed the matter with Vakil.
('58', 207, 3, 8, 390982) They do not accept a young man of his age, for they simply don’t have the necessary facility for that.
('58', 207, 3, 9, 391085) We shall discuss the matter further when we meet.
('58', 207, 3, 10, 391135) Shri Kateli knew that we had a stock of the swadeshi ink for fountain pen which you wanted, and, therefore, we have sent a bottle of it for you.
('58', 207, 3, 11, 391280) We have quite a large quantity of it.
('58', 207, 3, 12, 391318) The sugar used in the bread made here is probably swadeshi, for very little foreign sugar is available in Poona.
('58', 207, 3, 13, 391431) Even if it is foreign, I would not consider it wrong to eat the bread for that reason, for the sugar is used for preparing yeast.
('58', 207, 3, 14, 391561) That is, it mixes with the other ingredients of yeast and produces a new substance altogether—as two gases combine in a certain proportion and produce water.
('58', 207, 3, 15, 391719) Hence we cannot say that when eating bread we consume two different articles, wheat and sugar.
('58', 207, 3, 16, 391814) Three things are used for preparing yeast—mahura, sugar and salt.
('58', 207, 3, 17, 391880) The mahura is indigenous.
('58', 207, 3, 18, 391906) According to me, therefore, bread is innocent food even for a person who has taken a vow not to eat foreign sugar.
('58', 207, 3, 19, 392021) However, after knowing all these facts it is for you finally to decide what you should do.
('58', 207, 3, 20, 392112) If the chapatis which they prepare here agree with you, I certainly would not press you to eat bread.
('58', 207, 3, 21, 392214) I have received no reply as yet to my request 1 for permission to see you.
('58', 207, 3, 22, 392289) I understand your reason for not going to England just now for an operation.
('58', 207, 3, 23, 392366) Personally, I entertain no such fear at all.
('58', 207, 3, 24, 392411) Thousands of people get discharge from their ears and suffer from no other disease.
('58', 207, 3, 25, 392495) Since the affected parts adjoin the brain, extreme consequences may follow in some cases.
('58', 207, 3, 26, 392585) The possibility may alarm doctors and they, in turn, frighten the patients.
('58', 207, 3, 27, 392661) I would, therefore, willingly rest satisfied with whatever help is availablein India But this discussion is unnece ssary just now.
('58', 207, 3, 28, 392792) After there is a settlement, we shall know what to do.
('58', 207, 4, 29, 392847) 1 Vide “Letter to Home Secretary, Government of Bombay”, 29 11 1932.

('58', 209, 1, 2, 394453) 287. MESSAGE FOR ANTI UNTOUCHABILITY DAY 1
('58', 209, 2, 3, 394496) December 16, 1932 I hope the message of hope born of the movement for the aboli tion of untouchability will penetrate Harijan quarters in every village in India on next Sunday which has been fixed by the Central Board for the removal of untouchability.
('58', 209, 2, 4, 394749) Every Hindu child can do some thing by way of some little service to his or her Harijan brother or sister in this mass movement of self purification.
('58', 209, 2, 5, 394899) I have been listening to discourses of sanatanist friends with respectful attention with a perfectly open mind, and I shall continue to do so as long as they will strive with me with a view to conversion to their interpretation of Hinduism, but the conviction is daily growing upon me that untoucha bility as it is interpreted and practised today has no sanction whatso ever in the Hindu Shastras taken as a whole, as they must be taken.
('58', 209, 2, 6, 395337) There can be no doubt that the present interpretation and practice of untouchability is utterly contrary to every canon of morality.
('58', 209, 2, 7, 395470) When therefore the evil is banished from our midst, it will be the greatest single act of purification in modern times on thepart of caste Hindus.
('58', 209, 2, 8, 395617) I, therefore, hope that there will be full response to the progr amme issued by the Central Board.
('58', 209, 2, 9, 395716) I would invite the sanatani friends not to stand aloof from this movement on the ground that they cannot reconcile themselves to temple entry.
('58', 209, 2, 10, 395859) Service of no human being can be contrary to religious precepts; much less can the service of Harijans be contrary to the Hindu religion which regards them as a part of the Hindu society.
('58', 209, 2, 11, 396047) There are innumerable acts of kindness that they can perform by way of serving the Harijans who are truly children of God forsaken by us.
('58', 209, 2, 12, 396185) I have seen a paragraph in newspapers about the fast of one described as Avadhut Swami.
('58', 209, 2, 13, 396273) It is true that this gentleman wrote to me some letters some months ago.
('58', 209, 2, 14, 396346) They were, like the many letters that I often receive, long, incoherent and irrelevant.
('58', 209, 2, 15, 396434) The impression left on me was that the writer of those letters had lost his balance.
('58', 209, 2, 16, 396519) He said in his letters that he had met me in 1909 or thereabouts.
('58', 209, 2, 17, 396585) I have no re collection of any such meeting, and I wrote to him to that effect.
('58', 209, 2, 18, 396665) He never challenged my denial.
('58', 209, 3, 19, 396696) 1 The day was to be observed on December 18.
('58', 210, 0, 1, 396741) VOL. 58 : 16 NOVEMBER, 1932 14 JANUARY, 1933 211
('58', 210, 1, 2, 396790) I have no knowledge of the notice referred to in the Press message as having been received from him when he is supposed to have met me.
('58', 210, 1, 3, 396926) At that time years ago, there was no question of fast either.
('58', 210, 1, 4, 396988) Someone telegraphed me a few days ago saying that Avadhut Swami was fasting and would continue to do so, unless I gave up anti untouchability propaganda.
('58', 210, 1, 5, 397142) I wired to the sender of the telegram saying that he should wean the Swami from the fast.
('58', 210, 1, 6, 397232) The movement that I hold as a part of my living faith cannot be abandoned even if a million people fast to make me give it up.
('58', 210, 1, 7, 397359) To everyone the living faith comes from God, and God alone can turn him from it.
('58', 210, 2, 8, 397440) The Bombay Chronicle, 17 12 1932

('58', 214, 6, 11, 404687) I must say what I hold to be good and true, irrespective of consequence, and so should every responsible Hindu.
('58', 214, 6, 12, 404799) I hope that a humble man does not cease to be humble when he gives expression to his innermost thoughts which he
('58', 214, 7, 13, 404912) 1 Dated December 11, 1932. It read: “.
('58', 214, 7, 14, 404951) I had an interview with Dewan Bahadur T. R. Ramachandra Ayyar last month when I found him in a fairly reasonable frame of mind towards the movement.
('58', 214, 7, 15, 405100) I again met him this morning and asked him why he had changed his mind.
('58', 214, 7, 16, 405172) He said it was Gandhiji’s uncompromising attitude in the matter that had made him also uncompromising.
('58', 214, 7, 17, 405275) Previously when Mr. K. Bhashyam and other leaders in Madras had approached him, what they proposed was, what he regarded as a compromise, viz., to admit the Harijans as far as the Dhwaja Sthambha, i.e., to admit them within the temple, but in the outer round,.
('58', 214, 7, 18, 405536) He was also agreeable to admit Harijans into the inner round once or twice such as on Ekadasi days.
('58', 214, 7, 19, 405636) “Now in view of Gandhiji’s demand that they should be treated absolutely on the same terms as the higher castes, which he regards as most uncompromising he also assumes an equally uncompromising position and leads a movement organizing the orthodox with the support of all the Mathadhipatis.
('58', 214, 7, 20, 405928) “What has given him greater affront was Gandhiji’s statement that it was the caste Hindus who were the sinners and were to perform prayashchitta and not the Harijans.
('58', 214, 7, 21, 406095) He was very much excited over the idea that Gandhiji should have asked pious people like him to perform prayashchitta in their old age for their pious past conduct.
('58', 214, 7, 22, 406260) He felt that in dictating like this Gandhiji’s usual humility had entirely deserted him and made him an avatar of haughtiness .
('58', 214, 7, 23, 406388) .” (S.N. 18690).
('58', 215, 0, 1, 406405) 216 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('58', 215, 1, 2, 406447) holds to be true.
('58', 215, 1, 3, 406465) I have judged no individual in saying that cast Hindus as such are sinners before God and man in their treatment of Harijans.
('58', 215, 1, 4, 406591) An individual who is most pious may have to perform prayashchitta for the sin of the class to which he belongs.
('58', 215, 1, 5, 406703) I see no dictation, either, in stating the truth andit was said by me in 1915 and was repeated since from a thousand platforms.

('58', 215, 5, 10, 407023) December 16, 1932
('58', 215, 6, 11, 407041) DEAR FRIEND, I thank you for your letter of the 13th instant.
('58', 215, 6, 12, 407103) You may perhaps know that some Shastris from Pandharpur have had long discussions with me, at the end of which we agreed that on the 23rd instant there should be a discussion between them and those Shastris who generally support the view I have taken.
('58', 215, 6, 13, 407355) I therefore think that there will be a discussion on the 23rd and I suggest that the Shastris whom you have in mind should also take part in the discussion.
('58', 215, 6, 14, 407512) Personally, I do not think that any terms need be previously fixed, but if it is necessary, they can be fixed on the 23rd, and if a chairman is considered nece ssary, one could be appointed from those Shastris who will be present on the 23rd.
('58', 215, 6, 15, 407755) Acharya Dhruva will reach Poona in any case on the evening of the 22nd, and he will be available so long as the discussions last.
('58', 215, 6, 16, 407885) My own object in listening to such discussions is to allow my mind and heart to be acted upon, and if I discover a flaw in the attitude I have hitherto held, I should have no difficulty in owning my mistake and retracing my steps.
('58', 215, 6, 17, 408116) Whether a discussion induces a change in my attitude or not, a friendly conversation between Shastris representing different views cannot but do good and result in remov ing bitterness.
('58', 215, 6, 18, 408302) I quite agree with you that the number of those taking part in the discussion should not be more than seven on either side.
('58', 215, 6, 19, 408426) I do not at all anticipate that the discussion to be started on the 23rd can go on for more than two or, at the outside, three days,

('58', 216, 1, 2, 408608) three hours being devoted each day.
('58', 216, 1, 3, 408644) There is therefore no occasion just now to think of the 2nd of January next.

('58', 217, 5, 10, 410012) 296. LETTER TO NARANDAS GANDHI
('58', 217, 6, 11, 410043) December 16, 1932
('58', 217, 7, 12, 410061) NARANDAS, I got your postcard.
('58', 217, 7, 13, 410092) I hope Premabehn did not suffer much after the operation.
('58', 217, 7, 14, 410150) At the time of the operation one is not conscious and does not feel the pain, but very often the patient suffers after wards.
('58', 217, 7, 15, 410276) I hope that did not happen in this case.
('58', 217, 7, 16, 410317) It was in order to save a day that I wrote directly to Mavalankar yesterday regarding the problem of the Chharas.
('58', 217, 7, 17, 410431) Just now I asked Chhaganlal the name of Liladhar’s father, and he tells me that it is not our practice in the Ashram to note in the register the full names of the inmates.
('58', 217, 7, 18, 410603) Only the name by which a person is generally known is recorded.
('58', 217, 7, 19, 410667) If this is the general practice, or even if it happens only in exceptional cases, it should be imme diately changed.
('58', 217, 7, 20, 410784) For, if the full names are not recorded, we may sometimes find ourselves in a difficult situation.
('58', 217, 7, 21, 410883) When a name is first entered in the register, full particulars including the address should be recorded.
('58', 217, 7, 22, 410988) Even when a child’s name is entered, the full name should be written down.
('58', 217, 7, 23, 411063) The last place where the person lived before joining the Ashram should be mentioned in brackets.
('58', 217, 7, 24, 411160) This is how I learnt to keep registers.
('58', 217, 7, 25, 411200) If you look into the old registers, you will find in them all such information.
('58', 217, 7, 26, 411280) You should, therefore, examine the whole record and, wherever the names are incomplete, write them in full.

('58', 219, 2, 3, 412711) December 17, 1932
('58', 219, 3, 4, 412729) DEAR DR.
('58', 219, 3, 5, 412738) DATTA, I was delighted to have your letter, giving me the only thing you could properly give in my present condition.
('58', 219, 3, 6, 412856) In discovering the use of Indian words among the Gypsies, President Masaryk and you have perhaps made a discovery of great value.
('58', 219, 3, 7, 412986) How nice it would be if some painstaking and accurate scholar could follow up your dis covery and ascertain whether the few common words that you dis covered were a mere accident or whether they are evidence of a recent common origin or of intimate intercourse, or may it be that the Gy psies are a set of universalists for whom the whole world is their coun try?
('58', 219, 3, 8, 413350) The information you give about the old President is also very instructive.
('58', 219, 3, 9, 413425) I wish that we could emulate his energy and vigour.
('58', 219, 3, 10, 413477) Mahadev is with me, Devdas sees me fairly often, and Pyarelal was able to see me practically only during the fast.
('58', 219, 3, 11, 413592) Please send our love to Mrs. Datta and your boy.
('58', 219, 3, 12, 413641) I can feel your difficulties in your new post, but God will give you strength to grapple with them.
('58', 219, 3, 13, 413741) All this however is preface to the question I want to ask you: “What are your boys doing for the Harijans ?”
('58', 219, 4, 14, 413850) Yours sincerely, SJT.
('58', 219, 4, 15, 413872) S.K. DATTA PRINCIPAL, FORMAN CHRISTIAN COLLEGE LAHORE

('58', 220, 1, 2, 414950) 299. LETTER TO DUNICHAND 1
('58', 220, 2, 3, 414977) December 17, 1932
('58', 220, 3, 4, 414995) DEAR LALA DUNICHAND, You have done well according to your wont in writing to me on the burning question.
('58', 220, 3, 5, 415100) I think you are quite right in rejecting the evidence of the inner urge.
('58', 220, 3, 6, 415173) I was bound to meet that statement, as I believe it to be true.
('58', 220, 3, 7, 415237) But the public has not only the right but [it is] its duty to examine the question dispassionately and from a common sense point of view.
('58', 220, 3, 8, 415375) I have myself endeavoured therefore to reason out the justification for the steps I have taken and those that are contemplated.
('58', 220, 3, 9, 415503) Therefore you do not want me to reiterate the argument I have publicly advanced in my own statements in justification.
('58', 220, 3, 10, 415622) One issue however I have not dealt with publicly.
('58', 220, 3, 11, 415672) You are quite right in saying that my body is not my own, but that it belongs to the nation.
('58', 220, 3, 12, 415765) You will however recognize that it also belongs to God, or rather, it belongs to the nation because it belongs to God.
('58', 220, 3, 13, 415884) And here I have got to state that it is God who is dealing with this body, and He will keep it intact against the whole world if He wants to use it for a service, great or small, and the whole world will not be able to keep it if God decides to take it away.
('58', 220, 3, 14, 416143) Let us therefore wait upon Him and trust that whatever He does will be for our good.
('58', 220, 4, 15, 416228) Yours sincerely, SJT.
('58', 220, 4, 16, 416250) LALA DUNI CHAND, B.A. KRIPA NIVAS AMBALA CITY
('58', 220, 5, 17, 416296) From a microfilm: S.N. 18735
('58', 220, 6, 18, 416325) 1 The letter was in reply to the addressee’s of December 11, 1932, requesting Gandhiji not to go on fast from January 2, 1933 (S.N. 18689).
('58', 221, 0, 1, 416465) 222 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('58', 221, 1, 2, 416507) 300. LETTER TO N. SUBRAHMANYA AIYAR 1
('58', 221, 2, 3, 416545) December 17, 1932
('58', 221, 3, 4, 416563) DEAR FRIEND, I have your letter 2. Do you not remember the saying of a wise and learned man that the things you cannot say and intelligibly explain well inside of an hour are not worth saying or explaining?
('58', 221, 3, 5, 416770) But I promised you full one hour.
('58', 221, 3, 6, 416804) You can still take that hour if that will satisfy you.
('58', 221, 3, 7, 416859) Here are my answers to your questions: 1. A Hindu temple is one built by Hindus for worship by Hindus in accordance with the requirements of Hinduism.
('58', 221, 3, 8, 417010) 2. There is no such thing as Indian caste system in Hinduism, but there is varnashrama.
('58', 221, 3, 9, 417098) And varna is wholly different from the current caste.
('58', 221, 3, 10, 417152) 3. Custom that is not repugnant to the moral sense must be recognized by courts of law.
('58', 221, 3, 11, 417240) 4. Those who want to enforce a custom have to show that it has been in vogue for a long time and that it is not in conflict with the moral sense, but the burden may be shifted if a custom already recog nized is challenged.
('58', 221, 3, 12, 417463) 5. A self respecting court will not be bullied into giving decisions by agitations, but it would be governed by well recognized rules.
('58', 221, 3, 13, 417598) 6. The question is answered in No.
('58', 221, 3, 14, 417633) 1. 7. When the religious texts differ, evidence as to usage will be one of the determining factors.
('58', 221, 3, 15, 417733) 8. Private property lawfully acquired is entitled to protection.
('58', 221, 3, 16, 417798) 9. Communal property is also entitled to protection if communal ownership is not in conflict with the common weal.
('58', 221, 3, 17, 417913) 10. A private temple is entitled to the same protection as pri vate property.
('58', 221, 3, 18, 417991) 11. I am not aware of anybody having agitated for confis cation of temples
('58', 221, 4, 19, 418066) 1 Senior Dewan Peishkar, Travancore 2 Dated December 10, 1932 (S.N. 18687)
('58', 222, 0, 1, 418141) VOL. 58 : 16 NOVEMBER, 1932 14 JANUARY, 1933 223
('58', 222, 1, 2, 418190) 12. Simple suicide is an offence under the present Law as I have been told.
('58', 222, 1, 3, 418266) 13. If Gandhi took up his stand at the Viceregal gateway and threatened to fast even for one day unless the British Government withdrew from the country, the Government would be justly entitled to arrest him and imprison him till he came to his senses.
('58', 222, 1, 4, 418519) 14. The contemplated fast does not make it impossible for anybody to deal with the temple entry question in a fearless and rea sonable manner; nor do I see any sign that the opponents are in any way deterred from their purpose, and I think that they are quite right in ignoring the contemplated fast.
('58', 222, 1, 5, 418820) 15. I am sorry to have to remark that this question 1 is packed with ignorance of the true situation and is outside my limits.
('58', 222, 1, 6, 418947) Although I have, out of regard for you, answered your questions, you will permit me to say that many of them are argumen tative and take no note of the existing situation, and some of them are based upon mere assumptions.
('58', 222, 1, 7, 419169) It has filled me with sorrow to discover that learned men have imagined a woeful state of things to exist and have thrown themselves into rage over the imaginary woe.
('58', 222, 2, 8, 419336) Yours sincerely, SJT.
