('58', 222, 3, 10, 419458) From a microfilm: S.N. 18731
('58', 222, 4, 11, 419487) 1 It read: “15. Is not this movement—against which orthodox opposition is only being just mobilized and is bound to rise to a proportion which neither the Government nor its present engineers have any idea of, and started at a stage of India’s death and religious decline when faith in temples is steadily waning and is absolutely non existent among the people who are projecting and conducting this movement and who are doing so more as a political stunt against the Government for winning swaraj than as a measure of religious catholicity—calculated to create increasing discord in the country, rioting and even bloodshed—and to indefinitely postpone the prospect of swaraj which is the common aim of all?”
('58', 223, 0, 1, 420196) 224 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('58', 223, 1, 2, 420238) 301. LETTER TO M. M. ANANTA RAU
('58', 223, 2, 3, 420270) December 17, 1932
('58', 223, 3, 4, 420288) DEAR FRIEND,
('58', 223, 4, 5, 420301) I have your letter 1. You will please pardon me for the frankness with which I propose to discuss it in the hope that it may open your eyes to the untenability of the position you have taken up and which you say represents orthodox opinion.
('58', 223, 4, 6, 420542) Before I do that, let me ask why your letter paper is so grotes que.
('58', 223, 4, 7, 420611) It cannot add dignity to the sanatan dharma by having your letter paper printed with borders as on an address paper, still less to have a portrait of the agent surrounded by other figures.
('58', 223, 4, 8, 420800) Adver tisers do sometimes adopt ornamentation for their letter paper, but I have never seen anything so wholly inartistic as the paper which you are using.
('58', 223, 4, 9, 420956) I restrained myself twice against drawing your attention to the incongruity of a religious agency using ornamentation, and that, too, utterly inartistic, but though my claim may be rejected, I am or am trying to be a humble representative of sanatan dharma, and there fore, whenever anything unbecoming is done in the name of that dharma, it pains me deeply.
('58', 223, 4, 10, 421315) So much by way of preface.
('58', 223, 4, 11, 421342) Now, regarding the contents of your letter.
('58', 223, 4, 12, 421386) Surely, it ought to be easy for you to see that since you admit that untouchability is quite contrary to the divine fact of oneness of all life, the only way to realize that oneness 2 is to have as little differentiation as possible, and wherever it exists, it should be accepted as an evil to be removed at the first opportunity.
('58', 223, 4, 13, 421717) There is no such difficulty or impossibility about the removal of untouchability as we practise it today.
('58', 223, 4, 14, 421823) You say that untouchability is based on “physical, moral and mental purity”, and you have stated as if it was a self proved proposition.
('58', 223, 4, 15, 421960) I find it most difficult to understand your statement so utterly at variance with daily experience.
('58', 223, 4, 16, 422060) To claim permanence for untouchability, as you evidently claim for it, is to indefinitely postpone realization of oneness, unless you were to postulate that that realization is to come to humanity from outside sources.
('58', 223, 4, 17, 422279) But I have never heard anybody saying so; on the contrary, there is complete agreement that realization of oneness can

('58', 236, 1, 2, 443924) 325. LETTER TO R. B. TALEGAONKAR
('58', 236, 2, 3, 443957) December 19, 1932
('58', 236, 3, 4, 443975) DEAR FRIEND, Here are answers to the questions you left 1 with me: 1.The reformer has to convert the people by patience, gentleness and purity of character.
('58', 236, 3, 5, 444132) My fast can only prepare the ground for the reformer’s work and make the reformer also more active than before in the execution of his mission.
('58', 236, 3, 6, 444276) 2. I would just as soon fast in respect of Dakornath Temple 2 as Guruvayur if the call came.
('58', 236, 3, 7, 444369) I had no notion that I should have to contemplate a fast regarding Guruvayur, as everyone knows it came to me; but it would be wrong on my part to tack on other temples.
('58', 236, 3, 8, 444539) Nevertheless, there are many other ways in which the movement for opening other temples is being, and should be, carried on.
('58', 236, 3, 9, 444664) 3. If I refuse to be party to conditional temple entry by Harijans, it is not because I feel less for the cow, but because it is the best way of weaning Harijans from taking beef.
('58', 236, 3, 10, 444844) In matters of religion, there should be no bargaining.
('58', 236, 3, 11, 444899) Every Harijan knows that one of the essential conditions of being a good Hindu is to abstain from taking beef or carrion.
('58', 236, 3, 12, 445021) Therefore my formula is that those Harijans who are in the habit of taking beef or carrion should be induced to give it up, irrespective of whether the temples are opened to them or not, purely on the ground that beef and carrion eating is prohibited in Hinduism.
('58', 236, 3, 13, 445285) Similarly temples should be opened unconditionally.
('58', 236, 3, 14, 445337) Even as it is the duty of Harijans to abstain from beef and carrion without asking for or receiving any consideration therefor, so is it the duty of caste Hindus, irrespective of consideration, to throw open the doors of tem ples to Harijans without claiming any consideration.
('58', 236, 3, 15, 445615) Even today there is no inquisition held as to the Hindu practice of temple goers.
('58', 236, 3, 16, 445697) Very properly it is taken for granted that temple goers conform to the rules applicable to them regarding temple entry.
('58', 236, 3, 17, 445817) So must we expect Harijans to do.
('58', 236, 3, 18, 445851) 4. There are many courses that we can adopt in order to ensure success in a movement.
('58', 236, 3, 19, 445937) There are some courses, however, which are
('58', 236, 4, 20, 445980) 1 On December 16, 1932 (S.N. 18722) 2 In Gujarat
('58', 237, 0, 1, 446029) 238 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('58', 237, 1, 2, 446071) beyond our capacity to adopt.
('58', 237, 1, 3, 446101) My release is a course which it is beyond my capacity to adopt.
('58', 237, 1, 4, 446165) 5. To seek to abolish untouchability amongst untouchables before caste Hindus abolish untouchability with reference to untou chables is like an attempt to twist a rope of sand foredoomed to fail ure.
('58', 237, 1, 5, 446365) When caste Hindus really abolish untouchability, the other will crumble to pieces practically without an effort.
('58', 237, 1, 6, 446478) 6. In my opinion, seeing that the society now formed is one to do penance or to discharge an obligation due to Harijans, it should be composed of penitents or debtors, but there should be a corres ponding committee or society of creditors, that is Harijans, whose wishes should be ascertained from time to time.
('58', 237, 1, 7, 446790) 7. No law will abolish untouchability before caste Hindus are ready to do so.
('58', 237, 1, 8, 446868) Law can only help them when they need its assistance.
('58', 237, 1, 9, 446922) But it can never compel them.
('58', 237, 1, 10, 446952) 8. In Hinduism, and for that matter in every religion, every activity of a religious man is governed by his religion.
('58', 237, 1, 11, 447070) A man cannot be religious that is guided by his moral and spiritual sense in some activities and not in others.
('58', 237, 1, 12, 447182) When there is religion about a person, it pervades his whole being.
('58', 237, 1, 13, 447250) 9. All the three statements 1 are not inconsistent with one another, but they represent the same truth.
('58', 237, 1, 14, 447354) Without Guruvayur there will be no Kelappan fasting, without Kelappan there would have been no inspiration for me to fast for Guruvayur.
('58', 237, 1, 15, 447491) Yours sincerely, SJT.
('58', 237, 1, 16, 447513) R. B. TALEGAONKAR 1034 RAVIWAR PETH, POONA CITY
('58', 237, 2, 17, 447561) From a microfilm: S.N. 18722

('58', 238, 8, 23, 449409) December 19, 1932 It is true that I refused to eat eggs.
('58', 238, 8, 24, 449466) Still I believe that cod liver oil is objectionable, milk is less objectionable than cod liver oil and unfertilized eggs are less objectionable than either.
('58', 238, 8, 25, 449623) However, people have become accustomed to cod liver oil but not to eggs, and so even unfertilized eggs are regarded as objectionable.
('58', 238, 8, 26, 449757) In the statement: [“And if any man will sue thee at the law] and take away thy coat, let him have thy cloak also”, 2 it is understood
('58', 238, 9, 27, 449891) 1 On December 14, 1932; vide “Interview to Deputation of Arya Samaj, Bombay”, 14 12 1932. 2 St. Matthew, v.

('58', 239, 1, 2, 450041) that the man who asks for your coat is a deserving person.
('58', 239, 1, 3, 450100) But the statement also means that, if anybody tries to rob us of a thing and if it is not our duty to resist him, it would be better to let him take more than he wished.
('58', 239, 1, 4, 450270) The golden rule behind this precept is that of non possession.
('58', 239, 1, 5, 450333) Nobody can practise it to perfection.
('58', 239, 1, 6, 450371) If, however, wehave understood it fully, we should try to follow it more and more in our lives to the extent that we can.

('58', 247, 1, 2, 462865) 345. LETTER TO C. F. ANDREWS
('58', 247, 2, 3, 462894) December 20, 1932
('58', 247, 3, 4, 462912) MY DEAR CHARLIE, I have your letter 1 posted days after it was written, and I have your two dear cables.
('58', 247, 3, 5, 463017) I was wondering whether the later developments in the anti untouchability campaign including the prospective fast were thoroughly understood by you.
('58', 247, 3, 6, 463166) Your wires show that you have understood them fully, and I am so glad, for, whereas the fast in connection with British decision was appreciated by many, the one contemplated to take place on the 2nd January next is misunderstood by many, and I am afraid that you might not understand it at all, whereas to me the necessity is clearer than when I fasted about the British decision.
('58', 247, 3, 7, 463548) The British decision was a political issue, though with me it had a deeply religious significance.
('58', 247, 3, 8, 463647) In the present instance, it is a purely religious issue.
('58', 247, 3, 9, 463704) I have given many explanations in defence of it.
('58', 247, 3, 10, 463753) All of them put together fall far short of what I feel about it, but what, I have no adequate language to express.
('58', 247, 3, 11, 463868) Of course, for me per sonally, it transcends reason, because I feel it to be a clear call from God.
('58', 247, 3, 12, 463968) My position is that there is nothing just now that I am doing of my own accord.
('58', 247, 3, 13, 464048) He guides me from moment to moment.
('58', 247, 3, 14, 464084) This is a thing which you cannot make other people believe, and it would be quite proper for them to reject such testimony.
('58', 247, 3, 15, 464208) That has happened before now.
('58', 247, 3, 16, 464238) That which was claimed as the voice of God proved to be the prompting of the Devil.
('58', 247, 3, 17, 464322) What it is in my case will be partly judged by results and partly after my death, never wholly in any case and at any time except by God.
('58', 247, 3, 18, 464460) After all, the intention behind an act is the final criterion, and that God alone can know, not even the author of the intention.
('58', 247, 3, 19, 464590) There is no knowing whether the fast will have to be taken on the 2nd January.
('58', 247, 3, 20, 464669) It will depend upon the legal difficulty.
('58', 247, 3, 21, 464711) Yes, I read your book What I Owe to Christ immediately I got it.
('58', 247, 3, 22, 464776) Both Vallabhbhai and Mahadev have glanced through it.
('58', 247, 3, 23, 464830) Mahadev had not the time to go through it fully.
('58', 247, 3, 24, 464879) The opening chapters are very good indeed.
('58', 247, 3, 25, 464922) All the chapters are a great help to a struggling soul.
('58', 247, 4, 26, 464978) 1 The reference presumably is to addressee’s letter of November 10, 1932; vide Appendix “Extract from Letter from C. F. Andrews”, 10 11 1932.
('58', 248, 0, 1, 465120) VOL. 58 : 16 NOVEMBER, 1932 14 JANUARY, 1933 249
('58', 248, 1, 2, 465169) They reveal you as nothing else that you have written can do, but there was a chapter in it which as I read I criticized and I thought I had written to you about it, but evidently I have not.
('58', 248, 1, 3, 465361) I should have to look at the book again in order to be able to recall the chapter and the subject.
('58', 248, 1, 4, 465460) I could do so without much trouble, and if I can find a few spare moments, I will look it up and give you my criticism.
('58', 248, 1, 5, 465580) I shall await copy that you promise of Gurudev’s thoughts on his reading your book.
('58', 248, 1, 6, 465664) I hope that you got my cable already in answer to yours from Birmingham.
('58', 248, 1, 7, 465737) I am quite clear that your presence is most useful there, and you are not to have anxiety complex if I have to fast.
('58', 248, 1, 8, 465854) You at least will have no difficulty in believing that if I enter upon the fast, it would be by God’s will, and He will keep me intact if He has more service to take through this body.

('58', 254, 8, 20, 476443) You are under the vow to remain absolutely peaceful and non violent.

('58', 254, 8, 27, 476846) However, what I fear is that I am not likely to succeed in explaining to people my ideas.

('58', 262, 5, 10, 491214) 365. LETTER TO P. K. MATHEW
('58', 262, 6, 11, 491242) December 22, 1932
('58', 262, 7, 12, 491260) DEAR FRIEND, I thank you for your letter 1. I do not regard the Pulayas and the others as aborigines, and so far as I am aware Hinduism regards them as Hindus.
('58', 262, 7, 13, 491420) That in spite of their being Hindus, they seem tobe a class apart is the tragedy of Hinduism.
('58', 262, 7, 14, 491514) You will not quote school histories or any historical text books in order to show that they are not Hindus but please understand the formula under which the temple entry movement is being conducted.
('58', 262, 7, 15, 491713) It is the caste Hindus who have to do an act of reparation by throwing open the doors of Hindu temples to those who are regarded as untouchables though still part of Hindu society.
('58', 262, 7, 16, 491894) If Pulayas are not Hindus they will never enter Hindu temples.
('58', 262, 7, 17, 491957) I quite agree with you that what is needed is a change of heart on the part of caste Hindus.
('58', 262, 7, 18, 492050) Temple entry would be one of the signs of that change of heart.
('58', 262, 7, 19, 492114) If, as you say, it is quite possible that “these reformers care little for religion and temples”, might it not be said with a little more truth that it is equally possible that these reformers do care for Hindu religion and temples?
('58', 262, 7, 20, 492347) Seeing that they are working for temple entry, is not the presumption in their favour till the con trary is proved?
('58', 262, 7, 21, 492463) It would be proper to say that those who take no part in the movement, either for or against, care little for religion and temples.
('58', 262, 7, 22, 492595) If the reformers take up the attitude of touch me not in their daily life whilst they advocate temple entry, their advocacy is certainly hypocritical.
('58', 262, 7, 23, 492746) But there again the evidence is contrary to what you
('58', 262, 8, 24, 492799) 1 Dated December 17, 1932 in which, dissuading Gandhiji from his fast, the addressee had said that Pulayas and others were aborigines “who were in India long before the Aryan invasion and were never amalgamated into Hindu religion or society”.
('58', 263, 0, 1, 493043) 264 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('58', 263, 1, 2, 493085) think to be the attitude of “many a present day reformer”.
('58', 263, 1, 3, 493144) Believe me that I would not risk my life “for achieving a sham”.
('58', 263, 1, 4, 493209) On the con trary I am trying to achieve on behalf of Harijans a most subs tantial thing from a religious standpoint.

('58', 271, 5, 8, 505619) 381. FRAGMENT OF LETTER TO KHORSHED NAOROJI 1
('58', 271, 6, 9, 505665) December 23, 1932 Why do you think that my fast was due to disappointment?
('58', 271, 6, 10, 505740) On the contrary it sprang from hope eternal.
('58', 271, 6, 11, 505785) Fasting is as necessary for life as eating.
('58', 271, 6, 12, 505829) It is a necessary part of prayer.
('58', 271, 6, 13, 505863) We serve as well by dying as by living.
('58', 271, 6, 14, 505903) But it is the privilege of the few to have to fast.
('58', 271, 6, 15, 505955) Needless to say I write of spiritual fasts.
('58', 271, 6, 16, 505999) I know that fasting may come also from despair.
('58', 271, 6, 17, 506047) Then it is rank suicide.
('58', 271, 6, 18, 506072) I should defend my fast against such a charge.
('58', 271, 6, 19, 506119) For me it has always been a process of penance and purification.
('58', 271, 6, 20, 506184) The fast of 1921 was not born of despair.
('58', 271, 6, 21, 506226) The basis of all penitential fasts has always been faith in mankind, God and oneself.
('58', 271, 6, 22, 506312) It gives an inward joy that sustains one.
('58', 271, 6, 23, 506354) I therefore want you to share with me the joy of it.
('58', 271, 6, 24, 506407) I hope you have understood my argument.
('58', 271, 6, 25, 506447) Of course you know that there is no certainty about the 2nd January fast.
('58', 271, 6, 26, 506521) It may have to be postponed.
('58', 271, 7, 27, 506550) Mahadevbhaini Diary, Vol. II, pp.
('58', 271, 8, 28, 506584) 1 Mahadev Desai explains: “Khorshed’s sad letter came yesterday.
('58', 271, 8, 29, 506649) ‘Are you going to fast because you are disappointed?
('58', 271, 8, 30, 506702) Have you been disappointed in us?
('58', 271, 8, 31, 506736) I gave up my artistic aptitude on the altar of service just for your sake and your cause.
('58', 271, 8, 32, 506826) Why are you still disappointed?’ “Bapu telegraphed to her.

('58', 272, 6, 12, 507539) December 23, 1932

('58', 279, 0, 1, 517203) 280 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('58', 279, 1, 2, 517245) to by you, 1 and even if I had, I would not find the time to study it, nor is it necessary, because of the way I look at the whole question.
('58', 279, 1, 3, 517386) Whilst I believe in all the Hindu Shastras as such, I am guided by one supreme canon of interpretation provided in the Shastras them selves.
('58', 279, 1, 4, 517527) It is this.
('58', 279, 1, 5, 517539) Every rule and every interpretation thereof that is inconsistent with truth or morality (one and the same thing) is to be rejected.
('58', 279, 1, 6, 517671) Without some such canon in the midst of a multitude of texts and interpretations a man in the street would feel utterly helpless.
('58', 279, 1, 7, 517801) As a firm believer in the necessity of temples, I have held the opinion that public temples, except when they are designed for only particular sects, should be open to all Hindus and therefore to Harijans.
('58', 279, 1, 8, 518007) If your application of the law of karma was to hold good, sacrifice becomes a meaningless term and help given by one person to another a purely criminal act.
('58', 279, 1, 9, 518165) If an untouchable, assuming that he is so by reason of his past actions, may not be helped out of his degraded position, why should other people suffering from distress be helped?
('58', 279, 1, 10, 518345) And since I deny divine authority for rules that are inconsistent with truth, I easily come to the conclusion that the disabilities that Harijans are labouring under were imposed upon them by caste Hindus.
('58', 279, 1, 11, 518551) Hence I regard the latter as debtors.
('58', 279, 1, 12, 518589) You ask whether I believe in castes.
('58', 279, 1, 13, 518626) My answer is “No”, but I do believe in varnashrama—a totally different institution from the modern castes.
('58', 279, 2, 14, 518733) Yours sincerely, SJT.

('58', 282, 1, 2, 523126) 401. LETTER TO M. G. BHANDARI
('58', 282, 2, 3, 523156) December 24, 1932
('58', 282, 3, 4, 523174) DEAR MAJOR BHANDARI, Mahadev has told me all about what you felt over yesterday’s gathering.
('58', 282, 3, 5, 523267) I tried my utmost to keep the numbers inside of 25, but it was impossible to prevent the Shastris who had come from surroun ding districts and they belonged to the sanatanist school and therefore I had to walk warily.
('58', 282, 3, 6, 523485) I had hoped that today would be the last day but I find that I have to prolong the period.
('58', 282, 3, 7, 523576) They are coming on Monday.
('58', 282, 3, 8, 523603) It taxed all my strength and tact to keep the number inside of 25 as I had promised.
('58', 282, 3, 9, 523688) I shall try to keep it at that on Monday also and thereafter.
('58', 282, 3, 10, 523750) But I can make no promise.
('58', 282, 3, 11, 523777) I am fully aware that you have to act under instructions.
('58', 282, 3, 12, 523835) But they should not be inconsistent with the orders 1 of the Government of India.
('58', 282, 3, 13, 523917) According to my reading of those orders, the number of visitors has been left open, to be regulated by me.
('58', 282, 3, 14, 524024) I have been endeavouring to the utmost of my ability to suit your convenience both as to number and time, but occasions arise when it is impossible for me to restrict the number as you would wish.
('58', 282, 3, 15, 524221) If therefore it is necessary for you to refer the matter to higher autho rity, you will please do so and receive instructions as to the meeting on Monday and thereafter.
('58', 282, 3, 16, 524391) As the 2nd of January approaches, I know that the pressure is bound to increase.
('58', 282, 3, 17, 524472) I would therefore like a fairly free hand leaving me always to realize that I am a prisoner and therefore may not arrange things as if I have no restrictions to submit to.
('58', 282, 3, 18, 524644) But I would like you and the Government to feel with me that I can consult the convenience of the administration only so far as not to inter fere with the progress of the movement in furtherance of which extraordinary facilities have been given to me.
('58', 282, 4, 19, 524896) Yours sincerely,
('58', 282, 5, 20, 524913) M. K. GANDHI

('58', 283, 2, 3, 525192) December 24, 1932
('58', 283, 3, 4, 525210) NARANDAS, I got your mail.
('58', 283, 3, 5, 525237) I understand your point of view regarding Narayanappa.
('58', 283, 3, 6, 525292) I cannot take the step about the Chharas which I wish to from here before I hear from Mavalankar.
('58', 283, 4, 7, 525390) I do not know which ideas of Ramdas, Surendra is referring to.
('58', 283, 4, 8, 525453) Tara and Vasumati are at Thana.
('58', 283, 4, 9, 525485) From this, I infer that Maha lakshmi also must be there.
('58', 283, 4, 10, 525542) Do you get any news about Gangabehn?
('58', 283, 4, 11, 525579) I feel a little afraid about the consequences of Prema’s having left her bed.
('58', 283, 4, 12, 525657) If she does not exercise self control, not about food but about speaking, I am sure she will harm herself.
('58', 283, 4, 13, 525764) I do not know how to put some check on her in regard to what she writes in her letters.
('58', 283, 4, 14, 525852) One way is that you should stop sending me letters written by her in excite ment.
('58', 283, 4, 15, 525934) The last letter contained nothing but bitter criticism of Chhaganlal.
('58', 283, 4, 16, 526004) 2 I would never keep such a letter from him, and so I read out to him the whole of it.
('58', 283, 4, 17, 526091) The letter has had no effect on him, since he knows nothing about the allegations which Prema has made against him.
('58', 283, 4, 18, 526207) His only reply, therefore, is to endure in silence.
('58', 283, 5, 19, 526259) From a microfilm of the Gujarati: M.M. U./I. Also C.W. 8287. Courtesy: Narandas Gandhi

('58', 284, 1, 2, 527004) tatingly withdrew my letter and apologized.
('58', 284, 1, 3, 527048) 1 That was the only thing open to me to do.
('58', 284, 1, 4, 527092) I had no business to interfere except on the assum ption that anything I said would be welcomed as a friendly sugges tion.
('58', 284, 1, 5, 527215) When therefore it was not, I had to tender apology and with draw.
('58', 284, 1, 6, 527281) You will now do exactly as your conscience leads you.
('58', 284, 1, 7, 527335) Let me not guide you in such a delicate matter from this distance.
('58', 284, 1, 8, 527402) I do not mind the uttermost renunciation from you, but it must be from perfect assimilation, and the test of assimilation would be that it would give you perennial joy, there would be not a trace of anxiety in your face, and therefore in your mind.
('58', 284, 1, 9, 527651) What is more, Hemprabha should go with you heart and soul and the result of such life should be freedom from illness.
('58', 284, 1, 10, 527769) With you two, illness cannot be the result of dietetic error.
('58', 284, 1, 11, 527831) It can only be the result of unconscious anxiety, if not even conscious.
('58', 284, 1, 12, 527904) Mental worry and anxiety are as responsible for human illnesses as wrong air, wrong water, and wrong diet; but a life of natural, joyful renunciation has been known even to overcome compulsory limitations about air, water and food.
('58', 284, 1, 13, 528136) Men of God have been found in utter destitution, in swamps with pestilential air, dirty water and wretched food to sustain them, and yet they have kept their health for prolonged periods and carried on their work.
('58', 284, 1, 14, 528350) It is related of Mahomed that when a disciple questioned him about his own pro longed fasts and his prohibition to his followers against under taking more than the regulation fasts, he said he was fed by God when he was fasting and therefore did not even know the privation, but such was not the case with the followers.
('58', 284, 1, 15, 528671) Whether the tradition has a historical basis or not, what has been related is a permanent truth, verifiable by anybody, subject of course to the conditions laid down.
('58', 284, 1, 16, 528838) Not having the capacity myself for such uttermost renunciation and being still dependent upon pure air, pure water and suitable food for retaining my health, I am incompetent to advise you.
('58', 284, 1, 17, 529028) I can therefore only warn you against a hasty leap in the dark.
('58', 284, 1, 18, 529092) I take it that you will not refuse monetary help if it comes in due course and without door to door begging.
('58', 284, 1, 19, 529201) Will it not be wise of Hemprabha to do what was done for you, to come down to Poona and take rest, if necessary, for full one month if the climate is found suitable for her consti tution?
('58', 284, 1, 20, 529389) I dread the prospect of her developing beriberi.
('58', 284, 1, 21, 529438) Let her not give up writing to me because you are there.
('58', 284, 1, 22, 529495) With love, Yours sincerely, BAPU From a photostat: G.N. 1620

('58', 285, 12, 19, 530522) December 25, 1932
('58', 285, 13, 20, 530540) DEAR FRIEND, I thank you for your long letter.
('58', 285, 13, 21, 530587) You are at liberty to publish your own letter and this reply.
('58', 285, 13, 22, 530649) In the first place, it seems to me that you have misconstrued the
('58', 285, 14, 23, 530715) 1 The letter was in reply to the addressee’s dated December 22, requesting Gandhiji to justify his fast “as a means of solving a problem”.
('58', 285, 14, 24, 530854) 2 Dated December 20, 1932 (S.N. 18746)
('58', 286, 0, 1, 530893) VOL. 58: 16 NOVEMBER, 1932 14 JANUARY, 1933 287
('58', 286, 1, 2, 530941) proposed Bill.
('58', 286, 1, 3, 530956) It is not sought to impose the views of a minority on the majority, but it is sought to restore the condition as it was before the decisions of Courts gave a permanent legal effect to a custom.
('58', 286, 1, 4, 531150) Whilst a particular custom is in vogue without at any stage being made permanent by decisions of a Court or by legislation, it becomes stagnant and is not liable to the gradual and imperceptible change that every healthy custom undergoes in process of time and under pressure of the demand of the public governed by that particular custom.
('58', 286, 1, 5, 531490) The proposed Bill will so alter the Court made Law as to make it possible for the public interested by a majority to change the then existing custom.
('58', 286, 1, 6, 531640) Instances are not wanting in Hinduism to prove that even the interpretations of accepted Shastras have suffered evolu tion, so much so that in some cases the original meaning has compl etely gone into disuse.
('58', 286, 1, 7, 531849) All the fears that you have described in your letter are in my opinion groundless for the reason I have stated.
('58', 286, 1, 8, 531961) You will admit that there are rival schools of interpretation of the Agamas, as also there are Shastris who question the authenticity of certain Agamas.
('58', 286, 1, 9, 532114) If Hinduism was not in a decaying condition, we would not find those versed in Vedic lore supine, whilst gross supers tition is defiling a religion that was once pure and had inherent capa city for continually throwing out impurities and responding to the call of the age.
('58', 286, 1, 10, 532387) I can only give you my assurance that I have no desire whatsoever to do violence to Hindu public feeling or to ignore the Shastras on which Hinduism is based.
('58', 286, 1, 11, 532546) I have, however, reserved to myself the right to determine according to my light the choice of interpretation in the midst of a variety, or even in all humility to give a new interpretation where in rare instances I feel the capacity for it, and this practice is quite consistent with the spirit of Hinduism.
('58', 286, 1, 12, 532855) We would not have a variety of interpretations and make them acceptable to a large number of Hindus, not always ignorant of Shastras.
('58', 286, 1, 13, 532989) You say that whenever an idol is polluted, all that is needed to restore its purity is to do so by authorized purification.
('58', 286, 1, 14, 533113) 1 Since there is no method of guarding an idol against pollution by the surreptitious entry of an untouchable or others who are prohibited from entering a particular temple, and since there is no infallible method of detecting intruders before they come within the pollution distance, does it not follow that the ceremony of purification has to be gone through every day in order to retain the efficacy of the idol?
('58', 286, 2, 15, 533529) 1 Vide also 2nd footnote to “Letter to R. Sankaranarayana Iyer”, 24 12 1932.

('58', 287, 1, 3, 533817) Do you contemplate courts of inquisition for determining the birth status of tens of thou sands of Hindus?

('58', 297, 1, 2, 547213) 429. LETTER TO G. D. BIRLA
('58', 297, 2, 3, 547240) December 27, 1932 1
('58', 297, 3, 4, 547260) MY DEAR GHANSHYAMDAS, I have your letter 2 .
('58', 297, 3, 5, 547305) The dazzle of my presence is really a greater embarrassment to me than to friends like you, and I wish that we can work and speak to one another on a par.
('58', 297, 3, 6, 547460) I hate to have any special credit given to my word than would be claimed by any other person saying the same thing.
('58', 297, 3, 7, 547576) With this preface I must say that I wholly dissent from your diagnosis.
('58', 297, 3, 8, 547648) If I had written a similar letter 3 say, for instance, to you, I do not think that you would have resented it.
('58', 297, 3, 9, 547759) In other words, I would not have over rated my influence with you.
('58', 297, 3, 10, 547826) How could I help Dr. Roy in securing the co operation of Babus Suresh and Satis when I knew that such a thing was not possible unless I simply coerced them into giving mechanical co operation, but I would not think of such co operation even between Suresh babu and Satis babu?
('58', 297, 3, 11, 548103) Even in the Ashram, where I may be said to have equal influence with all, there are incompatible temperaments where I cannot look for co operation, much less can I impose it; and inas much as I believed that Suresh and Satis Babus were more effective people as plodders, I naturally desired the work to be in their hands, and I thought that Dr. Roy would appreciate my suggestion.
('58', 297, 3, 12, 548484) Why should anybody feel hurt if a burden is shifted from his shoulders and put on to another, thought to be more able to carry it?
('58', 297, 3, 13, 548615) And I, as it now turns out erroneously, thought that Dr. Bidhan would not misconstrue my letter, take it in good light, and contest, if he liked, the underlying assumption, but never resent the letter.
('58', 297, 3, 14, 548817) And why do you say that I have rebuked Dr. Roy in my second letter?
('58', 297, 3, 15, 548885) I think I have fairly put the position, but if you have not followed it, you may read it over again.
('58', 297, 3, 16, 548986) I would like you to understand the motive under lying the first letter.
('58', 297, 3, 17, 549058) I shall see if I can think of a good secretary for you who will work for the love of work.
('58', 297, 4, 18, 549149) 1 In the printed source, this letter is dated December 29, 1932, which seems to be wrong as the addressee referring to this letter in his reply dated January 2, 1933, says: “I have your letters of the 27th and 28th.” For the letter of the 28th, vide “Letter to G. D. Birla”, 28 12 1932. 2 Dated December 21, 1932; vide Appendix “Letter from G. D. Birla”, 21 12 1932. 3 The reference is to Gandhiji’s letter to Dr. B. C. Roy; vide 7 12 1932.

('58', 303, 5, 11, 557469) 442. LETTER TO MIRABEHN
('58', 303, 6, 12, 557493) Morning, after prayer [December 29, 1932] 1
('58', 303, 7, 13, 557537) MIRA, The notes were after all received.
('58', 303, 7, 14, 557578) Your letter came in at the usual time.
('58', 303, 7, 15, 557617) It is a wrong thing to rehearse a calamity 2 (i.e., an event believed by us to be a calamity though in fact it may be a blessing) and to reproduce in advance the feelings one would have.
('58', 303, 7, 16, 557804) It is enough that we hold ourselves prepared for the worst.
('58', 303, 7, 17, 557864) This we do by an ever increasing faith in God, the Good, the Just, the Compassionate, the Bountiful, the Giver of the daily bread, the Help of the helpless, the All powerful, the All knowing, the Ever vigilant, the Whole Truth.
('58', 303, 7, 18, 558092) Nirvan is utter extinction of all egoism, self.
('58', 303, 7, 19, 558140) Its positive aspect is capable of being experienced but incapable of being described.
('58', 303, 7, 20, 558226) But we know by inference that it is something vastly superior to any bliss that we can possibly experience on this earth.
('58', 303, 8, 21, 558348) 1 “Undated, probably December 29, 1932, postmark December 30, 1932”— Mirabehn.
('58', 303, 8, 22, 558427) At the top of the letter are the initials presumably of the Jail authority in Bombay with the date December 31, 1932. 2 “The teaching of this letter as likewise that of January 5, 1933 and January 19, 1933 has been one of the things that sank deep into my being and by now it has become a habit with me immediately to check my mind the moment it begins speculating and picturing.

('58', 307, 2, 3, 564279) The Bombay Chronicle, 30 12 1932
('58', 307, 3, 4, 564312) 448. STATEMENT ON UNTOUCHABILITY XIII
('58', 307, 4, 5, 564350) December 30, 1932 I had full consultation with Mr. C. Rajagopalachari, Mr. K. Madhavan Nair and Mr. Kelappan 1, who have come to Poona to confer with me.
('58', 307, 4, 6, 564504) They have placed the results of the Guruvayur refe rendum before me.
('58', 307, 4, 7, 564573) The referendum was taken of the Ponnani Taluk where the temple is situated.
('58', 307, 4, 8, 564649) Never perhaps was a referendum taken with such scrupulous care or with such scientific precision before this.
('58', 307, 4, 9, 564759) Rarely to my know ledge, have 73 per cent of the eligible voters voted.
('58', 307, 4, 10, 564831) In order to find out the truth, voting was confined only to those who were actual temple goers, that is to say, those who were not entitled to enter the Guruvayur Temple and those who would not, such as the Arya Samajists, were excluded from the voters’ list.
('58', 307, 4, 11, 565091) I had intended without thinking of all implications actually to find out by some method of examination, who were actual temple goers, but I have found it to be utterly impracticable.
('58', 307, 4, 12, 565274) It was enough to announce that only those should vote who believed in temple going, who had faith in temple worship as an integral part of the Hindu religion and who were entitled to enter the Guruvayur Temple.
('58', 307, 4, 13, 565485) The total population entitled to the temple entry being approxi mately 65,000, the outside estimate of adults may be taken as 30,000. As a matter of fact, 27,465 adult men and women were actually visited for receiving their votes.
('58', 307, 4, 14, 565716) Of these 55 per cent were in favour of tem ple entry; nine per cent against, eight per cent were neutrals, and 27 per cent abstained.
('58', 307, 4, 15, 565850) It should be remembered that the referendum was taken amidst adverse influences.
('58', 307, 4, 16, 565931) The Zamorin would not co operate, and I am sorry to have to say, even cast aspersions upon the workers and the procedure they followed.
('58', 307, 4, 17, 566067) The Ponnani Taluk is the stronghold of orthodoxy and yet there was a decisive majority in favour of admi ssion of the untouchables to that shrine now made famous throughout
('58', 307, 5, 18, 566240) 1 Vide Appendix “Discussion with K. Kelappan”, 29 12 1932.
('58', 308, 0, 1, 566299) VOL. 58: 16 NOVEMBER, 1932 14 JANUARY, 1933 309
('58', 308, 1, 2, 566347) the length and breadth of the land.
('58', 308, 1, 3, 566383) The figures were also instructive, as showing that both men and women had no hesitation in spite of the contemplated fast, of express ing their dissent.
('58', 308, 1, 4, 566536) I would also draw a fair deduction from the neutrals and non co operators.
('58', 308, 1, 5, 566611) They could not at all, if they had chosen to give their decision, be regarded as against the temple entry of the Harijans.
('58', 308, 1, 6, 566734) It would not be a bad or unfair guess to make, if I suggested that a fourth of these, at least, were probably for temple entry.
('58', 308, 1, 7, 566862) The percentage of the voters favouring temple entry would then be sixty five per cent of the total eligible voters.
('58', 308, 1, 8, 566978) If they be excluded altogether from the referendum, the majority would be 77 per cent.
('58', 308, 1, 9, 567065) Turn the figures as we may, the unchallengeable conclusion is that a decisive majority of eligible voters are in favour of the entry by the Harijans.
('58', 308, 1, 10, 567215) That fact shows that Mr. Kelappan’s statement that the majority of temple going population surrounding Guruvayur was in favour of temple entry, is correct.
('58', 308, 1, 11, 567371) In view of the official announcement that the Viceregal decision as to the sanction for the introduction in the Madras Legislative Council of Dr. Subbaroyan’s permissive Bill with reference to the temple entry could not possibly be announced before the 15th of January, the fast contemplated to take place on the 2nd day of the New Year will be indefinitely postponed, and in any case up to the date of the announcement of the Viceregal decision.
('58', 308, 1, 12, 567818) Kelappan concurs with this postponement.
('58', 308, 1, 13, 567859) As the contemplated fast was addressed to the public, let me, at the risk of repeating what I have said previously, state my own position clearly.
('58', 308, 1, 14, 568006) My fast, I regard, as a purely spiritual act, and therefore not capable of being fully ex plained.
('58', 308, 1, 15, 568105) But in so far as I can, I may say that it is intended to stir the public conscience.
('58', 308, 1, 16, 568190) Hinduism teaches that when evils and corruption are beyond control by ordinary means and, human endeavour is supplemented by tapasya or penance which, in its extreme form, means fasting either conditional or unconditional.
('58', 308, 1, 17, 568413) Therefore it is no new thing.
('58', 308, 1, 18, 568443) But for the influence, supposed or real, I enjoy among the masses, perhaps no notice would be taken of it.
('58', 308, 1, 19, 568550) My conviction is that Hinduism has fallen from the purity and vitality it once had.
('58', 308, 1, 20, 568634) Its very scriptures are evidence of the continu 
('58', 309, 0, 1, 568683) 310 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('58', 309, 1, 2, 568725) ous progress and adaptability to circumstances that arose from time to time.
('58', 309, 1, 3, 568802) Though it has retained unimpaired the claim to divine inspi ration for the scriptures as a body, it did not hesitate to introduce new reforms and make changes.
('58', 309, 1, 4, 568962) Hence it is that we have in Hindu ism not only Vedas, but all later writings claiming authority.
('58', 309, 1, 5, 569059) But a time came, when this healthy growth or evolution was arrested, and instead of the written word being used as an aid to the search for light from within, it was held to be all sufficing, whether it accorded with longings and strivings of the spirit within or not.
('58', 309, 1, 6, 569328) The descendants of those who wrestled with God Himself and drew from Him some of the imperishable things one finds in Vedas and later writings, felt too exhausted for further effort, either to wring out new meaning from an old verse or mantra or produce a new mantra.
('58', 309, 1, 7, 569596) They felt that they had done with God and that God had finished His work, after inspiring the last verse of the latest Shastra.
('58', 309, 1, 8, 569724) And so one finds an army of interpreters seeking to reconcile, often irreconcilable texts, unmindful as to whether they answer the pressing needs of the age or whether they can stand the light of searching examination.
('58', 309, 1, 9, 569943) And even penances took mere outward form, instead of being an expression of the inward agonizing struggle.
('58', 309, 1, 10, 570050) I may be wrong in my diagnosis, but such being my case and finding the Hindu society irresponsive to the central call of Hinduism, that is, progressive realization of unity of all life, not as a philosophical doctrine but as a solid fact of life, I thought that by continuous effort to live my religion as I understood it, I had the fitness for doing penance by way of fasting and that I had such a call from within I hope it is easy for the reader to see that there is no coercion behind the fast thus conceived.
('58', 309, 1, 11, 570564) If my fast was fixed as an unconditio nal one, it is obvious there can be no coercion about it, for nothing that the public may do or not do could suspend my fast.
('58', 309, 1, 12, 570728) Therefore, if a conditional fast is held to be coercive, it would be so considered because of the condition.
('58', 309, 1, 13, 570837) My experience is that the fast has not deter red people from sticking to their principles or even their incli nations, as was seen at Guruvayur.
('58', 309, 1, 14, 570982) The public will now understand that the postponement is what it means and no more.
('58', 309, 1, 15, 571065) The fast was intended to secure admission of the untouchables into the Guruvayur Temple, and if its resumption is necessary in a legitimate manner to secure the opening, it will cer tainly come, as for instance, if through the mere supineness of the
('58', 310, 0, 1, 571315) VOL. 58: 16 NOVEMBER, 1932 14 JANUARY, 1933 311
('58', 310, 1, 2, 571363) reformers and consequent want of expression by public opinion in demanding the necessary legislation to remove the block created by decisions of courts and the Law of Trusts or the Madras Religious Endowments Act, which itself was a measure affecting religion, natu rally the fast has to be resumed.
('58', 310, 1, 3, 571663) That is to say, it must be resumed, if the original vow is to be fulfilled.
('58', 310, 1, 4, 571739) The fast must be resumed for the acts of omission or commi ssion by those who are believed to be in favour of opening the Guru vayur Temple.
('58', 310, 1, 5, 571880) The Yeravda Pact was entered into between the representatives of the caste Hindus and the Harijans, and while confirming the Pact at the memorable conference in Bombay, the former resolved as follows:
('58', 310, 2, 6, 572081) This conference resolves that henceforth, amongst Hindus, no one shall be regarded as untouchable by reason of his birth and that those who have been so regarded hitherto, shall have the same rights as the other Hindus in regard to the use of public wells, public schools, public roads and other public institutions.
('58', 310, 2, 7, 572398) These rights shall have statutory recognition at the first opportunity, and shall be one of the earliest Acts of the Swaraj Parliament, if they shall not have received such recognition before that time.
('58', 310, 2, 8, 572601) It is further agreed that it shall be the duty of all Hindu leaders to secure, by every legitimate and peaceful means, an early removal of all social disabilities now imposed by caste Hindus upon the so called untouchable classes, including bar in the respect of admission to temples.
('58', 310, 3, 9, 572886) If the distinguished caste Hindus that passed the resolution, represented, as they claim to, the Hindu portion of the Indian Nation, the claim has to be made good by increasing fraternization day by day with Harijans on the part of caste Hindus by way of opening to them public institutions.
('58', 310, 3, 10, 573178) Mr. Kelappan’s fast over the opening of the Guruvayur Temple was actually going on whilst the Pact was emerging, and I asked him to suspend it principally at the suggestion of the Zamorin of Calicut.
('58', 310, 3, 11, 573378) Moreover, as I have already said, when on the British Government’s acceptance of relevant portion of the Pact I broke the fast, I solemnly assured Dr. Ambedkar and took a vow in the secret of my heart and in the presence of God that I would hold myself as a hostage for the fulfilment of the resolution above mentioned, and the general carry 
('58', 310, 4, 12, 573721) 1 This resolution was drafted by Gandhiji and passed by the conference with Malaviyaji in the chair on September 25, 1932; vide “Resolution at the Hindu Leaders’ Conference, Bombay”, 25 9 1932, where, however, “imposed by custom” is found instead of “imposed by caste Hindus”.
('58', 311, 0, 1, 573998) 312 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('58', 311, 1, 2, 574040) ing out of the Pact by the caste Hindus.
('58', 311, 1, 3, 574081) It would be a betrayal of trust and a betrayal of the Harijans if, in any shape or form, I slac kened my effort or gave up altogether the intention of fasting in connection with the removal of untouchability.
('58', 311, 1, 4, 574290) I would like the voiceless and helpless Harijans to feel that thou sands of Hindu reformers, as zealous of Hindu religion and scrip tures on which it is based, as any Hindu calling himself a sanatanistcan be, are prepared, no less than I am, to sacrifice their lives, if need be, in an attempt to remove untouchability, root and branch.
('58', 311, 1, 5, 574627) There can be no rest, therefore, for me or those who, by word of mouth or show of hands, silently endorsed the resolution, until untou chabilty becomes a thing of the past It would be only out of the ashes of untouchability that Hinduism can revive, and thus be purified and become a vital and vitalizing force in the world.
('58', 311, 2, 6, 574952) The Bombay Chronicle, 31 12 1932; also The Hindu, 31 12 1932
('58', 311, 3, 7, 575013) 449. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('58', 311, 4, 8, 575041) December 30, 1932 As some misunderstanding has arisen about Pandit Panchanan Tarkaratna’s visit to me, it is necessary to state how he came to me, and what happened between us.
('58', 311, 4, 9, 575218) The Pandit came with Babu Motilal Roy, Director of the Pravartak Sangh of Bengal.
('58', 311, 4, 10, 575300) Babu Motilal Roy has been tying to avoid a split among the Hindus over the campaign against untouchability and he was most anxious that Pandit Panchanan Tarkaratna should accompany him when he came to see me to discuss and understand the whole position from my standpoint When I heard that from Babu Motilal Roy, I telegraphed to him welcoming him and Pandit Pan chanan Tarkaratna.
('58', 311, 4, 11, 575682) It gave me joy, therefore, when the Pandit came to me.
('58', 311, 4, 12, 575737) We had two friendly conversations, as a result of which I think we came closer together and I began to entertain hope.
('58', 311, 4, 13, 575856) Though he repre sents the ordinary orthodox sanatani attitude, he appreciated my viewpoint and he did not despair of finding a way of solving the temple entry question.
('58', 311, 4, 14, 576025) I have made a definite suggestion to him, which ought to satisfy the most exacting sanatanist He is now in Guru vayur, and I hope a formula will be found acceptable to the Pro Change and No Change sanatanists.

('58', 314, 1, 2, 579757) 451. LETTER TO DR.
('58', 314, 1, 3, 579776) B. C. ROY
('58', 314, 2, 4, 579786) [December] 1 30, 1932
('58', 314, 3, 5, 579808) DEAR DR.
('58', 314, 3, 6, 579817) BIDHAN, I have your great and good letter quite worthy of you.
('58', 314, 3, 7, 579880) I love and accept your correction, and say with you that we are near to each other; and since we are near to each other, let me say that my letter 2 had no complaint behind it.
('58', 314, 3, 8, 580057) It simply went out as an advice in order to secure what I thought would be a better working of the orga nization, and I expected you, as a friend, if my advice did not find any response within your breast, to say plainly to me, ‘You do not know the situation, and therefore I do not accept your advice.’ Of course, your reply said the same thing, but in an unexpectedly different manner, but that is all dead and gone.
('58', 314, 3, 9, 580476) After having tendered you my apology 3, I had dismissed the incident from mind, but you have revived the memory, and now rendered it sacred by your generous letter.
('58', 314, 3, 10, 580641) I am glad of the news you give me about your distinguished patients 4. It is quite like Baby to have placed her flat at Kamala’s disposal.
('58', 314, 4, 11, 580780) Yours sincerely,

('58', 323, 2, 8, 596793) This time the fast has affected me very much.
('58', 323, 2, 9, 596839) Have become very weak.
('58', 323, 2, 10, 596862) The weight went down at once by six pounds and the hands and feet became stiff.
('58', 323, 2, 11, 596942) Doyle called after 11 o’clock and asked for time till Wednesday morning.
('58', 323, 2, 12, 597015) I readily agreed and gave up the fast.
('58', 323, 2, 13, 597054) If the decision is not satiafactory, the fast will have to be resumed.
('58', 323, 2, 14, 597125) Ate oranges and mosambis and also took their juice, as also pomegranate juice and grapes.

('58', 333, 0, 1, 614952) 334 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('58', 333, 1, 2, 614994) 464. LETTER TO THE ZAMORIN OF CALICUT
('58', 333, 2, 3, 615032) January 1, 1933
('58', 333, 3, 4, 615048) DEAR FRIEND, I thank you for your letter 1 of the 26th ultimo.
('58', 333, 3, 5, 615111) Your letter has come upon me with painful surprise.
('58', 333, 3, 6, 615163) In a matter that is purely religi ous to me, as it must be to you, I should expect the uttermost frank ness and goodwill on either side.
('58', 333, 3, 7, 615300) I miss the latter in your letter under reference.
('58', 333, 3, 8, 615350) Have you ever turned out an untouchable on the Krithigai Ekadasi day?
('58', 333, 3, 9, 615420) Surely, if hundreds, if not thousands, of un touchables, both men and women, enter the temple every Ekadasi, as can be proved they do, it cannot be difficult to detect some of them.
('58', 333, 3, 10, 615602) The evidence in my possession goes to show that crowds of untouchables make use of the privilege every year on that holy day.
('58', 333, 3, 11, 615728) You refer me to the judgment of the Madras High Court.
('58', 333, 3, 12, 615783) That judgment, if I understand it rightly, shows clearly that untouchables enter the temple on the Ekadasi day, not stealthily but openly and as a matter of right.
('58', 333, 3, 13, 615947) Here is what I read in the judgment before me:
('58', 333, 4, 14, 615994) The Guruvayur Temple is not a private temple, but a public temple and every Hindu has a right to worship in it, subject to such customary rules and regulations which have been prevailing from time immemorial.
('58', 333, 4, 15, 616203) The high castes are allowed actual right of entry into the temple throughout the year.
('58', 333, 4, 16, 616290) In that purpose they have a right of way over the roads leading to the temple and around the temple.
('58', 333, 4, 17, 616391) The lower castes are allowed the right of entry only on Ekadasi Festival day, and on that day they have got the right of using the roads.
('58', 333, 4, 18, 616529) On the other days they have neither of these rights.
('58', 333, 4, 19, 616582) This was the situation from time immemorial.
('58', 333, 5, 20, 616627) 1 This read: “You ask whether the temple is open to all Hindus including untouchables for three days every year.
('58', 333, 5, 21, 616740) In reply, I have to say that the information is not correct.
('58', 333, 5, 22, 616801) The untouchables have no right to enter the temple on any day.
('58', 333, 5, 23, 616864) But, as a large crowd admittedly enter the temple on the Krithigai Ekadasi day and as this crowd might possibly include untouchables and as in any case, it is difficult to ascertain the different castes to which the members of the crowd belong, a purificatory ceremony is performed on the next day (Dwadasi).
('58', 333, 5, 24, 617173) Apart from this, the alleged entry of untouchables on the Ekadasi day is not a fact.
('58', 333, 5, 25, 617258) They do not enter the temple at all.
('58', 333, 5, 26, 617295) For more definite particulars I would refer you to the judgment of Mr. Justice Ramesam Pantulu of the Madras High Court, pronounced in the middle of June last, of which I presume you have a copy.”
('58', 334, 0, 1, 617492) VOL. 58: 16 NOVEMBER, 1932 14 JANUARY, 1933 335
('58', 334, 1, 2, 617540) I read then from the same judgment
('58', 334, 2, 3, 617575) The lower caste Hindus are after all Hindus and it may be with this
('58', 334, 3, 4, 617643) consideration in view that for one day in the year the temple is thrown open to
('58', 334, 4, 5, 617723) them with the ostensible excuse that on such a day it would be impossible to
('58', 334, 5, 6, 617800) check the crowds, the inner object being to allow all castes’ entry on that day.
('58', 334, 6, 7, 617881) This was the view of Ramanuja, the famous Vaishnava reformer.
('58', 334, 6, 8, 617943) According to
('58', 334, 7, 9, 617956) him, all Vaishnava temples ought to be thrown open to all castes one day in
('58', 334, 8, 10, 618032) the year.
('58', 334, 8, 11, 618042) Unless I am very much mistaken, these two paragraphs seem to be conclusive evidence that for that particular Ekadasi day untoucha bles are allowed to enter the temple without let or hindrance.
('58', 334, 8, 12, 618235) As this matter is of great public importance, I am sending the correspondence to the Press.
('58', 334, 9, 13, 618327) Yours sincerely, RAJA MANAVEDAN RAJA ZAMORIN OF CALICUT KOTTAKKAL
('58', 334, 10, 14, 618393) From a microfilm: M.M.U./XXII
('58', 334, 11, 15, 618423) 465. LETTER TO C. Y. CHINTAMANI
('58', 334, 12, 16, 618455) January 1, 1933
('58', 334, 13, 17, 618471) DEAR MR. CHINTAMANI, I thank you for your letter.
('58', 334, 13, 18, 618521) The matter of the fast is not for me wholly one of reason, because you will have no hesitation in believing me when I tell you that all such fasts have been prompted by an un seen power.
('58', 334, 13, 19, 618708) I deliberately use the expression “unseen power”, because I do not exclude the possibility of that power being evil.
('58', 334, 13, 20, 618825) But these fasts have appealed to my reason as they have to that of many utterly detached friends.
('58', 334, 13, 21, 618923) The silent and invisible effects of all spiritual acts are far deeper and far more pervasive than their felt and visible effects.
('58', 334, 13, 22, 619053) If therefore these fasts have amounted to moral coercion in some cases, they have imperceptibly undoubtedly moved to action a thousand times more than those who have acted under moral coercion, which therefore may be regarded as a negligible quantity.
('58', 334, 13, 23, 619305) That such is the result of spiritual acts is not a matter of conjecture, but provable under given conditions like any other tangible result.
('58', 334, 13, 24, 619446) So much for the moral coercion.
('58', 335, 0, 1, 619478) 336 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('58', 335, 1, 2, 619520) As to the permissibility of fasts, I quite agree with you that the motive is irrelevant if the act itself is prohibited.
('58', 335, 1, 3, 619641) In the first instance, a conditional fast is not a suicide, but if we accept the authority of the Hindu Shastras, then there is ample warrant not only for conditional fasts, but even unconditional, under some extraordinary circum stances.
('58', 335, 1, 4, 619880) I have only recently found myself in possession of a pam phlet issued by Madras Advocates in which are collected instances of fasts like mine in the Shastras.
('58', 335, 1, 5, 620039) If you would care to explore the subject, I would gladly send you my copy.
('58', 335, 1, 6, 620114) My regards to you and Mr. Krishnaram.
('58', 335, 2, 7, 620152) Yours sincerely, SJT.
('58', 335, 2, 8, 620174) C. Y. CHINTAMANI 17 HAMILTON ROAD, ALLAHABAD
('58', 335, 3, 9, 620219) From a photostat: S.N. 19129

('58', 348, 5, 8, 638011) 494. INTERVIEW TO THE ASSOCIATED PRESS OF INDIA 1
('58', 348, 6, 9, 638061) January 2, 1933
('58', 348, 7, 10, 638077) That in a spirit of compromise he had made a suggestion in order to reconcile opposition to temple entry by Harijans at Guruvayur, was revealed by Mr. Gandhi to the Associated Press this afternoon in the course of an interview.
('58', 348, 8, 11, 638305) Gandhiji’s attention was drawn to the statement 2 made by him on Pundit Panchanan Tarkaratna’s visit to him in which he was reported to have made a definite suggestion to the Pundit which ought to satisfy the most exacting sanatanists.
('58', 348, 8, 12, 638541) When invited to throw light on the suggestion, Gandhiji said: 3
('58', 348, 9, 13, 638605) The suggestion I made was this: During certain hours of the day, the temple should be thrown open to Harijans and to other Hindus, who have no objection to the presence of Harijans, and during certain other hours it should be reserved for those who havescruples against the entry of Harijans.
('58', 348, 9, 14, 638898) There should be no difficulty, whatsoever, in accepting this suggestion, seeing that in connection with the Krithikai Ekadasi festival at Guruvayur, Harijans are allowed to enter side by side with other Hindus and then the idol of the temple undergoes purification.
('58', 348, 10, 15, 639164) Asked if his suggestion was that the temple might undergo purification daily
('58', 348, 11, 16, 639241) after the entry of the Harijans, Mr. Gandhi replied: Personally, I am opposed to purification at all.
('58', 348, 11, 17, 639343) But if that would satisfy the conscience of objectors, I would personally raise no objec 
('58', 348, 12, 18, 639433) 1 Gandhiji was reclining on a cot in the shade of the famous mango tree.
('58', 348, 12, 19, 639506) A few Shastris were sitting around him discussing and arguing.
('58', 348, 13, 20, 639569) 2 Vide “Statement to the Press”, 30 12 1932.
('58', 348, 14, 21, 639614) 3 This paragraph is from Amrita Bazar Patrika, 4 1 1933.
('58', 349, 0, 1, 639671) 350 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('58', 349, 1, 2, 639713) tion to purification.
('58', 349, 1, 3, 639735) If purification has any value, then there are so many possibilities of daily defilement from a variety of causes refer red to in the various texts, that there should be a daily purification, whether Harijans are allowed to enter or not.
('58', 349, 2, 4, 639972) Asked if the compromise suggested by him did not still maintain a distinction between Harijans and high castes, Mr. Gandhi replied that the Harijans’ attitude should be this: If there is a person who objects to my presence, I would like to respect his objection, so long as he (the objector) does not deprive me of the right that belongs to me.
('58', 349, 2, 5, 640317) So long as I am permitted to have a legiti mate share of the day for offering worship side by side with those who have no objection to my presence, I would be satisfied.
('58', 349, 3, 6, 640487) Mr. Gandhi proceeded to say that in a place where the majority of people favoured temple entry by Harijans, then the number of caste Hindus who would want the temple exclusively for them during certain hours, would be so small as to be negligible.
('58', 349, 3, 7, 640735) Proceeding to another aspect of the temple entry agitation, Mr. Gandhi emphatically discouraged direct action by non Hindus for procuring entry for Harijans.
('58', 349, 3, 8, 640893) He declared: This is a deeply religious movement, and it will be thousand pities if out of misplaced sympathy or other motives non Hindus were to interfere by way of direct action.
('58', 349, 4, 9, 641074) What prompted Mr. Gandhi to make this observation, was a letter received by him from Colombo, in which the correspondent stated that, with reference to the local temple entry campaign, what had been misnamed satyagraha was offered by non Hindus, consisting of a Buddhist, a Roman Catholic lady, a Christian and a few Muslims.
('58', 349, 4, 10, 641400) They were prosecuted by the law at the instance of the temple trustees and convicted.
('58', 349, 4, 11, 641486) The correspondent asked Mr. Gandhi whether interference by non Hindus in order to secure temple entry for Harijans could be justified.
('58', 349, 4, 12, 641621) Mahatmaji declared: I have no hesitation whatsoever in saying that this could not be justified under any circumstances.
('58', 349, 4, 13, 641741) It would be a most dangerous interference if non Hindus were to express their sympathy by way of direct action.
('58', 349, 4, 14, 641853) Indeed, I go so far as to say that direct action can be offered [only] by those caste Hindus who are entitled to enter the temple in regard to which such action is taken, and who being entitled, believe in temple entry.
('58', 349, 5, 15, 642073) Asked what he had to say about Viceregal sanction for Dr. Subbaroyan’s Bill, Mr. Gandhi said that he hoped that the Viceroy would give permission as early as possible.
('58', 349, 5, 16, 642241) The Hindu, 3 1 1933
('58', 350, 0, 1, 642261) VOL. 58: 16 NOVEMBER, 1932 14 JANUARY, 1933 351
('58', 350, 1, 2, 642309) 495. INTERVIEW ON SUBBAROYAN’S BILL
('58', 350, 2, 3, 642345) January 2, 1933
('58', 350, 3, 4, 642361) Asked for his views on sanatanists’ agitation based on the Queen’s Pro clamation, Gandhiji observed: I do not know what meaning is attached to the word ‘neutrality’ by those who are seeking to oppose Dr. Subbaroyan’s Bill.
('58', 350, 3, 5, 642584) I can say, with perfect confidence, that Dr. Subbaroyan’s Bill is intended to undo the wrong done by the British courts’ decision.
('58', 350, 3, 6, 642715) I do not suggest that the wrong was done intentionally.
('58', 350, 3, 7, 642771) It should again be remembered that Dr. Subbaroyan’s Bill seeks to amend the Madras Religious En dowments Act which is itself of a religious character, another breach of neutrality according to the sanatanists’ interpretation.
('58', 350, 3, 8, 642997) Again if one were to examine the contents of the Bill, dispassionately, it will be found that it seeks to impose nothing on the Hindus, but it merely seeks to register the will of the Hindu public in connection with temples in which that public are interested—not of the whole of the Hindu public but only of those who are entitled to have a say in connection with a particular temple.
('58', 350, 3, 9, 643383) I can see in this measure no in terference whatsoever, with anybody’s religion.
('58', 350, 3, 10, 643463) The Bill seeks to protect both the opponents and advocates of temple entry.
('58', 350, 4, 11, 643539) Gandhiji wanted the actual text of Mr. T. R. Ramachandra Aiyar’s Guruvayur speech to deal with it.
('58', 350, 5, 12, 643638) When I drew his attention to the fact that I was prohibited by the jail warders from bringing into the jail a copy of the newspaper containing the speech, Gandhiji said that he would talk to the Superintendent and see that the Pressmen were allowed to bring in their reference papers in the future.
('58', 350, 6, 13, 643937) Asked whether he would abandon the fast if the Viceroy gave his sanction to Dr. Subbaroyan’s Bill, Gandhiji said that he would further postpone the fast till the next stage was reached.
('58', 350, 6, 14, 644123) The Bill must be enacted and the Government’s final assent given for it to become law.
('58', 350, 6, 15, 644210) A referendum in which the Zamorin also would have to participate, would follow.
('58', 350, 6, 16, 644290) The possibility of a fast would continue till the temple was thrown open, but at every step stated above, the possibility would be reduced.
('58', 350, 6, 17, 644430) The fast would be finally abandoned only when the temple was thrown open.
('58', 350, 7, 18, 644504) Questioned what would be his attitude if the Viceroy refused his sanction to the Bill, Mahatma remarked: Ah, if the Viceroy refused sanction, I would consider the posi tion.
('58', 350, 7, 19, 644678) Then, the fast is bound to come, but I should wait till the Govern 
('58', 351, 0, 1, 644746) 352 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('58', 351, 1, 2, 644788) ment state their attitude.
('58', 351, 1, 3, 644815) I do not want to go into the question at the present moment.
('58', 351, 2, 4, 644876) Referring to the proposal of a section of South Indians for building new temples where reformers and Harijans could go for common worship, leaving the old temples to the orthodox, Gandhiji said: The question does not arise, until I am satisfied that those who are entitled to worship are in favour of that proposal.
('58', 351, 2, 5, 645192) The orthodox view is that the sanctity of a temple would decrease if Harijans are admitted.
('58', 351, 2, 6, 645284) People who are in favour of temple entry are of the opinion that the sanctity of a temple will increase if all the Hindus are allowed inside the temple.
('58', 351, 2, 7, 645437) Increase or decrease in sanctity is only a mental process.
('58', 351, 2, 8, 645496) If the majority of the temple goers are in favour of such a proposal, I shall give it consideration.
('58', 351, 2, 9, 645597) But I am sure that the sugges tion will not be acceptable to any of the reformers.

('58', 351, 9, 16, 645930) 497. STATEMENT ON UNTOCHABILITY IN HINDU SHASTRAS
('58', 351, 10, 17, 645980) January 3, 1933 I have had the privilege, as the public knows, of having a friendly discussion with Bhagwan Shastri Dharurkar of Pandharpur and others who accompanied him.
('58', 351, 10, 18, 646152) These gentlemen came, as they made it clear to me, in their personal capacity, and not as represen tatives of any association.
('58', 351, 10, 19, 646279) They came with a view to understanding my
('58', 351, 11, 20, 646321) 1 The telegram was in reply to a communication from Shrimati Lakshmamma, Congress worker and member, District Board, Ellore, informing Gandhiji of her determination to commence fasting from the 2nd instant, in respect of the local Sri Janardhana Swami Temple in case Mahatma Gandhi would fast in connection with the temple entry problem at Guruvayur, and requesting Gandhiji’s permission to do so.
('58', 351, 11, 21, 646719) 2 The telegram was reported under the date line: “Ellore, January 3”.
('58', 352, 0, 1, 646789) VOL. 58: 16 NOVEMBER, 1932 14 JANUARY, 1933 353
('58', 352, 1, 2, 646837) position regarding untouchability in general and the movement for temple entry by Harijans in particular.
('58', 352, 1, 3, 646943) No doubt they had also the intention of helping me to understand and even adopt the sanatani viewpoint, for which they were speaking.
('58', 352, 1, 4, 647077) I had a long discussion with them.
('58', 352, 1, 5, 647112) In order to leave no stone unturned in my attempt to understand the viewpoint of sanatani pun dits and in accordance with the arrangement made with Bhagwan Shastri Dharurkar, I had invited some friends, learned in the Shastras and who, I knew, generally supported my position, so that I may have both the schools of thought playing upon my mind.
('58', 352, 1, 6, 647458) I can say that I listened to their arguments and discourses with the greatest patience and with respectful attention.
('58', 352, 1, 7, 647576) I was unable to find any error in the position which I have held for period now nearing half a century.
('58', 352, 1, 8, 647680) I know that time never runs in favour of an error, and as I regard myself as a humble seeker after truth and prone to error like any other mortal, I have always held myself ready to confess errors as soon as the conviction went home; but these dis cussions have left me more convinced than ever that untouchability, as it is practised today in Hinduism, has no warrant in the Hindu Shas tras.
('58', 352, 1, 9, 648073) Many have done me and themselves great injustice by not giving their full value to the expression “as it is understood and practised today”.
('58', 352, 1, 10, 648214) But rather than just state the effect produced on my mind by these prolonged discussions, I have secured from the pundits or Shastris who gave me general support, their interpretation of the Shastras about untouchability, and I have pleasure in giving below an authorized translation of the statement which is in Hindi.
('58', 352, 1, 11, 648534) Acharya Anandshankar Dhruva and Dr. Bhagwandas are responsible for this translation.
('58', 352, 1, 12, 648619) The statement runs as follows:
('58', 352, 2, 13, 648650) Three kinds of untouchables are mentioned in the Hindu Dharma shastras: (1) Persons classed as untouchables by birth, i.e., progeny of the union of a Shudra with a Brahmin woman.
('58', 352, 2, 14, 648829) (2) Persons guilty of any of the five heinous sins or of certain practices condemned in Hinduism.
('58', 352, 2, 15, 648927) (3) Persons whilst they are in a polluted state.
('58', 352, 3, 16, 648976) There is nothing to show that any of the communities now classed as untouchables come under the first category.
('58', 352, 3, 17, 649088) Therefore, the rules governing untouchability and ex communication under the first head are inapplicable to them.
('58', 352, 3, 18, 649202) Assuming that any of these communities can be brought under the first head, they can be free from their untouchability and have all the privileges
('58', 353, 0, 1, 649349) 354 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('58', 353, 1, 2, 649391) enjoyed in common by the four varnas by clean living, initiation into the Shaiva or Vaishnava worship, and the like.
('58', 353, 2, 3, 649508) The second kind of untouchability obviously cannot attach exclusively to any class or community as a whole.
('58', 353, 2, 4, 649616) It may apply to individuals in any and every community.
('58', 353, 2, 5, 649672) The untouchability of the untouchables so called, is not due to their fallen state under the second head, nor can they be shown to be descendants of such fallen parents.
('58', 353, 2, 6, 649842) Persons guilty of heinous sins, referred to under the second head, become fully purified by the performance of appropriate purificatory ceremonies.
('58', 353, 2, 7, 649990) The progeny of such fallen persons as have not become thus purified cannot be classed as untouchables.
('58', 353, 2, 8, 650093) Some Smritikaras
('58', 353, 3, 9, 650110) who regard such progeny as untouchables, prescribe a very slight purificatory ceremonial for their restoration; and persons who are guilty of practices rendering them untouchable can also be free from untouchability by giving up such practices.
('58', 353, 4, 10, 650355) The third kind of untouchability, due to one’s being in a polluted state, obtains among all classes whether regarded as untouchables or not.
('58', 353, 4, 11, 650496) There is nowarrant in the Shastras for considering tanners, Bhangis and others as permanent untouchables, merely by reason of their occupation.
('58', 353, 4, 12, 650640) Their untouchability is due to the external uncleanness caused by the nature of their work.
('58', 353, 4, 13, 650732) All untouchability under the third head is cured by a bath and a change of clean clothes at the due time.
('58', 353, 5, 14, 650838) Thus, it is necessary that the rights common to four varnas, e.g., of entry into temples, educational institutions, of use of public wells, ghats, tanks, rivers, etc., should equally accrue to the untouchables so called, and that it is wrong to deprive them of such common rights.
('58', 353, 5, 15, 651119) This is probable from the texts, the fundamental principles and the spirit of the Dharmashastras.
('58', 353, 5, 16, 651217) SWAMI KEVALANAND NARAYAN SHASTRI MARATHE LAXMAN SHASTRI JOSHI BHAGWANDAS ANANDSHANKAR DHRUVA INDIRARAMAN SASTRI KESHAV LAXMAN DAFTARI P. H. PURANDARE I do not need to introduce the signatories to the public, but I can say that they claim to Sjt.
('58', 353, 5, 17, 651463) C. V. Vaidya.
('58', 353, 5, 18, 651477) All these I hope to share with the public as early represent sanatan dharma no less than those who call themselves sanatanists.
('58', 353, 5, 19, 651605) Apart from these, I have received valuable opinions in general support from Mahamahopadhyaya Pramathanath
('58', 354, 0, 1, 651711) VOL. 58: 16 NOVEMBER, 1932 14 JANUARY, 1933 355
('58', 354, 1, 2, 651759) Tarkabhushan, Pundit Shreedhar Shastri Pathak, Krishna Thanasukh Misra and last but not least as it is possible to have them printed simul taneously with this.
('58', 354, 1, 3, 651919) I am issuing to the Press the original Hindi and authorized translations in Marathi and Gujarati, and I hope that the respective journals would only print the authorized text.
('58', 354, 1, 4, 652095) The opinion of these learned men, popularly construed, means that no class of persons today bears the brand of permanent untou chability.
('58', 354, 1, 5, 652233) It is obvious that untouchability by birth cannot exist today in connection with a class.
('58', 354, 1, 6, 652323) In connection with individuals, it is practi cally impossible of detection.
('58', 354, 1, 7, 652399) There are undoubtedly men who must be guilty of the five heinous sins, but all castes are capable of commi tting those sins, and society today takes no notice of them.
('58', 354, 1, 8, 652567) The con demned practice under the second head refers to eating of carrion or beef.
('58', 354, 1, 9, 652650) There are undoubtedly some people among those classed as untouchables who are given to this practice, but they are bound to give it up as soon as caste Hindus make the real advance.
('58', 354, 1, 10, 652832) At the present moment the very incentive to give up beef or carrion is lacking.
('58', 354, 1, 11, 652912) The temporary pollution under the third head carries no condemnation with it.
('58', 354, 1, 12, 652990) It is a pollution which is inevitable for all in a certain state, and the pollution ceases immediately the state ceases.
('58', 354, 1, 13, 653111) If the signatories have correctly interpreted the Shastras, then we have been all these many years doing a grave injustice to Bhangis, tanners and others by classing them as permanent untouchables, although we recognize that their profession is as honourable as any and much more indispensable for the very existence of society than many others which do not carry the mark of untouchability with them.
('58', 354, 2, 14, 653513) M. K. GANDHI 1
('58', 354, 3, 15, 653528) The Hindu, 4 1 1933

('58', 359, 5, 8, 660078) January 3, 1933
