('58', 361, 13, 18, 662797) 515. APPEAL TO SANATANISTS
('58', 361, 14, 19, 662824) January 4, 1933 This is an appeal to you from a fellow sanatanist, whom you are trying to reject in spite of yourself.
('58', 361, 14, 20, 662943) Hard swearing at me and the libellous charges some of you are indulging in, are proof to me of your distorted love.
('58', 361, 14, 21, 663059) I feel like the wife whom her many husbands profess to reject because the poor woman cannot give equal satisfac tion to all her lords and masters.
('58', 361, 14, 22, 663206) But not being able to reject her, (they know she, the willing slave, has served them all well enough) they screw up all the wrath they think they have, and swear at her for all they are worth.
('58', 361, 14, 23, 663399) The faithful wife, staunch in her loyalty, calmly allows
('58', 361, 15, 24, 663456) 1 Vide “Statement to the Press”, 30 12 1932 and “Interview to the Associated Press of India”, 2 1 1933.
('58', 362, 0, 1, 663560) VOL. 58 : 16 NOVEMBER, 1932 14 JANUARY, 1933 363
('58', 362, 1, 2, 663609) the storm to pass over her, for she is utterly innocent of all the charges promiscuously hurled at her.
('58', 362, 1, 3, 663713) After the storm has subsided, the wife finds herself a greater favourite than before of her husbands, who laugh at their own exacting nature, and realize that their patient companion had, after all, placed her all at their disposal.
('58', 362, 1, 4, 663946) Thus will it be with me, I dare to prophesy.
('58', 362, 1, 5, 663991) There are some telling verses in a sanatan scripture.
('58', 362, 1, 6, 664045) You, having brooded over the wrongs you fancy I have done to you, have put yourself in a state of rage.
('58', 362, 1, 7, 664149) Those verses say: ‘Rage generates hallucination, which produces forgetfulness.
('58', 362, 1, 8, 664228) The lapse of memory clouds intelligence; and failing intelligence leads to destruction.’ 1 In your rage, you do not even know what you are doing.
('58', 362, 1, 9, 664374) You have not even cared to inquire what I am aiming at.
('58', 362, 1, 10, 664430) Let me put a few facts before you.
('58', 362, 1, 11, 664465) The popular definition of sanatan dharma is ‘that good conduct which people can reach’.
('58', 362, 1, 12, 664553) It rules out bad conduct and bad habits, however popular they may be.
('58', 362, 1, 13, 664623) Religion is something that binds.
('58', 362, 1, 14, 664657) Bad habits loosen, and therefore can never be religion.
('58', 362, 1, 15, 664713) Therefore, if after the issues are dispassionately put before the people, they choose a particular course which is not in itself an evil, is not that sanatan dharma?
('58', 362, 1, 16, 664879) Is it not the way how the body of doctrine and conduct known as sanatan dharma has grown?
('58', 362, 1, 17, 664969) Is it not a condition of its growth?
('58', 362, 1, 18, 665006) If I have taken you with me so far, then know that, in all that I am doing, there is nothing more and nothing less than that I amtrying to find out how far people will go along the road which I hold to be good and which some of the scholars, who have first hand knowledge of divine books, tell me is also good, according to their reading of them.
('58', 362, 1, 19, 665353) But you protest that their reading is bad.
('58', 362, 1, 20, 665396) Very well.
('58', 362, 1, 21, 665407) Let the two different readings be put before the people, and let them make their choice.
('58', 362, 1, 22, 665496) If they accept my reading, will that not be sanatan dharma?
('58', 362, 1, 23, 665556) You need not even then accept my reading.
('58', 362, 1, 24, 665598) You may adhere to your own, but in that case you will not call that sanatan dharma.
('58', 362, 1, 25, 665682) You think your reading is sanatan dharma, because you assume that a vast majority of the villagers will accept it, and you reject my claim to be a sanatanist because you think it will be unacceptable to the people if it was put to them.
('58', 362, 1, 26, 665919) I have put forth no insolent claim.
('58', 362, 1, 27, 665955) I have wandered amongst millions for a number of years, not as a politician, but as a man of religion.
('58', 362, 1, 28, 666058) They have accepted me as such, and your own hot
('58', 362, 2, 29, 666106) 1 Bhagavad Gita, II.
('58', 363, 0, 1, 666127) 364 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('58', 363, 1, 2, 666169) repudiation of me is itself a proof of your having hitherto believed me to be more a man of religion than of politics.
('58', 363, 1, 3, 666288) Have you not noticed that the politician will have none of me, and has always regarded me as an intruder and unpractical visionary, whilst at religious meetings I have been instinctively welcomed?
('58', 363, 1, 4, 666485) And that happened even so early as 1915, when I had the good fortune to be practically an unknown man.
('58', 363, 1, 5, 666588) If you will but calmly examine the situation, you will discover that whether at Guruvayur or anywhere else, I am doing nothing but examining my claim and even yours by implication.
('58', 363, 1, 6, 666769) My reading of sanatan dharma has forced me to the conclusion that caste men have erred in treating a large number of Hindus as ‘untouchables’ and prohibiting them, amongst other things, from entering temples.
('58', 363, 1, 7, 666978) You hold that sanatan dharma obliges you to regard these very Hindus as ‘untouchables’ and, therefore, they are unfit, under any circum stances, to enter the temples on the same terms as yourself.
('58', 363, 1, 8, 667175) I say, let temple goers themselves make a choice of the two readings, and you throw yourself in a state of rage, because I advance such a simple pro position.
('58', 363, 1, 9, 667334) That, surely, is neither law nor common sense, nor toleration.
('58', 363, 1, 10, 667397) I am sure you would not deny me the right you have allowed to non Hindus, that is, of preaching their opinion so long as they do not adopt illegal, immoral or otherwise questionable methods.
('58', 363, 1, 11, 667588) You call my fast a species of coercion.
('58', 363, 1, 12, 667628) It ill becomes a sanatanist to describe a simple fast as coercion for, are not the pages of religious history filled with instances of fasting, whenever dharma had been in danger?
('58', 363, 1, 13, 667808) I will not insult your intelligence by citing notable illustrations in support of my statement.
('58', 363, 1, 14, 667904) But even the fast is off for the time being.
('58', 363, 1, 15, 667949) You then raise a hue and cry over a simple Bill such as Dr. Subbaroyan’s is, and shout that religion is in danger.
('58', 363, 1, 16, 668064) But if you were to examine this Bill, it again seeks to do nothing more than ascertain the wish of the parties concerned and to give effect to that wish.
('58', 363, 1, 17, 668218) If the British courts had not intervened at the instance of a sanatanist, if the mixed legislatures such as we now have, had not passed a measure of a religious character at the instance of Hindu legislators, this Bill would be unnecessary.
('58', 363, 1, 18, 668459) So, you see, it simply seeks to remove the obstruction created under modern conditions, and not to introduce innovations in Hinduism.
('58', 363, 1, 19, 668593) It is the British law, as it exists today, that makes it possible for a single individual to thwart the will of a whole host—may be even nine thousand nine hundred and ninety nine.
('58', 363, 1, 20, 668774) It may suit you today, but if you will give calm consideration to it, you will come to the
('58', 364, 0, 1, 668865) VOL. 58 : 16 NOVEMBER, 1932 14 JANUARY, 1933 365
('58', 364, 1, 2, 668914) conclusion that it is a most dangerous thing both for you and for me.
('58', 364, 1, 3, 668984) It is calculated to deaden religious life.
('58', 364, 1, 4, 669027) Sanatan dharma, and for that matter, all dharma, must give fair play.
('58', 364, 1, 5, 669097) You do not wish to play with loaded dice, as you would if this law was not altered.
('58', 364, 1, 6, 669181) I have suggested another test for the demonstration of the spirit of fair play, if there is any in you.
('58', 364, 1, 7, 669285) You will not deny that there are at least a respectable number of Hindus, if not a majority, who believe that it is consistent with the Hindu religion to admit Harijans to public temples.
('58', 364, 1, 8, 669473) I have therefore suggested a solution which is incapable of improvement from the fair play point of view.
('58', 364, 1, 9, 669579) It respects every prejudice and every scruple, and so far as Guruvayur is concerned and my solution is only confined for the moment to Guruvayur—it follows an established precedent, with but a variation.
('58', 364, 1, 10, 669783) Harijans have been admitted from time immemorial, without restriction along with other Hindus to that temple for full one day in the year.
('58', 364, 1, 11, 669922) There is, therefore nothing irreligious or extraordinary in my suggestion, that they should be always allowed, but only for certain hours in the day.
('58', 364, 1, 12, 670072) You may say there is purification after this mixing of the two on the Ekadasi day.
('58', 364, 1, 13, 670155) Repugnant as the idea is to me, if purification satisfied the scruples of the objectors, let there be a daily purification by all means.
('58', 364, 1, 14, 670292) All the letters I have received from sanatanists have protested that behind the sanatanists’ upholding of untouchability, there is no hatred.
('58', 364, 1, 15, 670434) The writers proclaim that though Harijans are children of God, equal with all others, religion demands their separation on high moral grounds, but that it should be carried out with love and not in hatred, and therefore, they should have full rights of citizenship.
('58', 364, 1, 16, 670700) Let us examine this claim in the light of the existing facts.
('58', 364, 1, 17, 670762) (1) Have you ascertained who are untouchables and why?
('58', 364, 1, 18, 670817) (2) Do you know why a subtle and in my opinion cruel social arrangement has made them landless?
('58', 364, 1, 19, 670913) If one happens to possess land, he cannot make the same use of it that you can.
('58', 364, 1, 20, 670993) (3) He cannot make use of the innumerable public utilities that you can; and you have provided no such separate utilities.
('58', 364, 1, 21, 671116) Therefore, he might die of thirst, and you would not help him to a drink of water.
('58', 364, 1, 22, 671199) (4) Careers that are open to you are tightly closed against him.
('58', 364, 1, 23, 671264) (5) Even medical assistance and spiritual assistance are denied to him.
('58', 364, 1, 24, 671336) If these are the fruits of love, will you not think with me that hate must be far more preferable to love?
('58', 364, 1, 25, 671443) I cannot think of anything
('58', 365, 0, 1, 671470) 366 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('58', 365, 1, 2, 671512) more bitter than the fruits I have pictured above.
('58', 365, 1, 3, 671563) I tell you that there is nothing like this on the face of the earth, and what is worse, bearing the stamp of religion.
('58', 365, 1, 4, 671682) I have addressed this appeal to you, which proceeds out of my soul’s agony.
('58', 365, 1, 5, 671758) I ask you to share that agony and shame with me, and co operate with me, for I have no other end to serve than to see sana tan dharma revivified and lived in its reality in the lives of millions who at present seem to me to deny it.
('58', 365, 1, 6, 671991) I am glad you are awakened, but you must now work and, instead of engaging in a perfectly fruitless quarrel with me, go through the catalogue of evils that have crept into Hinduism and make a giant effort to remove them.
('58', 365, 1, 7, 672212) I call your quarrel with me a fruitless effort, because I won’t be a party to it.
('58', 365, 1, 8, 672294) An English proverb has it, that it takes two to make a quarrel—happily I will not help you to make up the two.
('58', 365, 2, 9, 672405) The Hindu, 5 1 1933

('58', 369, 1, 3, 678388) As I used to say so often in London, he had every excuse for the bitterness with which only he could speak whenever he spoke about untouchability or of those touchable Hindus who had anything to do with it.
('58', 369, 1, 4, 678595) He has not only witnessed the inhuman wrongs done to the social pariahs of Hinduism, but in spite of all his culture, all the honours that he has received, he has, when he is in India, still to suffer many insults to which untouchables are exposed.
('58', 369, 1, 5, 678844) The wonder is that he is so tolerant and forbearing as he showed himself, for instance, at the time when the Yeravda Pact was being hammered into shape.

('58', 369, 1, 7, 679129) He will soften if the terms of the Yeravda Pact are carried out in full by the caste Hindus, but though things are shaping well on the whole, I am experiencing newer difficulties from day to day.
('58', 369, 1, 8, 679325) They do not dismay me.

('58', 369, 1, 14, 679853) Such is the contagious nature of this dreadful disease.

('58', 370, 1, 2, 680550) 523. LETTER TO BIRESWAR SEN
('58', 370, 2, 3, 680578) January 5, 1933
('58', 370, 3, 4, 680594) DEAR FRIEND, You have done well in writing to me.
('58', 370, 3, 5, 680644) If the analogy you have taken was correct, what you say will be quite true, but there is no ana logy between a public temple and a private house.
('58', 370, 3, 6, 680790) Public temples are the common property of Hindus or sects of Hindus, and members of those sects have a perfect right to regulate admission.
('58', 370, 3, 7, 680930) All I claim is just that and no more, the right of the temple goers of the existing temples to decide whether Harijans shall enter.
('58', 370, 3, 8, 681062) You are wrong also in thinking that my fast was a suicide.
('58', 370, 3, 9, 681121) A suicide is when a man does an act with the intention of ending his earthly existence.
('58', 370, 3, 10, 681209) I never had any such intention.
('58', 370, 3, 11, 681241) To my fast was atta ched a condition.
('58', 370, 3, 12, 681279) That you may still call it wrong is quite possible; only the fast could not be condemned on the ground you have advanced.
('58', 370, 4, 13, 681401) Yours sincerely, SJT.

('58', 375, 1, 2, 687554) 532. LETTER TO NARANDAS GANDHI
('58', 375, 2, 3, 687585) January 5, 1933
('58', 375, 3, 4, 687601) NARANDAS, I must content myself with the fewest letters today.
('58', 375, 3, 5, 687664) Tell all the people that I would have to write for Harijan and, therefore, they should not be surprised if I write fewer letters for some time.
('58', 375, 3, 6, 687808) Any body who has something to communicate may certainly write to me.
('58', 375, 3, 7, 687877) In any case the women and the children must write.
('58', 375, 3, 8, 687928) For them it is a kind of education too.
('58', 375, 3, 9, 687968) Even if I do not write in reply, they should continue to write.
('58', 375, 3, 10, 688032) After leaving school, Rambhau’s weight seems to have increased very much.
('58', 375, 3, 11, 688106) That seems to have happened to Shanti and Jaikore after they left the Ashram.
('58', 375, 3, 12, 688184) Try to discover the reason for this and, if you succeed, let me know it.
('58', 375, 3, 13, 688257) Two or three correspondents have complained in their letters that stray dogs loitering in the Ashram compound find nothing to eat and, therefore, try to eat shoes, etc.
('58', 375, 3, 14, 688426) If this is true, it does not mean that we should give them rotlas to eat.
('58', 375, 3, 15, 688500) You should send for a cart from the pinjrapole and the dogs should be removed in it, as used to be done in the past.
('58', 375, 3, 16, 688617) Probably you know that we have such an understanding with the pinjrapole.
('58', 375, 3, 17, 688691) You will even find in the office the correspondence which took place on this subject.
('58', 375, 3, 18, 688777) We should certainly think what we can do in cases like .
('58', 375, 3, 19, 688834) .’s 1. If a young man who has been living in the Ashram wishes to marry, it seems to me that we cannot immediately throw him on the streets.
('58', 375, 3, 20, 688975) We should be able to help them in some way.
('58', 375, 3, 21, 689019) I have not thought what we can do, or whether we can do anything.
('58', 375, 3, 22, 689085) The first thing to do is to consider whether we owe any duty to such persons.
('58', 375, 3, 23, 689163) If we do, then we will think further and may discover some way of helping.
('58', 375, 3, 24, 689238) You and other senior members may think about this and you may then let me know the view of you all.

('58', 376, 1, 2, 689524) 533. LETTER TO PRABHASHANKAR PATTANI
('58', 376, 2, 3, 689561) January 5, 1933
('58', 376, 3, 4, 689577) SUJNA BHAISHRI, I got your letter.
('58', 376, 3, 5, 689612) I am satisfied.
('58', 376, 3, 6, 689628) I also have full confidence that you will do your best.
('58', 376, 3, 7, 689684) By contribution I did not mean money.
('58', 376, 3, 8, 689722) Even an unknown child who approaches you for money will get it.
('58', 376, 3, 9, 689786) Don’t think I am so simple minded as to ask you for money.
('58', 376, 3, 10, 689845) For that, I would simply sign a hundi on you.
('58', 376, 3, 11, 689891) I want from you a much bigger contribution than that.
('58', 376, 3, 12, 689945) You can make it and I believe that you will.
('58', 376, 3, 13, 689990) I would not use coercion even to save a cow from the hands of a butcher.
('58', 376, 3, 14, 690063) I certainly don’t wish to use it to secure freedom for Harijans to enter temples, nor to make the Harijans give up beef, meat, etc.
('58', 376, 3, 15, 690195) But the latter tell me: ‘You force us to remove dead cattle and charge us for their flesh.
('58', 376, 3, 16, 690286) We, therefore, eat it and through long habit we have come to relish it.
('58', 376, 3, 17, 690358) So in the first place you should not charge us for the flesh, and secondly, should make some other arrangement for the removal of the dead cattle so that we may have no opportunity to remove their flesh.’ There is some cunning in this.
('58', 376, 3, 18, 690594) They know that we cannot make any other arrangement for the removal of dead cattle in theimmediate future, and some of them wish to exploit the situation.
('58', 376, 3, 19, 690749) They have a right to do so.
('58', 376, 3, 20, 690777) This is what anyone would do.
('58', 376, 3, 21, 690807) I suggest this step to the States.
('58', 376, 3, 22, 690842) The carcass of a dead cattle belongs, or should be considered as belonging, to the owner of the cattle.
('58', 376, 3, 23, 690946) Since he does not arrange for the proper disposal of the carcass, it means that he renounces his right over it.
('58', 376, 3, 24, 691058) It, therefore, becomes the property of the State, and the State should arrange for its disposal through Harijans by paying them suitably.
('58', 376, 3, 25, 691196) The State should also use every part of the body for public good.
('58', 376, 3, 26, 691262) If it does not do that, for the present it may utilize only the hide.
('58', 376, 3, 27, 691332) It may fix a reasonable price for the hide, and the Chamar or the Harijan concerned should pay it, deducting from it the charge for his labour.
('58', 376, 3, 28, 691476) Or, if separate cash payment is fixed for labour, he may have that and hand over the hide to the State.
('58', 376, 3, 29, 691580) The State should instruct its officer to see that at the time of the skinning of the carcass, the flesh and the bones which cannot be sold or utilized in any way are buried deep at a spot fixed for the purpose.
('58', 376, 3, 30, 691791) This will of course show the ignorance of the State.
('58', 377, 0, 1, 691844) 378 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('58', 377, 1, 2, 691886) prudent State can make profitable use of the flesh and the bones.
('58', 377, 1, 3, 691952) If you wish to know how this can be done, I will explain that in another letter.
('58', 377, 1, 4, 692033) Just now, I have only suggested the easiest and simplest way, one which can be immediately adopted, of making the Chamars give up the practice of eating beef and carrion.
('58', 377, 1, 5, 692204) At present, besides the hide and the flesh, the other parts of the carcass are not utilized at all.
('58', 377, 1, 6, 692304) They can be easily utilized.
('58', 377, 1, 7, 692333) But since that is not relevant to my purpose in writing this letter, I have saved your time and mine by not entering into a discussion of it.
('58', 377, 1, 8, 692475) I hope you will be able to read my handwriting and will get my point.
('58', 377, 1, 9, 692545) I am quite well.
('58', 377, 1, 10, 692562) Why do you feel that you have grown old?
('58', 377, 1, 11, 692603) Why do you believe that the body has become old, even though you continue to work?
('58', 377, 1, 12, 692686) You enforce laws on others, but yourself do not obey the laws of good health.
('58', 377, 1, 13, 692764) Who should punish you for that?
('58', 377, 2, 14, 692796) Vandemataram from
('58', 377, 3, 15, 692814) MOHANDAS

('58', 378, 1, 2, 693256) 535. INTERVIEW TO ASSOCIATED PRESS OF INDIA 1
('58', 378, 2, 3, 693302) January 5, 1933 In my opinion, No.
('58', 378, 2, 4, 693337) What my proposal does is to respect the prejudices of a class of temple goers who still feel that they would be doing something wrong in associating with Harijans at the time of entering temples, and since this reform movement is not one of com pulsion but conversion, my proposal is intended to respect the scru ples even of one single conscientious objector.
('58', 378, 2, 5, 693698) In a matter, essen tially of religion, so far as it is possible one would avoid carrying out the will of the majority.
('58', 378, 2, 6, 693817) By this compromise, such an objector can, during certain hours of the day, offer worship as he used to, before the reforms.
('58', 378, 2, 7, 693941) Underlying my proposal is undoubtedly the belief or assumption that at Guruvayur (because my compromise is for the present moment confined only to Guruvayur) a large majority of caste Hindus are in favour of admission of the Harijans to that temple.
('58', 378, 2, 8, 694191) If, when the compromise is accepted and put into practice, it is found to be otherwise, then, I admit the distinction is still maintained.
('58', 378, 2, 9, 694330) If on the other hand the majority remain with the Harijans, then it would be a mark of generous self restraint on the part of the Harijans and the majority of temple goers.
('58', 378, 2, 10, 694503) If reformers are found to be in a minority, it would be a question for considerationas to whether the Harijans should take advantage of the compromise or not.
('58', 378, 2, 11, 694662) After all it is the essence of compromise that it must be a half way house between the two extreme positions without, of course, involving any surrender of principles by either party.
('58', 378, 2, 12, 694846) In this proposed compromise, the principle on behalf of the Harijans and the reformers is that the two should offer worship on terms of equality.
('58', 378, 2, 13, 694992) The period during which the worship may be offered is not an essential part.
('58', 378, 2, 14, 695069) The principle on the part of the objectors is that they cannot offer worship side by side with the Harij ans without doing violence to their religious sense.
('58', 378, 2, 15, 695227) This objection I promise to respect in its entirety, but only limit the period during which they can offer worship consistently with their objection.
('58', 378, 3, 16, 695377) The Bombay Chronicle, 6 1 1933
('58', 378, 4, 17, 695408) 1 The correspondent had asked Gandhiji whether the compromise regarding entry of Harijans into Guruvayur Temple (vide “Interview to the Associated Press of India”, 2 1 1933) still retained untouchability to a certain extent.

('58', 379, 5, 6, 695898) 537. LETTER TO JOHN MORRIS
('58', 379, 6, 7, 695925) January 6, 1933
('58', 379, 7, 8, 695941) MY DEAR FRIEND JOHN MORRIS, I was much touched to receive your wonderful letter and the Christmas card, both of which reached me in due time.
('58', 379, 7, 9, 696083) I have always treasured the memory of that early morning visit to your hospital and the handshake.

('58', 380, 1, 2, 697243) 538. LETTER TO MADELEINE ROLLAND 1
('58', 380, 2, 3, 697278) January 6, 1933
('58', 380, 3, 4, 697294) MY DEAR MADELEINE, It was a great joy to receive your brief letter, especially as it recalled the precious days of communion with you all.
('58', 380, 3, 5, 697433) It was like meeting members of one’s family.
('58', 380, 3, 6, 697478) If the events at the time of the late fast 2 were a miracle, as they were, it was purely God’s work.
('58', 380, 3, 7, 697579) I was but a very humble instrument in His hands.
('58', 380, 3, 8, 697628) At no stage did I feel that I was doing anything.
('58', 380, 3, 9, 697678) I simply could not do it, but when I said that it was God working through me, it was literally true, as far as my knowledge went.
('58', 380, 3, 10, 697808) But I observe from your great and good brother’s 3 telegram to Devdas that people on the Continent had not understood the contemplated second fast.
('58', 380, 3, 11, 697956) I don’t wonder at it.
('58', 380, 3, 12, 697978) The whole conception seems to be so new, and yet it appears to me to be the logical outcome of a prayerful search after truth.
('58', 380, 3, 13, 698105) There is no prayer without fasting, and fasting which is not an integral part of prayer is mere torture of the flesh doing no good to anyone.
('58', 380, 3, 14, 698247) Such fasting is an intense spiritual effort, a spiritual striving.
('58', 380, 3, 15, 698314) It is a penance and a process of self puri fication.
('58', 380, 3, 16, 698367) True fast generates a silent unseen force which may, if it is of requisite strength and purity, pervade all mankind.
('58', 380, 3, 17, 698484) I have seen its unseen pervasive effect on a small scale but sufficiently large to know that it is a mighty force.
('58', 380, 3, 18, 698599) It was in this instance an inevitable step in the prosecution of the campaign against untouchability.
('58', 380, 3, 19, 698701) I would have been false to myself, to my companion Kelappan and tothe cause of the Harijans, if I had faltered.
('58', 380, 3, 20, 698813) At the present moment, however, it stands indefinitely postponed.
('58', 380, 3, 21, 698879) Even now, perhaps, I have not made myself clear.
('58', 380, 3, 22, 698928) It is difficult to do so.
('58', 380, 3, 23, 698954) But I have no hesitation in saying that time will prove the correctness of the step, and in any case for me it was a call from God which I could not resist.
('58', 380, 3, 24, 699111) If a further explana tion is necessary, please do not hesitate to write to me.
('58', 380, 3, 25, 699190) I have been tying to find out a suitable adjective for your brother.
('58', 380, 3, 26, 699259) To write of him to you as ‘Mons.
('58', 380, 3, 27, 699292) Rolland’ or as ‘your brother’ sounds too prosaic and distant.
('58', 380, 3, 28, 699354) To describe him as simple
('58', 380, 4, 29, 699380) 1 A copy of this letter was sent to Mirabehn.
('58', 380, 4, 30, 699426) 2 Gandhiji’s fast of September 1932. 3 Romain Rolland
('58', 381, 0, 1, 699480) 382 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('58', 381, 1, 2, 699522) ‘brother’ is too familiar and does not convey adequately the existing relationship.
('58', 381, 1, 3, 699606) The two words that come to me are ‘rishi’ or ‘the sage’.
('58', 381, 1, 4, 699663) They are almost synonymous terms but not identical in meaning.
('58', 381, 1, 5, 699726) Subject therefore to his and your approval, I am going henceforth to describe him as “the Rishi’.
('58', 381, 1, 6, 699824) I hope that this letter will find him in full possession of his normal health.
('58', 381, 1, 7, 699903) I am afraid one dare not hope for perfect health for him.
('58', 381, 1, 8, 699961) He will not give it all that chance.
('58', 381, 1, 9, 699998) It would mean concentration on physical health at the expense of concentra tion on his historical researches, and with him historical is also spiritual, or else he would not be a rishi.
('58', 381, 1, 10, 700184) Please tell the Rishi that some months ago I had for the first time his volumes on Ramakrishna and Vivekananda.

('58', 383, 1, 2, 703383) 541. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('58', 383, 2, 3, 703411) January 7, 1933 Of late several Congressmen have been to me and told me that there is much suppressed talk among them about my action in setting up an agitation against untouchability from within the prison walls and that they do not know whether to prosecute civil disobedience or to take an active part in the campaign against untouchability.
('58', 383, 2, 4, 703756) I do not wonder at the question.
('58', 383, 2, 5, 703789) All I have been able to tell these questioners is this: ‘For me there is nothing inconsistent in my conduct.
('58', 383, 2, 6, 703898) It would be foolish, if not sinful, for me if I did not use all the talents that my Master has given me, whenever I have the opportunity for their use.
('58', 383, 2, 7, 704050) I have used all the talents, I have for civil disobedience.
('58', 383, 2, 8, 704110) I found that I had also talents for the service of Harijans which I could use, and I am using them.
('58', 383, 2, 9, 704210) In doing so I have abated nothing from my existing dharma or obligation.
('58', 383, 2, 10, 704283) I have added service of the untouchables to it.
('58', 383, 2, 11, 704331) I had therefore no question before me of making a choice.
('58', 383, 2, 12, 704389) With those who are outside prison walls, the case, I know, is different.
('58', 383, 2, 13, 704462) Those who are civil resisters have to decide whether to continue civil disobe dience or to take up anti untouchability work.
('58', 383, 2, 14, 704587) This is a question I cannot decide for them.
('58', 383, 2, 15, 704632) I am constitutionally unfit, having entered the prison gates, to guide the movement of civil disobedience in any shape or form.
('58', 383, 2, 16, 704760) And even if I thought otherwise, I must not guide it as I have bound myself in honour not to take advantage of the conside rable latitude given to me regarding untouchability by directly or in directly and secretly or openly guiding the movement.
('58', 383, 2, 17, 705007) Everyone therefore has to take his or her decision without reference to me.’ Having adopted this attitude, I have refused to guide even my wife and my son.
('58', 383, 2, 18, 705163) My appeal for the removal of untouchability lies to every caste Hindu, be he a Congressman or other.
('58', 383, 2, 19, 705264) For the resolution of Bombay arrived at during the Fast Week pledges the honour of every Hindu to remove untouchability, so far as he or she is perso nally concerned and to induce his or her neighbours to do likewise.
('58', 383, 2, 20, 705482) The first part is a mere mental performance accompanied by personal conduct wherever corresponding action is called for.
('58', 383, 2, 21, 705603) The second, that is, the propaganda part, requires everyone to make the choice between propaganda and his or her present work, where the former cannot be added to the latter.
('58', 384, 0, 1, 705778) VOL. 58 : 16 NOVEMBER, 1932 14 JANUARY, 1933 385
('58', 384, 1, 2, 705827) Congressmen who are civil resisters are undoubtedly presented with a conundrum; but that would be only if they would make the vain effort of reading my mind.
('58', 384, 1, 3, 705985) I think I have made it clear that I have no mind whatsoever for them.
('58', 384, 1, 4, 706055) When I decided to conduct the untouchability campaign from within the prison, I had not civil resis ters in my mind as such, but I had the whole of Hindu society.
('58', 384, 1, 5, 706218) If that whole fails to respond, civil resisters alone cannot remove the age long evil.
('58', 384, 1, 6, 706305) But a civil resister may well feel a special call for doing untouchability work, or, he or she may think that there is no disciplined resistance left in him or her, or that the spirit of resistance is played out, or even that there is no such thing as civil resistance and that all resistance is necessarily uncivil or incivil.
('58', 384, 1, 7, 706633) It is obvious that I can offer no useful guidance in the consideration of these problems.
('58', 384, 1, 8, 706723) These are all matters for those who are outside to judge.
('58', 384, 1, 9, 706781) If many are filled with doubts, let them confer together and come to a decision as to the proper course to take.
('58', 384, 1, 10, 706894) Those who have no doubts may be reminded of the celebrated Sanskrit verse 1 whose exact equivalent perhaps is to be found in the equallycelebrated English proverb, “Much wants more and loses all”.
('58', 384, 2, 11, 707091) M. K. GANDHI
('58', 384, 3, 12, 707104) From a photostat: C.W. 9694

('58', 389, 4, 12, 715365) 549. A LETTER
('58', 389, 5, 13, 715379) January 7, 1933 There is also one more thing about all this unnecessary trave lling.
('58', 389, 5, 14, 715464) Even the inmates of the Ashram do not show sincere love of simplicity.
('58', 389, 5, 15, 715535) This is not only your defect.
('58', 389, 5, 16, 715565) Even some of the inmates who have been longer in the Ashram than you are not free from it.
('58', 389, 5, 17, 715656) Nevertheless, I do wish to explain to those who will listen to me that it is our duty to live as the poorest among the poor do.
('58', 389, 5, 18, 715784) We should not spend two pice where we can do with one and we should take whatever risks this may involve.
('58', 389, 5, 19, 715890) We should, therefore, avoid travelling as far as possible and renounce as many facilities and conveniences as we can.
('58', 389, 5, 20, 716008) We should practise such strict economy not only in money matters but also in our activities.
('58', 389, 5, 21, 716101) We should be miserly even in our speech and thinking.
('58', 389, 5, 22, 716155) Only then shall we be able to follow truth and ahimsa and observe brahmacharya.
('58', 389, 5, 23, 716235) Try and overcome this deficiency in you.
('58', 389, 5, 24, 716276) Do not answer me, nor think in your mind, that A, B and C in the Ashram spend more than you do.
('58', 389, 5, 25, 716372) The path of dharma is for him who chooses to follow it.
('58', 389, 5, 26, 716428) And now for the question which you have asked.
('58', 389, 5, 27, 716475) If we measure our children from our experience of the strength of our own passions, we shall never succeed in our aim.
('58', 389, 5, 28, 716594) We did not have the benefit of the environment which, learning from our own experience, we have created for the children.
('58', 389, 5, 29, 716716) We should have faith that it is bound to produce an effect on them.
('58', 389, 5, 30, 716784) We need not worry if we see no such effect immediately.
('58', 389, 5, 31, 716840) It may be that in making this experiment we shall sacrifice our own children.
('58', 389, 5, 32, 716918) Still we should not lose faith.
('58', 389, 5, 33, 716950) Our efforts will be rewarded with success only if we continue the experiment as
('58', 390, 0, 1, 717030) VOL. 58 : 16 NOVEMBER, 1932 14 JANUARY, 1933 391
('58', 390, 1, 2, 717079) long as we do not see any error in it.
('58', 390, 1, 3, 717118) The path is like the flame of the sacrificial fire and, therefore, we should offer ourselves and our children as oblation in it with a smiling face.
('58', 390, 1, 4, 717267) Unless we act thus in all spheres of our activities, we shall not get a vision of perfect truth, ahimsa or brahmacharya, or we shall arrive at the conclusion that one or both of those principles are wrong.
('58', 390, 1, 5, 717473) There are a good many schools of thought which regard ahimsa as a wrong ideal, and we see before our very eyes how the numbers of those who look upon brahma charya as a sin keep growing.
('58', 390, 1, 6, 717660) If, despite that, we wish todemonstrate that the ideal of brahmacharya is the right one and that those who oppose it are mistaken, we shall have to learn to sacrifice a boy like .
('58', 390, 1, 7, 717840) 1 and a girl like .
('58', 390, 1, 8, 717860) 2 We cannot sacrifice the children of others.
('58', 390, 1, 9, 717906) We should give that privilege to our own children.
('58', 390, 1, 10, 717957) But you say that our children, too, can be regarded to have passed the test only if they remain above the waves when they are thrown into the sea of life outside.
('58', 390, 1, 11, 718120) I agree with you, and that is why we have made the Ashram an arm of that sea.
('58', 390, 1, 12, 718198) If we do not sink in it, we can hope to be able to swim even in the great ocean of life.
('58', 390, 2, 13, 718287) [From Gujarati]

('58', 393, 1, 2, 722434) 554. LETTER TO HEMPRABHA DAS GUPTA
('58', 393, 2, 3, 722469) January 7, 1933
('58', 393, 3, 4, 722485) HEMPRABHA, A nice long letter from you has arrived after a long interval.
('58', 393, 3, 5, 722559) Let me point out your fault which is not the one you regard as such.
('58', 393, 3, 6, 722628) Your fault lies in being too greedy.
('58', 393, 3, 7, 722665) “Bapu is working for the Harijans, so I must do that too.” Keep away from what Bapu has taken up and stick to what you were already doing.
('58', 393, 3, 8, 722804) That too was service and consumed all your time.
('58', 393, 3, 9, 722853) “Better one’s own duty, bereft of merit, than another’s well performed.” 1 You should be satisfied with what ever falls to your lot.
('58', 393, 3, 10, 722986) Greed even for good works is to be eschewed.
('58', 393, 3, 11, 723031) “Excess is to be avoided in every matter.” You can give up Harijan service even now.
('58', 393, 3, 12, 723116) You wish to work for your “Bapu”, don’t you?
('58', 393, 3, 13, 723161) Bapu will be fully satisfied with khadi work alone.
('58', 393, 3, 14, 723213) Your attempt to do both jobs will deprive you of both as the body will be unable to stand the strain.
('58', 393, 3, 15, 723315) Khadi work involves sufficient Harijan service; be content with this.
('58', 393, 3, 16, 723385) You have to be above attachment.
('58', 393, 3, 17, 723418) Greed is another name for attachment, this is my reading.
('58', 393, 3, 18, 723476) If you do not concur, forget it.
('58', 393, 3, 19, 723509) “Do as you wish.” As you always do good you can never come to grief.
('58', 393, 3, 20, 723578) God is ever with you, He will never forsake you.

('58', 394, 1, 10, 724823) If each were to be examined separately as to what they hold in reverence and what they will endeavour to put into practice, the answer would be different.

('58', 401, 11, 16, 735440) 569. LETTER TO PARMANANDA K. KAPADIA
('58', 401, 12, 17, 735477) January 8, 1933 The explanation about Guruvayur is contained in your own statement.
('58', 401, 12, 18, 735561) It is literally true that the issue is an offshoot of the withdrawal of the Cabinet decision.
('58', 401, 12, 19, 735655) Ever since I came to India, I have been impressing on people the importance of a pledge, but I see that it is not readily accepted even by persons like you.
('58', 401, 12, 20, 735812) At the time of the withdrawal of the decision, a pledge was taken in the name of the people under the leadership of a great man like Malaviyaji.
('58', 401, 12, 21, 735957) Can we now forget the pledge even for a moment and still hope to win swaraj?
('58', 401, 12, 22, 736034) People should now act with a greater sense of urgency for the removal of untouchability than they thought it necessary to do for the with drawal of the decision.
('58', 401, 12, 23, 736196) It would not matter if they do not succeed immediately.
('58', 401, 12, 24, 736252) But the tempo of this campaign should be faster than that of the movement for the withdrawal of the decision.
('58', 401, 12, 25, 736362) Why do you
('58', 401, 13, 26, 736373) 1Addressee’s daughter whom Gandhiji had adopted and brought up in the Ashram
('58', 402, 0, 1, 736450) VOL. 58 : 16 NOVEMBER, 1932 14 JANUARY, 1933 403
('58', 402, 1, 2, 736499) believe that swaraj is something apart from the eradication of untou chability?
('58', 402, 1, 3, 736579) Swaraj is not like a straight rod.
('58', 402, 1, 4, 736614) It is rather like a banyan tree.
('58', 402, 1, 5, 736647) The latter has innumerable branches each of which is as impor tant for the tree as the original trunk.
('58', 402, 1, 6, 736750) Feeding any of them means feeding the tree.
('58', 402, 1, 7, 736794) Nobody can lay down a rule as to which of the branches should be fed when.
('58', 402, 1, 8, 736869) Circumstances determine that.
('58', 402, 1, 9, 736899) Kelappan’s mistake was a very small one.
('58', 402, 1, 10, 736940) If, after having persuaded him to give up his fast, I had abandoned him, I am sure all of you would have left me in the end.
('58', 402, 1, 11, 737065) Anybody who forsakes an humble co worker at a difficult hour is a man of straw.
('58', 402, 1, 12, 737145) ` Your other questions can be convincingly answered, but they lie outside the limits of my present freedom.
('58', 402, 1, 13, 737253) If I am alive, I will explain them some other time.
('58', 402, 1, 14, 737305) My fasts never spring from despair or frus tration.
('58', 402, 1, 15, 737357) They have their source in my undying optimism and intense faith.
('58', 402, 1, 16, 737422) Nor are they as cheap as you think.
('58', 402, 1, 17, 737458) If the last fast had not been postponed, I would have violated dharma.
('58', 402, 1, 18, 737529) But I cannot explain all this fully just now.
('58', 402, 1, 19, 737575) The fact is that I am making my experiment in the quest of truth along a new line altogether.
('58', 402, 1, 20, 737669) New ideas, therefore, occur to me at every step—they are new even to me—and are placed before the nation.
('58', 402, 1, 21, 737775) How can all of them be understood by the people immediately?
('58', 402, 1, 22, 737836) And I also cannot explainthem freely.
('58', 402, 1, 23, 737874) But truth does not require many words to explain it–if in fact it requires any.
('58', 402, 1, 24, 737954) It has the power of spreading by itself, like the fragrance of a flower.
('58', 402, 1, 25, 738027) The difference between the two is that fragrance disappears as quickly as it spreads, whereas truth continues to spread indefinitely and with even greater speed.
('58', 402, 1, 26, 738189) Since we cannot measure that speed, we make the mistake of believing that truth does not spread.
('58', 402, 1, 27, 738286) You should, therefore, have patience and faith and never give way to despair.
('58', 402, 1, 28, 738364) [From Gujarati]
('58', 402, 2, 29, 738380) Mahadevbhaini Diary, Vol. III, pp.

('58', 404, 1, 2, 740427) and told you that I did not know even that Manilal had complained.
('58', 404, 1, 3, 740494) Do you have personal knowledge of his having complained?
('58', 404, 1, 4, 740551) If you have it, your first duty as a gentleman and as a relation was to write to him.
('58', 404, 1, 5, 740637) I am willing to write to him if you give me some evidence of his misdeeds.
('58', 404, 1, 6, 740712) Apart from that, I don’t know what to say about your suggestion as to whom I should put up with.
('58', 404, 1, 7, 740809) I do not think that I am so good a man that I should never put up with a person whom the people believe to be a bad man.
('58', 404, 1, 8, 740930) I myself am a bad man, and still I live in my house.
('58', 404, 1, 9, 740983) Would it be proper for me, then, if I try to sit in judgment over others?
('58', 404, 1, 10, 741057) Moreover, how can a man, who daily wanders from place to place and eats and sleeps at other people’s places, afford to be too particular about the place where he puts up.
('58', 404, 1, 11, 741228) I, therefore, follow one rule, namely, to regard all strangers as my kith and kin.
('58', 404, 1, 12, 741311) My own relations remain so inany case.
('58', 404, 1, 13, 741350) I do not agree with the principle, if you have laid down any such for yourself, that one must not lodge a criminal complaint against one’s relations, no matter what wicked things they do, but one may do so against strangers.
('58', 404, 1, 14, 741575) However that may be, I ought to tell you, as I told Khimchand some months ago, that I have not the least trust in him.
('58', 404, 1, 15, 741694) You may also know that Manilal is not the cause of my distrust.
('58', 404, 1, 16, 741758) It is Khimchand’s own letters one after another which have increased my distrust of him.
('58', 404, 1, 17, 741847) You may see now how much worry and trouble you have created for me.
('58', 404, 1, 18, 741915) And still you ask for forgiveness, but I don’t think, you expect to receive it.
('58', 404, 1, 19, 741995) But you are free to do whatever you like and so are safe.
('58', 404, 2, 20, 742053) Vandemataram from

('58', 412, 5, 10, 753410) 587. LETTER TO NARANDAS GANDHI
('58', 412, 6, 11, 753441) January 9, 1933
('58', 412, 7, 12, 753457) NARANDAS, You will find with this a letter from Kanhaiyalal to Ghan shyamdasji.
('58', 412, 7, 13, 753537) Do you know anything about it?
('58', 412, 7, 14, 753568) If you do not, it was improper for an inmate of the Ashram to have applied for help to an outsider, particularly to a friend of the Ashram.
('58', 412, 7, 15, 753708) Kanhaiyalal him self may not have been aware of any impropriety when writing the letter, but this incident makes it necessary to warn everybody.
('58', 412, 7, 16, 753853) It is assumed that those who join the Ashram do so in a spirit of renun ciation.
('58', 412, 7, 17, 753934) Hence, while they live in the Ashram, they should not seek help from outside even for their work of service.
('58', 412, 7, 18, 754043) When giving such a warning to the inmates of the Ashram, it is not necessary to mention Kanhaiy alal’s name.
('58', 412, 7, 19, 754152) I am writing to him too.
('58', 412, 7, 20, 754177) I have already written 1 to you suggesting that Jamna should try fenugreek seeds.
('58', 412, 7, 21, 754259) A letter from Kishorelal just received gives a little more information.
('58', 412, 7, 22, 754331) The discovery about the efficacy of these seeds is his own.
('58', 412, 7, 23, 754391) He eats about 20 25 seeds in the morning and the same num ber in the evening.
('58', 412, 7, 24, 754469) He roasts them till they become red.
('58', 412, 7, 25, 754506) He says that they may even be eaten fried in ghee.
('58', 412, 7, 26, 754557) There is a possibility that they may bring about constipation.
('58', 412, 7, 27, 754620) If that happens, Jamna may reduce the quantity.
('58', 412, 7, 28, 754668) If 20 25 seeds have no effect, she can increase the quantity up to 50 60 grains.
('58', 412, 7, 29, 754749) Kishorelal had started with that number.
('58', 412, 8, 30, 754790) 1Vide “Letter to Narandas Gandhi”, 1 1 1933.

('58', 414, 4, 9, 756637) I do accept the Shastras as authoritative.

('58', 414, 6, 17, 757007) 591. LETTER TO NANASAHEB KHASGIWALE
('58', 414, 7, 18, 757043) January 9, 1933 I believe in the injunctions of the Shastras, as also in custom and the practice of respected men and women.
('58', 414, 7, 19, 757168) But the inner voice springs from the cumulative effect of all these.
('58', 414, 7, 20, 757237) It is the moving force behind the whole world.
('58', 414, 7, 21, 757284) It is no exclusive virtue or defect of mine.
('58', 414, 7, 22, 757329) My inner voice may certainly be imperfect, as everybody else’s.
('58', 414, 7, 23, 757393) That is why man has been regarded as the embodiment of errors.
('58', 414, 7, 24, 757456) If there truly exists an untouchable class in the human race I am striving to be born only into that and no other.
('58', 414, 7, 25, 757571) My whole inclination is towards a revival of the varnashrama dharma; I have no doubt about it.
('58', 414, 7, 26, 757666) To spend thought or anything else on an irrelevant matter is against my nature.
('58', 414, 7, 27, 757746) Devotion to Krishna is the keynote of my life; and sanatan dharma is my very life breath.
('58', 414, 7, 28, 757836) One day those who at present call themselves sanatanists will accept the truth of this avowal of mine.
('58', 414, 8, 29, 757939) [From Hindi]
('58', 414, 9, 30, 757952) Mahadevbhaini Diary, Vol. III, p.
('58', 414, 10, 31, 757986) 1Vide “With Bare Religious Rites”, 7 3 1926.

('58', 416, 4, 6, 760070) 594. LETTER TO R. V. PATWARDHAN
('58', 416, 5, 7, 760102) January 10, 1933
('58', 416, 6, 8, 760119) DEAR FRIEND, I have your letter 1. I think you have mixed argument with curses and you have addressed your argument to a state of things that does not exist.
('58', 416, 6, 9, 760277) I would therefore ask you to adopt a dispassionate attitude and study this question as a student studies and works at problems.
('58', 416, 6, 10, 760405) If you will do that, many of the eight points that you have raised will fall to pieces.
('58', 416, 6, 11, 760493) For instance, when you have studied the question dispassio nately and properly you will discover as to your first point that there is no question of ‘molesting’ a single Hindu temple; as to your second point that there is no legislation attempted in the matter of temple entry, what is attempted is to remove an artificial barrier created by a foreign Court of Law; as to the third, that you should say with me those who seek equity or justice should come with clean hands.
('58', 416, 7, 12, 760967) Yours sincerely,
('58', 416, 8, 13, 760984) From a microfilm: S.N. 19210
('58', 416, 9, 14, 761013) 1Dated December 9, 1933 which read: “I solemnly warn you that you do not appear to be acting as a God fearing Hindu; and although you may succeed in forcing the entry of the untouchables into our temples .
('58', 416, 9, 15, 761219) all honest sanatanists will always regard your act as a sacrilegious deed becoming an atheist .
('58', 416, 9, 16, 761315) .” (S.N. 19206).

('58', 417, 6, 10, 761723) 596. LETTER TO N. H. PURANDARE
('58', 417, 7, 11, 761754) January 10, 1933
('58', 417, 8, 12, 761771) MY DEAR PURANDARE, I have your letter.
('58', 417, 8, 13, 761810) I am sorry for the mistakes that still remain in your book 2. As to the remuneration, I have accepted, without demur, the figure mentioned by Haribhau.
('58', 417, 8, 14, 761962) I hope that the amount has been paid to you already.
('58', 417, 8, 15, 762015) Five copies of any new edition for the translation should certainly be given to you.
('58', 417, 8, 16, 762100) I hope you have five copies of the first edition.
('58', 417, 8, 17, 762150) I don’t like the spirit of the rest of your letter.
('58', 417, 8, 18, 762202) There never can be any question of anyone making a personal profit.

('58', 423, 8, 14, 772183) 607. STATEMENT TO ASSOCIATED PRESS
('58', 423, 9, 15, 772218) January 11, 1933
('58', 423, 10, 16, 772235) I observe that there is a lot of misunderstanding about the compro mise proposal 2 I have made in connection with the temple entry question, and I see that there is dissatisfaction over it even among Harijans.
('58', 423, 10, 17, 772445) That dissatisfaction is quite natural.
('58', 423, 10, 18, 772484) Where inequality is ram pant, anything that savours of it is immediately suspected and conde mned.
('58', 423, 10, 19, 772583) I have however every faith in my proposal and in spite of the criticisms directed against it, I see no reason to withdraw it.
('58', 423, 10, 20, 772709) If any single temple is opened according to that proposal, it would be found not only workable in practice, but that Harijans, who are now suspecting in it inequality and a surrender to orthodox opinion, will see that, while it takes that opinion into full account, it surrenders nothing of the principle, namely, that Harijans should be admitted to temples, if at all, on terms of absolute equality with the rest of the Hindus.
('58', 423, 10, 21, 773138) But since there can be no compulsion in religion, prejudices, which amount to belief for those who hold them,
('58', 423, 11, 22, 773248) 1The remaining pages of the exercise book are blank.
('58', 423, 11, 23, 773301) 2 Vide “Interview to the Associated Press of India”, 2 1 1933.
('58', 424, 0, 1, 773364) VOL. 58 : 16 NOVEMBER, 1932 14 JANUARY, 1933 425
('58', 424, 1, 2, 773413) must be respected, in so far as that respect is consistent with the main thing.
('58', 424, 1, 3, 773493) There is then needed a formula whereby such objectors will not be deprived of the religious consolation to which they are en titled.
('58', 424, 1, 4, 773626) That can only be done if there is some period fixed during which they can have their darshan 1 in isolation.
('58', 424, 1, 5, 773735) However unreasonable it may appear to reformers, as it does to me, the sentiment undoubtedly exists that the efficacy of the idol is dimi nished, if not altogether destroyed, by the presence of certain people in the temple in which it is installed.
('58', 424, 1, 6, 773984) It is not possible to make the people who harbour that sentiment give it up by force of law or arms.
('58', 424, 1, 7, 774085) That can only disappear either through an appeal to reason or through experience gained from those who act contrariwise, and yet do not suffer any misfortune which can be directly connected with their giving up that particular sentiment.
('58', 424, 1, 8, 774323) I am sure that Harijans do not want to cause vio lence to the feelings of any single person in their legitimate demand to vindicate their status in Hinduism.
('58', 424, 1, 9, 774481) This is a period of grace.
('58', 424, 1, 10, 774508) Caste Hindus are on their trial.
('58', 424, 1, 11, 774541) Either the Resolution 2 arrived at last September at the meeting in Bombay has the backing of the general mass of the caste Hindu or it has not.
('58', 424, 1, 12, 774686) If it has, the temples must be voluntarily flung open to Harijans and if the majority of the temple goers show their desire in no unmistakable terms for such admission, the Resolution must be regarded as fully vindicated.
('58', 424, 1, 13, 774908) Cent per cent assent is almost an impossibility in human affairs, and in a mattes of religion dissenters ought to be taken into consideration.
('58', 424, 1, 14, 775051) My proposal does that, and nothing more.
('58', 424, 1, 15, 775092) It is an acid test for all.
('58', 424, 1, 16, 775120) The dissenters are in a minority, and sincere in their conviction but tolerant to their opponents.
('58', 424, 1, 17, 775219) After having made every provision for themselves, they would make equal provision for their opponents.
('58', 424, 1, 18, 775322) If the reformers be equally sincere and tolerant towards the dissenters, they will make adequate provision for the dissenters’ being able to offer worship according to their wont.
('58', 424, 1, 19, 775502) If Harijans have no desire whatever to coerce anybody so long as they can exercise equal rights with the reformers, they should have nothing to complain of at all.
('58', 424, 1, 20, 775666) My proposal is undoubtedly based on the assumption that upon
('58', 424, 2, 21, 775727) 1 Sight of a person, place or thing considered holy 1 Vide “Resolution at the Hindu Leaders’ Conference, Bombay”, 25 9 1932.
('58', 425, 0, 1, 775852) 426 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('58', 425, 1, 2, 775894) a referendum, a large majority of the temple goers would vote for the admission of Harijans to temples, and that, therefore, they would visit temples only during the joint hours, and would not visit them during the time set apart for the dissenters.
('58', 425, 1, 3, 776144) If, in practice, it is discovered that the reformers are a negligible quantity, they would naturally abstain from making use of such temples and if the majority of the temples show such an unfortunate minority they will rightly conclude that the Bombay Resolution has not the backing of the caste Hindus
('58', 425, 2, 4, 776448) But say Harijan friends: ‘What about the purification against which you have so often written and spoken?’ Of course, I am as much against purification now as ever.
('58', 425, 2, 5, 776613) If purification remains a general law, then untouchability remains.
('58', 425, 2, 6, 776681) But purification under my proposal assumes a different shape altogether.
('58', 425, 2, 7, 776754) Do we not do many things in order to respect the sentiments of our friends and tolerate many more?
('58', 425, 2, 8, 776853) The question before Harijans, before Hindu society and before the whole world is whether caste Hindus, as a whole, have undergone a change of heart, and whether they are ready to abolish untouchability as it is practised today.
('58', 425, 2, 9, 777081) If the majority of the caste Hindus vote for its abolition, surely, it is the duty of both reformers and Harijans to accommodate the minority that may notsee eye to eye with the reformers, when their difference is based on what is to them a deep religious conviction.
('58', 425, 2, 10, 777349) Mutual toleration is the law of the human family, and what my proposal has done is to rigidly enforce that principle.
('58', 425, 3, 11, 777467) I would like, in one sentence, to emphasize the fact that the present campaign is one against untouchability as it is practised today in Hindu ism, and not against untouchability which is, in some shape or form, common to mankind.
('58', 425, 3, 12, 777698) Such untouchability does not attach to a person, but to his work or to his conduct.
('58', 425, 3, 13, 777782) It is not sought to gain complete freedom from the laws of cleanliness and hygiene and the like, the observance of which is obligatory on every temple goer, even at the present day.
('58', 425, 3, 14, 777964) But what is insisted upon is that every Harijan who conforms to these laws is entitled to admission to all public temples on terms of equality with the rest.
('58', 425, 4, 15, 778122) The Hindu, 12 1 1933

('58', 429, 2, 3, 783259) January 11, 1933
('58', 429, 3, 4, 783276) DEAR FRIEND, I have your letter 1 enclosing three cuttings for which I thank you.
('58', 429, 3, 5, 783358) I take them in order of their dates.
('58', 429, 3, 6, 783395) That of the 28th December calls for no reply.
('58', 429, 3, 7, 783441) That of the 29th, that is, the one on the postponement 2 of the fast has led you to grant me an indulgence, because you have been averse to the method of the fast.
('58', 429, 3, 8, 783605) But I must not exist on indulgences from friends, especially in religious matters.
('58', 429, 3, 9, 783688) Fortunately for me, your indulgence is due to an oversight of a material condition, whose happening was to automatically postpone the fast, and this was some legal difficulty which could not be got over within the time.
('58', 429, 3, 10, 783908) This difficulty came in the shape of the want of Viceregal sanction.
('58', 429, 3, 11, 783977) If I had taken the fast on the 2nd of January, I am afraid that you would not only have condemned the fast as such but you would have condemned it as coercion against the Government of India.
('58', 429, 3, 12, 784169) So, you see that the fast is postponed, not because I have realized its uselessness, but because I have realized the sinfulness of taking it in spite of the supervening of a contingency that had been contemplated and provided for.
('58', 429, 3, 13, 784400) Your last article, that is, of the 4th instant, calls for a fairly large reply, but I shall not attempt it, if only because I have to economize time just at present.
('58', 429, 3, 14, 784566) I see in my proposal no surrender whatsoever of principle.
('58', 429, 3, 15, 784625) In this campaign I have endeavoured, as much as a Harijan by adoption can, to put myself in his position, and I say to the objectors: ‘If you are polluted by my presence or by my touch, I am quite prepared to consent to a separate period being reserved for you to offer worship by yourselves.
('58', 429, 3, 16, 784918) give you the same credit for sincerity that I claim for myself.
('58', 429, 3, 17, 784982) You are as much entitled to worship in the temple as I think I am.
('58', 429, 3, 18, 785049) Therefore you offer worship in your time, and I shall offer worship, along with the reformers, during the period
('58', 429, 4, 19, 785162) 1 In which the addressee had written: “I feel you have let down the reformers by your compromise formula, and I hope you will excuse me when I say that the impression in enlightened circles in South India is that you have played into the hands of orthodox Brahmins.” 2 Vide “Interview to the Associated Press of India”, 29 12 1932 and “Statement on Untouchability XIII”, 30 12 1932.
('58', 430, 0, 1, 785545) VOL. 58 : 16 NOVEMBER, 1932 14 JANUARY, 1933 431
('58', 430, 1, 2, 785594) reserved for us, and since by tradition you have been taught to think that the efficacy of the idol is diminished by my entering the portals of the temple gate, though I do not believe in it myself, let the priest perform the purification cere mony.’ 1
('58', 430, 2, 3, 785847) This is how I rehearsed the whole thing to myself before I made the proposal to Pandit Panchanan Tarkaratna.
('58', 430, 2, 4, 785956) Of course the proposal would not be worthy of consideration if there was not a big assumption underlying it, namely, that the objectors would be in a negligible minority.
('58', 430, 2, 5, 786127) My proposal, therefore, is an effective and acid test of the sincerity of all concerned.
('58', 430, 2, 6, 786216) If the objectors including the Shastris are sincere in their protest on behalf of what they consider to be sanatana dharma, they would jump at the proposal.
('58', 430, 2, 7, 786373) If the reformers and the Harijans are sincere, they should hail the proposal with joy, and if it is accepted, regard it as a vast step towards the fruition of the reform.
('58', 430, 2, 8, 786544) If it is found by experience that the caste Hindus who offer worship during the joint period are themselves a negligible quantity, it would be a defeat for the reformer, and it would be a sign that the Harijans should abstain from entering those temples where they are unwelcome visitors.
('58', 430, 2, 9, 786833) They would not then have to go to the temples as beggars before caste men.
('58', 430, 2, 10, 786908) They will go, if they go at all, as fellow Hindus, welcomed by an overwhelming majority of caste men who would not consider themselves in any way polluted by the touch of the erstwhile untouchables.
('58', 430, 2, 11, 787107) Any other solution would be tantamount to compulsion.
('58', 430, 2, 12, 787161) You will recall what I said in one of my previous statements that wherever the majority of the temple goers are against the admission of Harijans those temples should not be visited by them, and where the majority was composed of reformers, the possession should go to them along with the Harijans and that the minority should build another temple for themselves, if they so choose; but in the course of argument with Pandit Panchanan Tarkaratna, I discovered a flaw in that proposal.
('58', 430, 2, 13, 787646) It is an undoubted fact that—whether it is right or wrong is not the question—thousands of people attribute particular sanctity to their favourite temples.
('58', 430, 2, 14, 787802) That sanctity is for them an untransferable thing.
('58', 430, 2, 15, 787853) Sanctity handed down from ancient times cannot be imparted to a new image and a new temple by the mere will of man, and therefore the
('58', 430, 3, 16, 787987) 1 Gandhiji’s compromise proposed to satisfy caste Hindus.
('58', 430, 3, 17, 788045) Vide “Interview to the Associated Press of India”, 29 12 1933.
('58', 431, 0, 1, 788108) 432 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('58', 431, 1, 2, 788150) proposal I have now published dawned upon me, and the proposal to be of any value has to carry withit the consent to purification, again out of scrupulous regard for the religious sentiment of the minority.
('58', 431, 2, 3, 788357) You will sympathize with my reasoning, even if you may not agree with it, when you realize that ahimsa is a fundamental creed with me and enforceable under every conceivable circumstance.
('58', 431, 2, 4, 788545) That I may fail miserably in reducing my creed to practice on all occasions does not detract from the creed, and is irrelevant to the discussion; and my non violence would not permit me to do violence to the feelings of a single devotee who has been accustomed to visit a particular temple.
('58', 431, 2, 5, 788836) I would also ask you to remember that, whatever may be said to the contrary, for me the whole of this campaign against untouchability is a purely religious campaign.
('58', 431, 2, 6, 789002) It is a movement of a big reform in Hinduism which, as I have said so repeatedly, must die if untouchability as we know it today is not eradicated.
('58', 431, 2, 7, 789150) I must also confess that I have a profound reverence for the Hindu Shastras as I have conceived them; but I cannot impose my conception upon others by force.
('58', 431, 2, 8, 789308) I must let it work its way in the midst of competing interpretations and conceptions.
('58', 431, 2, 9, 789394) Therefore wherever possible, my attitude would be to make provision for all other conceptions and interpretations.
('58', 431, 3, 10, 789509) If you would bear these things in mind, you would not only understand my position but you will support me whole heartedly, and I want your support.
('58', 431, 3, 11, 789657) I want the support of every Hindu.
('58', 431, 3, 12, 789692) Your paper represents I know a very large body of advanced Hindu opinion and since you are taking the trouble of trying to understand me, I am not going easily to give up the attempt to enlist your full support.
('58', 431, 4, 13, 789904) You have asked me quite unjustly “whether he (i.e., I) would be willing to satisfy the conscience of conservative seekers in England who want that political reform in India should be postponed to some later period”.
('58', 431, 4, 14, 790120) I will not insult your intelligence by showing you that there is no analogy between the position underlying your question and the position with reference to temple entry, especially in view of what I have said in the foregoing paragraphs.
('58', 431, 5, 15, 790359) Lastly, you cavil at the use of the word ‘Harijan, for untouch ables.
('58', 431, 5, 16, 790429) Evidently, you do not know how the word came to be used in the first instance.
('58', 431, 5, 17, 790508) It was suggested by certain untouchable friends who do not like to be called ‘untouchables’, and it was suggested because
('58', 432, 0, 1, 790630) VOL. 58 : 16 NOVEMBER, 1932 14 JANUARY, 1933 433
('58', 432, 1, 2, 790679) a saintly poet 1 of Gujarat, according to their interpretation of one of his hymns, used it in connection with ‘untouchables’.
('58', 432, 1, 3, 790806) I immediately seized upon the word as also otherwise most fitting, for the most despised people are the most favoured of God.
('58', 432, 1, 4, 790932) I fail to see any slave mentality about the origin of the use of the word or its continuance, and let us hope that when untouchability has a decent burial, we shall all strive to become Harijans, that is, pure men of God.
('58', 432, 1, 5, 791154) Yours sincerely, SJT.

('58', 435, 12, 23, 795627) 2. Is it not a fact that there are thousands of people who believe that India cannot get real swaraj without you?

('58', 436, 1, 4, 796164) I cannot endure anybody giving up what he regards as his dharma in order to save my life.

('58', 452, 4, 6, 825698) 635. LETTER TO R. SOMASUNDARAM AIYAR
('58', 452, 5, 7, 825735) January 12, 1933
('58', 452, 6, 8, 825752) DEAR FRIEND, I have your letter for which I thank you.
('58', 452, 6, 9, 825807) Your letter seems to me to be an illustration of the imaginary quarrel between the poor wife and her many husbands.
('58', 452, 6, 10, 825923) You say you will not allow my will to thwart your allegiance to God and your conscience.
('58', 452, 6, 11, 826012) I say I am not going to allow a few million out of my 300 millions to thwart my allegiance to God, my conscience and, what is perhaps more pertinent for you, my allegiance to my other many million husbands.
('58', 452, 6, 12, 826219) So you see the odds against me are not even.
('58', 452, 6, 13, 826264) Husbands can always play ducks and drakes with their wives, for they always play with loaded dice.
('58', 452, 6, 14, 826363) But God has gifted wives with infinite patience.
('58', 452, 6, 15, 826412) So, you will see how at the end of it I bear down the opposition of the very few husbands out of many who are up in arms against me, and when the quarrel is over, you will shed crocodile tears over the scars “the whole host” of you may leave on your poor wife and then make her forget all about her past miseries.
('58', 452, 6, 16, 826726) You appeal to me to exploit your sympathy for the economic betterment of the backward classes.
('58', 452, 6, 17, 826821) I invite you to make a sporting offer.
('58', 452, 6, 18, 826860) Your argument, I hope, you don’t want me to take seriously, or, if you do, then I must ask you dispassionately to study all the statements that I have been making, and you will find that every one of the questions raised by you is sufficiently answered therein.
('58', 452, 7, 19, 827122) Yours sincerely, SJT.
('58', 452, 7, 20, 827144) R. SOMASUNDARAM AIYAR

('58', 453, 2, 3, 827313) January 12, 1933
('58', 453, 3, 4, 827330) MY DEAR VENKATAPPAYYA,
('58', 453, 4, 5, 827353) I have your letter.
('58', 453, 4, 6, 827373) 1 I fear that your suggestion is fatal, especially at the present moment.
('58', 453, 4, 7, 827447) To set up new temples would be to set up a new religion and accept defeat.
('58', 453, 4, 8, 827522) If it is to be defeat, I should take it and resign myself to it, but I will not set up a new religion.
('58', 453, 4, 9, 827625) If our contention is right and the public reject it, we should know that untouchability is not to be destroyed or even shaken during our time.
('58', 453, 4, 10, 827768) Whether the contemplated legislation should be there or not is a matter that should be examined on its own merits.
('58', 453, 4, 11, 827883) I have come to the conclusion that both from the point of view of interference in matters religious and seeking Viceregal sanction, it is free from reproach.
('58', 453, 4, 12, 828041) Any time we would want legislation in order to correct errors and, in the hottest non co operation days, I should not hesitate to promote legislation backed by public will.
('58', 453, 4, 13, 828214) No law or rule can be cited to defeat its own end.
('58', 453, 4, 14, 828265) You may then be sure that there is flaw in your reasoning.
('58', 453, 4, 15, 828324) The cry of religious interference is perfectly thoughtless where it is not obviously hypocritic[al].
('58', 453, 4, 16, 828425) Of course, there is a third objection to the proposed Bill, namely, that the question who should or should not enter a temple should not be decided by those who are temple goers’ but by some extraneous authority, in this instance, learned men.
('58', 453, 4, 17, 828669) I totally deny the validity of that proposition.
('58', 453, 4, 18, 828718) No religion could grow under such a chilling rule.
('58', 453, 4, 19, 828769) Hindu religion, so far as I know it, has never followed any such rule.
('58', 453, 4, 20, 828840) Mind, I do not insist that all old temples should be opened to Harijans, but I do insist that all old temples should be opened where the majority of present worshippers are willing.
('58', 453, 4, 21, 829022) It is the acid test of the sincerity or the reality of the Bombay Resolution.
('58', 453, 5, 22, 829100) I suppose we must resign ourselves to the prospect of your wife
('58', 453, 6, 23, 829164) 1 The addressee had written: “So far as Guruvayur temple is concerned, the object may be taken as having been practically fulfilled, the opinion of the people being found to be decidedly favourable.
('58', 453, 6, 24, 829363) There will be no need to seek the aid of law if public opinion is secured in favour of the movement and legislation will be of no value if public opinion is adverse.”

('58', 458, 4, 8, 836537) 645. LETTER TO SITARAM K. NALAVDE
('58', 458, 5, 9, 836571) January 12, 1933
('58', 458, 6, 10, 836588) BHAI NALAVDE, Your letter.
('58', 458, 6, 11, 836615) The Harijan brethren certainly have the right to give up carrion eating as well as disposal of dead cattle.
('58', 458, 6, 12, 836723) But it would be better if they took the vow to give up carrion eating.
('58', 458, 6, 13, 836794) The duty of removal of dead cattle has the sanction of society.
('58', 458, 6, 14, 836858) After all someone has to perform this duty.
('58', 458, 6, 15, 836902) The public will certainly be put to hardship if those who are well versed in the job give it up.
('58', 458, 6, 16, 836999) It is the dharma of all to protect society from this difficulty.
('58', 458, 6, 17, 837064) Therefore if necessary this job may be given up only after coming to some arrangements with .
('58', 458, 7, 18, 837158) the mahajan 2. The giving up of carrion eating is, however, obligatory.
('58', 458, 7, 19, 837230) Those who give up beef and carrion eating and have proper bath, etc., should be entitled to enter temples.
('58', 458, 7, 20, 837337) They too should thus qualify themselves for darshan of the image and be confident that they will have the right of temple entry.
('58', 458, 7, 21, 837466) Those who do not give up carrion eating should not be summarily boycotted.
('58', 458, 7, 22, 837541) They should have the chance of reforming themselves.
('58', 458, 7, 23, 837594) It is not an easy matter for everyone to give up a long standing habit.
('58', 458, 7, 24, 837666) I hope that the Conference will be successful.
('58', 458, 7, 25, 837713) I also hope that all the Harijan brothers and sisters will resolve on self reform.
('58', 458, 9, 26, 837796) MOHANDAS GANDHI

('58', 459, 2, 3, 837969) January 12, 1933
('58', 459, 3, 4, 837986) DEAR SHASTRIJI, I have received all your letters.
('58', 459, 3, 5, 838036) I have already stated that my mind and heart are open for a discussion with you.
('58', 459, 3, 6, 838117) Though I have not been given enough time to write to the Shastris I have in mind, I have sent invitations to those who can come immediately.
('58', 459, 3, 7, 838258) I still do not know whether they will be able to come.
('58', 459, 3, 8, 838313) The subject for our discussion is not whether untouchability is sanctioned by the Shastras or not.
('58', 459, 3, 9, 838412) The subject is to determine the sanction of the Shastras for untouchability as it is practised today.
('58', 459, 3, 10, 838514) And if the untouchability in current usage has the sanction of the Shastras, then who can be defined as untouchable?
('58', 459, 3, 11, 838631) I certainly desire in all humility to hear your views on these two questions and other points that may arise out of these and I hope you are now satisfied and will honour me by coming over.
('58', 459, 5, 12, 838821) MOHANDAS GANDHI

('58', 460, 5, 12, 840487) I don’t like the spirit underlying it.
('58', 460, 5, 13, 840526) You have looked upon the whole thing as a commercial transaction, whereas I have looked upon the whole thing as a matter of selfless service.
('58', 460, 5, 14, 840668) You left the question of remuneration entirely in my hands, although I asked you to tell me what you would charge for giving me a corrected collection of your speeches on untouchability and for supervising the printing.
('58', 460, 5, 15, 840888) But you would not think of it, telling me that there was no mercenary motive behind it.
('58', 460, 5, 16, 840976) That being so, I had no hesitation in undertaking the delicate task, but at the end of it, I shirked it, and I asked Haribhau to name the sum.
('58', 460, 5, 17, 841119) He named Rs. 125 and I straightaway accepted.
('58', 460, 5, 18, 841165) Believe me, so far as I am concerned, I did not think of the Arya Bhushan bill in connection with fixing up your fee, remuneration or honorarium, whatever it may be called.
('58', 460, 5, 19, 841338) Nor did I then know nor do I now know that the Arya Bhushan bill is exorbitant.
('58', 460, 5, 20, 841418) My understanding is that they should not make anything but nominal profits.
('58', 460, 5, 21, 841494) You are thinking of anything between Rs. 500 to 3,000. I can only meet your proposal with a reasonable offer.
('58', 460, 5, 22, 841604) You can take over the book yourself by simply paying the printing charges and sell the book on your own account and make whatever profit you can, only you should not increase the published price, for any increase in the price would be unjust to the public.
