('58', 464, 1, 2, 846178) 654. LETTER TO C. RAJAGOPALACHARI
('58', 464, 2, 3, 846212) January 13, 1933
('58', 464, 3, 4, 846229) MY DEAR C.R., Vallabhbhai had a battle royal with me last night on your behalf.
('58', 464, 3, 5, 846309) If a person, an utter stranger to him, had chance to be there, from the vehemence of Vallabhbhai’s language, he would have concluded that we must be most quarrelsome persons.
('58', 464, 3, 6, 846484) He thought that I was doing violent injustice to you, inasmuch as, without consultation with you, I made proposals that might prove to be utterly embarrassing, as had happened on two occasions.
('58', 464, 3, 7, 846678) The cause of our quarrel was my compromise proposal 1. He thought that I had no right to publish it without consultation with you, and he was quite sure that though you were too good to mention it to me, you had felt very much embarrassed by it, if not also irritated.
('58', 464, 3, 8, 846947) I told him that you were too good to conceal your embarrassment from me, if you were really embarrassed, and that would be quite unlike you.
('58', 464, 3, 9, 847088) I even added that in this particular instance you happened even to like my proposal and that even if it was discovered that you did not like it and that you were really embarrassed, it was impossible for me every time to consult you, or such other colleagues on such occasions.
('58', 464, 3, 10, 847366) I went further and argued that work on such lines would become almost impossible.
('58', 464, 3, 11, 847448) People act together when there is a general agreement between them on fundamentals and [provided] that their deductions from those fundamentals were, as a rule, identical, and that if, at times, they came to different deductions, a timely confession of error would keep their friendship in tact, as also the common cause.
('58', 464, 3, 12, 847770) Nothing that I could say, however, would conciliate Vallabhbhai.
('58', 464, 3, 13, 847835) The curfew bell, mutually agreed upon by us, came to the rescue, and put an end to what promised to be an endless discussion.
('58', 464, 3, 14, 847961) But I retired to bed with a determination that I would refer the matter to you.
('58', 464, 3, 15, 848041) Your reply, one way or the other, would bring some consolation to your counsel, and you know that it won’t make me disconsolate if you agreed with your counsel on both his propositions, namely, that before giving to the world the compromise proposal which I had given to Pandit Panchanan Tarkaratna I should have consulted you, and that it, as a matter of fact, did embarrass you.
('58', 464, 3, 16, 848422) You would also add
('58', 464, 4, 17, 848441) 1 For a discussion, vide Appendix “Talk with Sadashivrao and Shinde”, 13 1 1933.
('58', 465, 0, 1, 848522) 466 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('58', 465, 1, 2, 848564) to your opinion on these points, your opinion whether on merits you consider my proposal to be sound or otherwise.
('58', 465, 1, 3, 848679) A perfect tragedy was enacted here yesterday.
('58', 465, 1, 4, 848725) Five pandits and their five advisers came to the jail gate yesterday an hour and a half after the appointed time and took two hours and a half in exchanging brief notes with me, the three notes 1 that they exchanged with me taking all the two hours and a half.
('58', 465, 1, 5, 848986) And, will you believe it, when I tell you that they would not come in and carry on the discussion because I would not remove one word I had added to their draft, the word being an adjective added to the word ‘untouchables’.
('58', 465, 1, 6, 849210) The adjective applied was ‘as at present classified’.
('58', 465, 1, 7, 849264) Of course it altered the whole scope of their discussion.
('58', 465, 1, 8, 849322) So they went away.
('58', 465, 1, 9, 849341) Of course it is not our position that there is no untouchability at all in the Shastras.
('58', 465, 1, 10, 849430) Our position is that there is no untouchability in the Shastras as we practise it today.
('58', 465, 1, 11, 849519) They were expected to prove that untouchability as at present practised has sanction in the Shastras.
('58', 465, 1, 12, 849621) It is an impossible task to perform honestly.
('58', 465, 1, 13, 849667) No text that has yet been cited on their behalf has proved it.
('58', 465, 1, 14, 849730) The Shastris on our behalf are really very learned men, and also pious men.
('58', 465, 1, 15, 849806) It is their honest conviction that there is no warrant for the untouchability of the present day in the Shastras.
('58', 465, 1, 16, 849920) The real untouchability will be there for all time.
('58', 465, 1, 17, 849972) It is a sound hygienic rule practised all over the world.
('58', 465, 2, 18, 850030) Yours sincerely,
('58', 465, 3, 19, 850047) From a microfilm: S.N. 18922
('58', 465, 4, 20, 850076) 655. LETTER TO GEORGE JOSEPH
('58', 465, 5, 21, 850105) January 13, 1933
('58', 465, 6, 22, 850122) MY DEAR JOSEPH,
('58', 465, 7, 23, 850138) You can better imagine than I can describe my joy at receiving your letter, and especially your letter 2 to Pyarelal.
('58', 465, 7, 24, 850256) I shall try to have your letter delivered to him.
('58', 465, 7, 25, 850306) But let me say two things in connection with that letter.
('58', 465, 8, 26, 850364) 1 Vide “Note to Deonayakacharya”, 12 1 1933.
('58', 465, 9, 27, 850409) 2 In which the addressee had expressed his views on Pyarelal's book The Epic Fast and stated: “The Inner Voice is either a hallucination or the voice of God.
('58', 465, 9, 28, 850567) If it is truly the voice of God, it cannot counsel self destruction because the life that God gives is for Him alone to put an end to .
('58', 466, 0, 1, 850703) VOL. 58 : 16 NOVEMBER, 1932 14 JANUARY, 1933 467
('58', 466, 1, 2, 850752) My fast was not a fast unto death in its literal sense.
('58', 466, 1, 3, 850808) The Roman Catholic priest, who is a visitor to this prison, knows me, and when I was on the eve of taking that fast, he came over to me in his kindly manner just to say one word, and he said how he drew the distinction between a suicide and a sacrifice.
('58', 466, 1, 4, 851062) A suicide carried with it a certainty of destruction.
('58', 466, 1, 5, 851116) A sacrifice meant risking life, the greater the risk, the greater the sacrifice.
('58', 466, 1, 6, 851197) But there should be nothing beyond risk.
('58', 466, 1, 7, 851238) I had no hesitation in agreeing with the distinction, and my fast being conditional was not a fast amounting to suicide, but it was a fast involving the greatest risk, but still a risk and no more.
('58', 466, 1, 8, 851436) You will be interested to know that some of my Roman Catholic friends have detected no flaw in the fast.
('58', 466, 1, 9, 851541) Of course, in Hinduism some few extreme cases there are in which ending of life is peremptory, but these I need not consider at present.
('58', 466, 1, 10, 851678) There is general agreement between Hinduism and other faiths that suicide is a sin.
('58', 466, 1, 11, 851762) Now, about the Inner Voice.
('58', 466, 1, 12, 851790) 1 Here again I can agree with you whole heartedly when you say that the voice of God can never counsel or ountenance sin.
('58', 466, 1, 13, 851912) Encouragement to sin can only come from the devil.
('58', 466, 1, 14, 851963) But the real difficulty comes in when the question of sin itself is debatable.
('58', 466, 1, 15, 852042) Those who would consider a particular act to be sinful will naturally reject the claim that it was prompted by God.
('58', 466, 1, 16, 852158) Hence it was that in answer to a question I said that whilst in self defence and for the sake of truth which I worship I was bound to say what I believed, my claim was not to be accepted as part of argument in determining relevant questions.
('58', 466, 1, 17, 852400) The opponents were bound to rule [out] that claim as wholly beside the point.
('58', 466, 1, 18, 852478) Whether the claim for the voice of God was well or ill made in a particular case can only be decided after the claimant’s death, and in some extraordinary cases it may even then be difficult.
('58', 466, 1, 19, 852670) Apart from the danger of hypocrisy there is the still greater danger of self deception to which mankind is prone, and it is possible for self deceived people to attain great things and yet their claim that the voice of God was behind their acts might be wholly wrong.
('58', 466, 1, 20, 852938) These are final difficulties which will remain to the end of time, but if the truth is to make any progress, then self deluded people must also be allowed full play.
('58', 466, 1, 21, 853104) Finally comes the question of confession.
('58', 466, 1, 22, 853146) You may not know that I have some very valued Roman Catholic friends also.
('58', 466, 1, 23, 853221) I am in the habit of picking up knowledge more from personal contact than from
('58', 466, 2, 24, 853300) 1 For a discussion, vide Appendix “Discussion with a Friend”, 13 1 1933.
('58', 467, 0, 1, 853373) 468 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('58', 467, 1, 2, 853415) printed texts.
('58', 467, 1, 3, 853430) These friends have not yet been able to clearly define the function of Confession and the Confessor.
('58', 467, 1, 4, 853531) For instance, what is one to confess who has no consciousness of guilt and when there is, I can understand a Confessor granting absolution, but can he also guide the future acts of the penitent?
('58', 467, 1, 5, 853726) In the place of the Confessor Hinduism has the Guru.
('58', 467, 1, 6, 853779) I have all my life striven to find one, one to whom I can shift all my burdens and roam about merely doing his will.
('58', 467, 1, 7, 853896) But then such implicit limitless obedience is not a mechanical act; and having got the spirit of obedience instinctively within me I would be satisfied by nothing less than tendering complete obedience.
('58', 467, 1, 8, 854099) But it seems to me that it is not given to all to find the true Guru in this short span of life.
('58', 467, 1, 9, 854196) But it is given to all to make that diligent search, and it may be that that very search is its own reward, and that it keeps one in possession of peace and joy everlasting.
('58', 467, 1, 10, 854370) Anyway, you will accept my testimony that ceaseless search has not only given me such joy and peace, but has protected me from conscious error.
('58', 467, 1, 11, 854514) I thank you for copying for me that extract from Imitation of Christ.
('58', 467, 1, 12, 854584) I read that book in one single sitting, I think, in the year 1905 or 1906, and a friend, only a few months ago, sent me another copy.
('58', 467, 1, 13, 854718) With our love to all of you,
('58', 467, 2, 14, 854747) Yours sincerely, GEORGE JOSEPH, ESQ., M.A., BARRISTER AT LAW “HILL VIEW”, MADURA
('58', 467, 3, 15, 854828) From a microfilm: S.N. 18923

('58', 471, 4, 8, 861034) 662. LETTER TO M. THIAGARAJAN
('58', 471, 5, 9, 861064) January 14, 1933
('58', 471, 6, 10, 861081) DEAR FRIEND, I have your letter.
('58', 471, 6, 11, 861114) The question is not so much what the Harijans need, but how the caste Hindus should behave towards them.
('58', 471, 6, 12, 861219) In my opinion, it is the clear duty of caste Hindus to give to the Harijans the same rights that they enjoy.
('58', 471, 6, 13, 861328) The fact that evil has survived numberless generations does not make it any the less an evil.
('58', 471, 6, 14, 861422) Similarly, the fact that untouchability has survived the great religious teachers whom you name does not warrant the present generation in continuing it, if it can be proved to be an evil.
('58', 471, 6, 15, 861611) I am convinced it is.
('58', 471, 6, 16, 861633) A person who has heard the inner call should still be open to reason and therefore conviction.
('58', 471, 6, 17, 861728) That attitude enables him and others to test the truth of his claim.
('58', 471, 6, 18, 861797) I do say with my conception of Hinduism that God denies Himself what Harijans are denied, because they are called Harijans.
('58', 471, 7, 19, 861921) Yours sincerely, SJT.

('58', 474, 2, 3, 865593) APPENDIX I
('58', 474, 3, 4, 865604) DISCUSSION WITH “ THE TIMES OF INDIA” REPRESENTATIVE
('58', 474, 4, 5, 865657) November 21, 1932
('58', 474, 5, 6, 865675) REPRESENTATIVE: Have you decided to devote the rest of your life to eradication of untouchability?
('58', 474, 6, 7, 865774) GANDHIJI: I cannot say that that is my present intention or that there is a poss ibility of it.
('58', 474, 6, 8, 865870) It is wholly true to say that my life is devoted to this most important reform of Hindu dharma.
('58', 474, 6, 9, 865966) But then my life is devoted to so many other things.
('58', 474, 6, 10, 866019) I cannot divide my life into water tight compartments.
('58', 474, 6, 11, 866074) My life is indivisible.
('58', 474, 6, 12, 866098) The root of all my activities is the same.
('58', 474, 6, 13, 866141) In every sphere of life, be it small or big, my aim is to promote truth and ahimsa.
('58', 474, 6, 14, 866225) This morning I read an article appearing in The Times of India.
('58', 474, 6, 15, 866289) I would like to say something about it.
('58', 474, 6, 16, 866329) I wish to correct an error in your
('58', 474, 7, 17, 866364) editorial.
('58', 474, 7, 18, 866375) It is not correct to say that all the questions regarding giving social rights to Harijans are covered by temple entry.
('58', 474, 7, 19, 866495) Temple entry is just one of the many questions.
('58', 474, 7, 20, 866543) If today it has come to the fore it is not because of me.
('58', 474, 7, 21, 866601) At my request Shri Kelappan has given up his fast.
('58', 474, 7, 22, 866652) So I am under an obligation to help him.
('58', 474, 7, 23, 866693) Therefore, naturally, I have to do all I can to attract public attention to Guruvayur and see that before the second of January, the famous temple is thrown open to Harijans.
('58', 474, 7, 24, 866868) The fast will be only to get that temple opened and no other.
('58', 474, 7, 25, 866930) The fast will not be of my choosing.
('58', 474, 7, 26, 866967) Only if Shri Kelappan is obliged to fast, it becomes my duty to undertake a fast too.
('58', 474, 7, 27, 867053) In the effort to have the temple opened to Harijans, there is no thought of coercing any section of society.
('58', 474, 7, 28, 867162) According to the information I have—and I have no cause to doubt the truth of it—many caste Hindus are in favour of throwing open the temples to Harijans.
('58', 474, 7, 29, 867317) If this is so, it cannot be said that there was coercion.
('58', 474, 7, 30, 867375) It may be kept in mind that though this question was put before the public only recently, Shri Kelappan and his associates have been working for it for a long time.
('58', 474, 7, 31, 867540) And if he has won the public over to his view, it has not happened in a few days.
('58', 474, 7, 32, 867622) It is the result of many years of sustained work.
('58', 474, 8, 33, 867672) R. Is your duty towards Shri Kelappan so great that if he undertakes a fast you must stake your life ?
('58', 474, 9, 34, 867775) G. If I lose self respect, I would at once become useless for any kind of service.
('58', 474, 9, 35, 867858) I do not consider it a great thing to risk my life to keep a pledge made in all awareness in a just cause.
('58', 474, 10, 36, 867965) R. Do you consider this of more importance than the work you are doing for the Harijan cause?
('58', 475, 0, 1, 868059) 476 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('58', 475, 1, 2, 868101) G. Once I have violated a pledge, my life would be of no use to Harijans.
('58', 475, 1, 3, 868175) But if in keeping a vow I have to die, it will be in my view a precious thing not only for the Harijans, not only for Hinduism, but I humbly submit, for the whole of India and the entire world.
('58', 475, 2, 4, 868369) R. Since you do not believe in image worship, why are you taking so much trouble to have the right of image worship given to Harijans?
('58', 475, 3, 5, 868504) G. I don’t think I have ever said that I have no faith in image worship.
('58', 475, 3, 6, 868577) I don’t remember that there is anything of this sort in my articles either.
('58', 475, 3, 7, 868653) What I have repeatedly said is that I am both an iconoclast and an idolator.
('58', 475, 3, 8, 868730) Is it not a very different thing from saying that I have no faith in image worship?
('58', 475, 3, 9, 868814) But if someone says that I hardly ever go to a temple, it will be quite true.
('58', 475, 3, 10, 868892) I would not like to go into the reasons why I don’t visit the temples.
('58', 475, 3, 11, 868963) But I will say this: that my religion is so all embracing that I go with the same devotion to a Hindu temple, a Muslim mosque, a Christian church or a Jewish synagogue.
('58', 475, 3, 12, 869132) I have never gone to any of these places as an atheist or a critic, but always with full devotion.
('58', 475, 3, 13, 869231) [From Gujarati]
('58', 475, 4, 14, 869247) Mahadevbhaini Diary, Vol. II, pp.
('58', 475, 5, 15, 869281) APPENDIX II
('58', 475, 6, 16, 869293) DISCUSSION WITH “FREE PRESS” REPRESENTATIVE 1
('58', 475, 7, 17, 869339) December 3, 1932
('58', 475, 8, 18, 869356) 1. From the point of view of the duty of the caste Hindus the question of Guruvayur is not a small one.
('58', 475, 8, 19, 869460) It is wholly wrong to use the phrase ‘uplift of Harijans’.
('58', 475, 8, 20, 869519) According to me, the first duty of the caste Hindus towards the Harijans is to throw open all the temples to them which are open to others.
('58', 475, 9, 21, 869659) 2. I would not place the responsibility for temple entry on the Anti Untouchability League.
('58', 475, 9, 22, 869751) Before the League was born, the question of Guruvayur was before the people.
('58', 475, 9, 23, 869828) The League should certainly do as much as it can about the matter.
('58', 475, 9, 24, 869895) But if the temple is not thrown open within the time fixed for it, the Sangh would not deserve to be castigated more than the other institutions.
('58', 475, 10, 25, 870041) 3. If it is proved that Guruvayur is a private temple, there can be no ground for the fast.
('58', 475, 11, 26, 870133) 4. If the reformers are truthful and humble, they can bring about a change of heart in the sanatanists.
('58', 475, 11, 27, 870237) They should bear in mind that before they became reformers, they were sailing in the same boat with the sanatanists.
('58', 475, 12, 28, 870354) 1 Vide “Statement on Fast to Anti Untouchability Committee”, 4 12 1932.
('58', 476, 0, 1, 870426) VOL. 58: 16 NOVEMBER, 1932 14 JANUARY, 1933 477
('58', 476, 1, 2, 870474) 5. Reformers are trying their best to cultivate public opinion.
('58', 476, 1, 3, 870538) And as a reformer myself, I think that public opinion has veered towards the reform to a considerable degree.
('58', 476, 1, 4, 870648) I do not believe at all that most of the Hindus are under the influence of dharmacharyas.
('58', 476, 1, 5, 870738) They listen to the Shankaracharya and other acharyas
('58', 476, 2, 6, 870791) only to the extent it suits them.
('58', 476, 2, 7, 870825) Suppose the Shankaracharya issues an injunction that nobody should drink liquor, do you think everyone will abide by it?
('58', 476, 2, 8, 870946) If the dharmacharyas themselves observe restraint, then only can they make others do so.
('58', 476, 3, 9, 871035) 6. I cannot wait to see myself fully restored before I undertake the fast.
('58', 476, 3, 10, 871110) I believe that it will be at the command of God.
('58', 476, 3, 11, 871159) When my body is weak, I am better able to stand fasting.
('58', 476, 4, 12, 871216) 7. Millions of people—if they love me—will be distressed by my fast.
('58', 476, 4, 13, 871285) They will raise such a powerful voice that it will become irresistible.
('58', 476, 4, 14, 871357) There is a war between me and untouchability.
('58', 476, 4, 15, 871403) If you want me to live, untouchability has to go.
('58', 476, 4, 16, 871453) If you want untouchability to stay, I have to die.
('58', 476, 4, 17, 871504) [From Gujarati] Mahadevbhaini Diary, Vol. II, pp.

('58', 476, 6, 19, 871567) LETTER FROM E. E. DOYLE 1
('58', 476, 7, 20, 871593) INSPECTOR GENERAL OF POLICE, BOMBAY PRESIDENCY, POONA, December 4, 1932
('58', 476, 8, 21, 871665) DEAR MR. GANDHI,
('58', 476, 9, 22, 871682) I am in receipt of your letter of today for which many thanks.
('58', 476, 9, 23, 871745) I shall convey its contents, tomorrow, personally to Government.
('58', 476, 9, 24, 871810) There is one point, a very important point, to my mind, on which we were agreed, which you have not touched on in your letter, it is, that the present practice of employing so called ‘low caste’ prisoners is of very wide import, and that you realize it cannot at present be altered.
('58', 476, 9, 25, 872093) I feel I shall have a stronger case, if I have your confirmation of this in writing.
('58', 476, 9, 26, 872178) I am sorry to worry you on your day of silence, especially after the strain of interviewingthe Deputation, but I am sure you will appreciate that I desire to have all my points absolutely correct, when I place your case before Government tomorrow.

('58', 476, 10, 28, 872443) E. E. DOYLE

('58', 477, 2, 3, 872653) DISCUSSION WITH POONA SANATANISTS
('58', 477, 3, 4, 872687) December 7, 1932
('58', 477, 4, 5, 872704) GANDHlJI: Temple entry is a purely religious question.
('58', 477, 4, 6, 872759) I have never regarded it as a question of expediency.
('58', 477, 4, 7, 872813) For me religion is practice.
('58', 477, 4, 8, 872842) Every Hindu has the right to go to a temple.
('58', 477, 4, 9, 872887) The rules regarding personal hygiene apply to all.
('58', 477, 4, 10, 872938) The custom of admitting Hindus of one particular class into temples has been in vogue for many years.
('58', 477, 4, 11, 873040) But which Hindus should be admitted into a temple and which not is not a religious question.
('58', 477, 4, 12, 873133) About this only the temple goers should be consulted.
('58', 477, 4, 13, 873187) Dharmashastras should not be brought in.
('58', 477, 4, 14, 873228) The few who are left out should not coerce others.
('58', 477, 4, 15, 873279) They should build another temple for themselves.
('58', 477, 4, 16, 873328) From what study I have made of my religion, I feel that for those who are not permitted in other temples, the temple should be opened for a few hours.
('58', 477, 4, 17, 873479) True religion is that which leads to spiritual progress and for which we are ready to sacrifice everything.
('58', 477, 4, 18, 873587) The temple should be thrown open for ‘touchables’ for a few hours; but if the reformers are few, it cannot be thrown open to untouchables.
('58', 477, 4, 19, 873726) The question of minority and majority arose from my fast.
('58', 477, 4, 20, 873784) In answer to those who doubted if the majority wanted temples to be opened to untouchables, a referendum was suggested.
('58', 477, 4, 21, 873904) If you prove beyond doubt that temple entry by untouchables is against the Shastras, I shall be helpless.
('58', 477, 5, 22, 874010) QUESTION: Do you promise to listen to the Shastris if they secure a 51 per cent
('58', 477, 6, 23, 874090) majority?
('58', 477, 7, 24, 874100) G. I would give up the fast today if you prove it to be adharma.
('58', 477, 8, 25, 874165) Q. Would you consider this opportunity for a discussion with the Shastris ?
('58', 477, 9, 26, 874241) G. Whether it is my good luck or bad luck, you people have come here because of my fast.
('58', 477, 9, 27, 874330) I had resolved that it was our duty to throw open the temples.
('58', 477, 9, 28, 874393) I decided this long ago.
('58', 477, 9, 29, 874418) I met the Shastris at Vaikom.
('58', 477, 9, 30, 874448) They showed me Shankara Smriti and translated it too.
('58', 477, 9, 31, 874502) But there was nothing in it to support what the Shastris said.
('58', 477, 9, 32, 874565) I shall, of course,
('58', 477, 10, 33, 874585) listen to you, since you have come to throw new light on the question; but, in the course of discussion I will not give up the resolve to fast.
('58', 477, 10, 34, 874729) I read through many granthas and their translations and in the end decided that that which stands the test of ahimsa and truth is dharma.
('58', 477, 10, 35, 874867) I did not go to the Gita, instead the Gita came to me.
('58', 477, 10, 36, 874922) The Gita is for me an independent support.
('58', 477, 10, 37, 874965) To save myself from all sorts of criticisms, I fell back on my faith, reason and bhakti.
('58', 477, 10, 38, 875054) If what you say appeals to my reason, I
('58', 477, 11, 39, 875094) shall say that I have lost on the rational plane.
('58', 477, 11, 40, 875144) Then I shall depend on my heart.
('58', 477, 11, 41, 875177) You will have to satisfy my heart.
('58', 477, 12, 42, 875212) Q. Will it not follow that what appeals to your heart is your dharma?
('58', 478, 0, 1, 875282) VOL. 58: 16 NOVEMBER, 1932 14 JANUARY, 1933 479
('58', 478, 1, 2, 875330) G. Whatever appeals to a man’s heart is dharma to him.
('58', 478, 1, 3, 875385) Dharma cannot be reached by the intellect.
('58', 478, 1, 4, 875428) It can only be reached by the heart.
('58', 478, 1, 5, 875465) That is why it is for fools too.
('58', 478, 1, 6, 875498) The question of temple entry is purely religious.
('58', 478, 1, 7, 875548) To alter my views is very difficult indeed because behind my views is a past.
('58', 478, 1, 8, 875626) An ordinary man cannot decide what is and what is not dharma as regards temple entry.

('58', 481, 0, 1, 882139) 482 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('58', 481, 1, 2, 882181) MACRAE: What have you to say about the allegation that through this you impose your opinion on others?
('58', 481, 2, 3, 882284) G. My answer to this question will also cover what you have said about the resolution concerning my fast.
('58', 481, 2, 4, 882390) Shri Jamnadas Mehta has perfect right to make the criticism he has made.
('58', 481, 2, 5, 882463) But I do not accept his allegations.
('58', 481, 2, 6, 882500) I have never tried to impose my views on others.
('58', 481, 2, 7, 882549) I have never imposed my views even on the closest co workers.
('58', 481, 2, 8, 882611) But it has so happened that, despite my having admitted that I have committed Himalayan blunders, my views on many things have been proved correct.
('58', 481, 2, 9, 882759) For me the question of untouchability is forty years old.
('58', 481, 2, 10, 882817) Ever since, I have been facing opposition on this score.
('58', 481, 2, 11, 882874) It has come not only from outsiders but also from my family members—old and young.
('58', 481, 2, 12, 882957) But the views I have been holding and putting into practice for the last 45 years have been commonly accepted.
('58', 481, 2, 13, 883068) Today, if my sanatanist friends charge that I have been forcing my views on the public or on the sanatanists, there is not much substance in the charge.
('58', 481, 2, 14, 883221) Looking at the history of mankind, we find that whenever an individual has held some good ideas, has insisted on them and put them into practice in his life, the whole society has accepted them.
('58', 481, 2, 15, 883416) Now, to say that he has forced his thoughts on the people is absurd.
('58', 481, 2, 16, 883485) So long as there is no physical force behind one, it cannot be said that one has forced one’s views on others.
('58', 481, 2, 17, 883596) It is true that my fast has evoked some anxiety.
('58', 481, 2, 18, 883645) But I have no doubt in my mind that I am not at all to blame for it.
('58', 481, 2, 19, 883714) I am carefully watching, with the eye of a scientist, the impact that my contemplated fast has had, and is having.
('58', 481, 2, 20, 883829) What I see fills me with joy and hope.
('58', 481, 2, 21, 883868) The fast has made people think.
('58', 481, 2, 22, 883900) The fast will not force anybody to do anything against his conscience, but those who are lethargic will give up their lethargy and will start working with zest, that is, all those who love me will actively start working.
('58', 481, 2, 23, 884121) I do not in the least feel depressed by this development.
('58', 481, 2, 24, 884179) Those who feel that I am destroying Hinduism write angry letters saying I should quickly undertake the fast and depart from the world.
('58', 481, 2, 25, 884314) Such letters do not have any effect on me.
('58', 481, 2, 26, 884357) I am talking about these letters on]y to show that those who are opposed to eradication of untouchability will not be affected in the least by the fast which I am thinking of undertaking and it should be so.
('58', 481, 2, 27, 884565) But about the fast, I will have to say more later on.
('58', 481, 2, 28, 884619) At the moment I can only say that nobody would be able to deflect Shri Kelappan or me from the resolve to fast which has been inspired by God.
('58', 481, 2, 29, 884762) I appreciate the efforts of Shri Mehta who has already warned the public beforehand.
('58', 481, 2, 30, 884847) What causes me pain and surprise is the fact that the Zamorin is bringing all sorts of allegations against those who are engaged in organizing voting.
('58', 481, 2, 31, 884998) I consider him to be a gentleman.
('58', 481, 2, 32, 885032) He knows that Shri Madhavan Nair, who is the Chairman of the Voting Committee is a respectable lawyer, well known throughout Kerala.
('58', 481, 2, 33, 885165) Rajaji is helping the Committee and supervising the work.
('58', 481, 2, 34, 885223) They are people who will not tolerate any unfairness.
('58', 481, 2, 35, 885277) It is the Zamorin’s duty to point out if they have resorted to any objectionable means.
('58', 481, 2, 36, 885365) This question is purely moral and religious.
('58', 481, 2, 37, 885410) There can be no
('58', 482, 0, 1, 885426) VOL. 58: 16 NOVEMBER, 1932 14 JANUARY, 1933 483
('58', 482, 1, 2, 885474) room for taking sides, for love and hate.
('58', 482, 1, 3, 885516) If the sanatanists and reformers work together they will be able to bring out the truth.
('58', 482, 1, 4, 885605) Let me once again assure you that as soon as I come to know that I am mistaken about the public opinion, I will immediately give up the idea of fasting.
('58', 482, 1, 5, 885758) I wish to worship Truth only.
('58', 482, 1, 6, 885788) I have no other aim than that.

('58', 482, 11, 21, 887401) the truth as regards the statement that untouchability and restrictions on untouchables’ temple entry have no Shastraic basis.

('58', 483, 3, 4, 887839) December 9, 1932
('58', 483, 4, 5, 887856) You say the Poona Pact is much better than the Award for it gives more seats.
('58', 483, 4, 6, 887934) I wish to inform you that it is not the quantity that is important but it is the quality.
('58', 483, 4, 7, 888024) The Award gives 18 seats by separate election, voting power in the general election, and seats if liked by the Depressed Classes and allowed by the caste people in the general electorate.
('58', 483, 4, 8, 888212) The Pact gives only 30 seats in the general electorate.
('58', 483, 4, 9, 888268) In the words of Dr. Ambedkar according to the Premier’s Award we will send to the Councils 30 diluted (in Madras).
('58', 483, 4, 10, 888383) Secondly by the Award the so called high class people would beg of the Depressed Classes to give them votes by which the pride of the high caste people will be suppressed.
('58', 483, 5, 11, 888555) You say the Poona Pact “provides against the election of any candidate who is not in the first place approved by the majority of Harijans”.
('58', 483, 5, 12, 888695) I know you are referring to the Primary Election and its panel is four.
('58', 483, 5, 13, 888767) I hope you would realize dear Mahatmaji that there is difference in confidence which each member in the panel enjoys among the Depressed Classes.
('58', 483, 5, 14, 888913) Suppose in the Primary Election ten people contest.
('58', 483, 5, 15, 888965) The first man secures 5,000 votes, the second 2,000 votes, the third 1,000, the fourth 900, the fifth 800, the sixth 700, .
('58', 483, 5, 16, 889089) the eighth 600, the ninth 590, and the tenth 500. All these people enjoy the confidence of the Depressed Classes but there is difference in the confidence.
('58', 483, 5, 17, 889245) If the panel is six, the first six would be approved by the Depressed Classes, and if the panel is eight, the first eight would be approved by the Depressed Class.
('58', 483, 5, 18, 889409) But don’t you see there is vast difference between each man?
('58', 483, 5, 19, 889470) After the Primary Election the selected candidates would have to stand in the joint electorate (I know the mentality of the caste people), and the result is the last man in the panel would be elected by the caste Hindus.
('58', 483, 5, 20, 889691) The caste people would elect a man who possesses the least confidence among the Depressed Classes so that he may be subservient to them.
('58', 483, 6, 21, 889828) On 9 3 31 [I] wrote you a letter requesting you [to] stay in a paracheri (i.e., the place where the Depressed Classes live) whenever you visited Madras so that you may learn at first hand the difficulties of my people but you took up your residence in the palatial buildings of the Brahmins at Mylapore.
('58', 483, 6, 22, 890132) If you had listened to my words, you would never have spoiled the Premier’s award.
('58', 483, 7, 23, 890215) You say “I am certainly not in favour of special electorates for the merchants, landlords, and others.
('58', 483, 7, 24, 890318) Then why don’t you fast for their abolition; is it because that

('58', 484, 8, 11, 890836) LETTER FROM RAMTARAN MUKHERJI1
('58', 484, 9, 12, 890867) December 6, 1932
('58', 484, 10, 13, 890884) I humbly beg to approach you as the greatest man of India, nay of the whole world, in view of the fact that you claim to be a sanatanist.
('58', 484, 11, 14, 891022) You know that Dadhichi gave up his bones for the benefit of the Devas, when they asked for them, but you are going to lay down your life without the asking.

('58', 492, 2, 4, 909300) What we said was that some madhyasthas 1 will have to be appointed and it will have to be settled what
('58', 492, 3, 5, 909403) books shall be relied upon and the rules of interpretation will have to be settled.
('58', 492, 4, 6, 909487) It is, therefore, absolutely necessary that you will please mention the names of any two gentlemen of experience, position and dignity to sit as madhyasthas and
('58', 492, 5, 7, 909648) the names of the pundits whom you or Acharya Dhruva intend to call to support your statements.
('58', 492, 6, 8, 909743) As soon as this is done, we shall mention the names of our pundits and the two madhyasthas.
('58', 492, 7, 9, 909835) The duty of the madhyasthas will not be the duty of the Chairman but
('58', 492, 8, 10, 909904) the duty will be to see that the discussion is carried on in writing in an organized manner.
('58', 492, 9, 11, 909997) Our sole desire is that the discussion should be carried on in an organized manner as has been stated to you in the very beginning and not merely a fruitless discussion.
('58', 492, 10, 12, 910167) As has already been settled in the correspondence, the objects of the discussion would be to investigate and find out the truth whether untouchabi lity is enjoined by Shastras and whether there are restrictions in Shastras on untouchables’ temple entry.
('58', 492, 10, 13, 910421) We take it that if it is done and the pundits whom you call are unable to support the view hitherto propounded by them, you will retrace your steps.
('58', 492, 11, 14, 910570) Yours truly,
('58', 492, 12, 15, 910583) HIRALAL D. NANAVATI
('58', 492, 13, 16, 910603) SECRETARY, A.I.V.S. SANGH M. K. GANDHI, ESQ.

('58', 493, 0, 1, 910714) 494 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('58', 493, 1, 2, 910756) APPENDIX XVI
('58', 493, 2, 3, 910769) LETTER FROM G. D. BIRLA 1
('58', 493, 3, 4, 910795) BIRLA HOUSE, ALBUQUERQUE ROAD, NEW DELHI,
('58', 493, 4, 5, 910837) December 14, 1932
('58', 493, 5, 6, 910855) MY DEAR BAPU,
('58', 493, 6, 7, 910869) I have received today the resignation from Dr. Roy.
('58', 493, 6, 8, 910921) He has also sent to me a copy of his letter to you which he wrote in this connection.
('58', 493, 6, 9, 911007) I am accepting his resignation.
('58', 493, 6, 10, 911039) The more I think of the matter the more I feel that our troubles are not ended.
('58', 493, 6, 11, 911119) Dr. Roy is not a quarrelsome man, and I hope he may forget the whole incident.
('58', 493, 6, 12, 911198) But I doubt if his followers will so easily forget it.
('58', 493, 6, 13, 911253) Besides I feel the public would not sympathize with Satisbabu and Sureshbabu, as in my opinion by humiliating Dr. Roy they have put themselves absolutely in the wrong.
('58', 493, 6, 14, 911421) Thus your action instead of soothing the situation may cause a greater gulf between the various parties in Bengal.
('58', 493, 6, 15, 911536) Satisbabu and Sureshbabu both being closely related to you, probably it would have been better for them to yield rather than wish for Dr. Roy’s resignation.
('58', 493, 6, 16, 911693) This would have helped easing the situation.
('58', 493, 6, 17, 911738) As it is, you have given Bengalis cause to feel that it was a non Bengali who could make or unmake Presidents of public bodies.
('58', 493, 6, 18, 911866) This would surely be resented.
('58', 493, 6, 19, 911897) If I were 2 Dr. B. C. Roy, I would refuse to accept Presidentship under such circumstances.
('58', 493, 6, 20, 911989) I, however, express these views just for your information and that of Satisbabu, if he is still there.
('58', 493, 6, 21, 912092) Let me hope, this will end the trouble.
('58', 493, 7, 22, 912132) We are coming out with the first issue of our weekly on the Ist of January.
('58', 493, 7, 23, 912208) Please therefore send us your article in time.
('58', 493, 8, 24, 912255) Yours affectionately,
('58', 493, 9, 25, 912277) M. K. GANDHI, ESQ.
('58', 493, 10, 26, 912296) From a photostat: S.N. 18704
('58', 493, 11, 27, 912325) 1 Vide “Letter to G. D. Birla”, 20 12 1932.
('58', 493, 12, 28, 912369) 2The source has “would be”.

('58', 494, 1, 2, 912445) APPENDIX XVII
('58', 494, 2, 3, 912459) EXTRACT FROM LETTER FROM C. F. ANDREWS 1
('58', 494, 3, 4, 912500) November 10, 1932
('58', 494, 4, 5, 912518) The whole of my own religious upbringing has been such as to make any thought of suicide on my part impossible.
('58', 494, 5, 6, 912630) I am really troubled still .
('58', 494, 5, 7, 912659) such a practice as this will certainly be used by fanatics to force an issue which may be reactionary instead of progressive.
('58', 494, 5, 8, 912785) Human madness or even doting affection may become tyrannical in this way.
('58', 494, 5, 9, 912859) How far my anxieties and fears are mixed with weak human affection I can hardly myself understand.
('58', 494, 5, 10, 912958) I do know that I saw you finally giving your life itself for the Depressed Classes, in your last fast, and I was glad—I saw in it the ‘greater love’.
('58', 494, 5, 11, 913108) I can see you now preparing to do the same thing on January Ist, if the temple authorities do not give way.
('58', 494, 6, 12, 913216) It seems to me that I would very gladly lay down my life to remove ‘untouchability’, between the white race fanatics who call themselves Christians and the other races.
('58', 494, 6, 13, 913385) But you have evidently come to the point of forcing the issue, literally forcing it, and I have to think that out in terms of Christ.
('58', 494, 7, 14, 913519) I think He did force the issue, when He set His face steadfastly to go to Jerusalem.
('58', 494, 7, 15, 913604) He saw then, I think, that only His own death could call the Jewish leaders to a halt.
('58', 494, 7, 16, 913691) There is one strange saying of His, ‘The Kingdom of Heaven suffereth violence, and the violent take it by force.’ Again I am not sure whether His act in cleansing the temple was not of the same character, i.e., forcing the issue.
('58', 494, 7, 17, 913921) But the method of fasting, committing suicide, still instinctively repels me.
('58', 494, 8, 18, 913999) Charles Freer Andrews, p.
('58', 494, 9, 19, 914025) APPENDIX XVIII
('58', 494, 10, 20, 914040) DISCUSSION WITH K. KELAPPAN 2
('58', 494, 11, 21, 914070) December 29, 1932
('58', 494, 12, 22, 914088) KELAPPAN: When I asked you to share my burden, I said nothing about the fast.
('58', 494, 13, 23, 914166) GANDHIJI: Others gave what they could.
('58', 494, 13, 24, 914205) What had I to give other than a fast?
('58', 494, 13, 25, 914243) So you should have known that I would be sharing your burden only in some such way.
('58', 494, 13, 26, 914327) There is nothing wrong in this.
('58', 494, 13, 27, 914359) The more I think over it, the more I feel that the
('58', 494, 14, 28, 914410) 1Vide “Letter to C. F. Andrews”, 20 12 1932.
('58', 494, 15, 29, 914455) 2Vide “Interview to Associated Press of India”, 29 12 1932 and “Statement on Untouchability”, 30 12 1932.
('58', 495, 0, 1, 914561) 496 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('58', 495, 1, 2, 914603) complications I have created were necessary.
('58', 495, 1, 3, 914648) Hinduism is dying before my eyes.
('58', 495, 1, 4, 914682) If I want to revive it, what else is there for me to do?
('58', 495, 1, 5, 914739) You don’t know what is going on inside me.
('58', 495, 1, 6, 914782) You must wait and enquire and suffer.
('58', 495, 1, 7, 914820) If I have to fast, you must put up with it.
('58', 495, 1, 8, 914864) For the present the fast is postponed.
('58', 495, 1, 9, 914903) What the future has in store, I do not know.
('58', 495, 1, 10, 914948) Maybe, fasting will be unnecessary.
('58', 495, 1, 11, 914984) Or I may feel that to undertake a fast for Guruvayur will be foolish and a waste of energy.
('58', 495, 1, 12, 915076) You will benefit from the confusion I am causing you.
('58', 495, 1, 13, 915130) The questions which Rajaji asked yesterday have set me thinking and maybe my statement will take a different shape.
('58', 495, 1, 14, 915246) But you should let the matter rest here and set to work at once.
('58', 495, 1, 15, 915311) Try to understand the inner meaning of the fast, of the eradication of untouchability and of temple entry.
('58', 495, 1, 16, 915418) I feel that if we can get rid of untouchability the right way, it will be the saving of Hinduism.
('58', 495, 1, 17, 915516) Otherwise, there is going to be a fierce fight between caste Hindus and the so called untouchables.
('58', 495, 1, 18, 915616) The untouchables will fight with violent rage and hatred and in sheer desperation will try to obliterate Hinduism from the face of the earth.
('58', 495, 1, 19, 915758) They are not going to deny Hinduism.
('58', 495, 1, 20, 915795) They are also not going to embrace any other religion.
('58', 495, 1, 21, 915850) But they will deny God.
('58', 495, 1, 22, 915874) This strife will be more fierce than between Brahmins and non Brahmins because they feel the pain more deeply.
('58', 495, 1, 23, 915985) My fast may prevent such a strife, though I do not know.
('58', 495, 1, 24, 916042) Or it may not have any effect.
('58', 495, 1, 25, 916073) But I did not go in search of the fast.
('58', 495, 1, 26, 916113) I lay in bed thinking about an ugly decision of the Government and this question of yours came up before me and I plunged into it.
('58', 495, 1, 27, 916244) At that time, I did not even know that it would call for a fast.
('58', 495, 1, 28, 916309) You did right in acquainting me with all the facts.
('58', 495, 1, 29, 916361) Other friends also sent me telegrams, which too was proper.
('58', 495, 1, 30, 916421) Everything that has happened has been for the good.
('58', 495, 2, 31, 916473) [From Gujarati]
('58', 495, 3, 32, 916489) Mahadevbhaini Diary, Vol. II, pp.
('58', 495, 4, 33, 916523) APPENDIX XIX
('58', 495, 5, 34, 916536) DISCUSSION WITH MAHADEV DESAI
('58', 495, 6, 35, 916566) BAPU: In a religious matter nobody should accept anyone else’s opinion as binding.
('58', 495, 6, 36, 916649) One must rely on one’s own intuition.
('58', 495, 7, 37, 916687) MAHADEV: Then we should not join in calling the Parishad.
('58', 495, 8, 38, 916745) BAPU: We are not doing that.
('58', 495, 8, 39, 916774) They are calling the Parishad on their own.
('58', 495, 8, 40, 916818) I tell them that if they can convince me that I am wrong, I will admit my error.
('58', 495, 9, 41, 916899) MAHADEV: Then we should not concern ourselves with whether or not the Parishad comes to a unanimous decision.
('58', 495, 9, 42, 917009) You should merely say, you are keeping an open mind.
('58', 495, 9, 43, 917062) That’s enough.
('58', 495, 9, 44, 917077) Bapu further explained: Look at the man asking me why I do not challenge my opponents to a public discussion and defeat them, as Shankaracharya did.
('58', 495, 9, 45, 917226) I tell him that that is beyond my strength.
('58', 495, 9, 46, 917270) My strength is of a different character and I am using it.
('58', 495, 9, 47, 917329) How can I change my idea of dharma in deference to other people’s views?
('58', 495, 10, 48, 917402) [From Gujarati]
('58', 495, 11, 49, 917418) Mahadevbhaini Diary, Vol. II, p.
